Under the procedures prescribed by the Senate, I am required to determine whether a motion to refer this matter to the Privileges Committee should have precedence of other business, having regard to the following criteria:

In making my determination, I do not make a judgment on the facts of the matter raised or on the question of whether any contempt has been committed.

In previous rulings I have indicated to the Senate the way in which I apply this criteria. I have given precedence to a motion if I consider that the matter raised is capable of being regarded by the Senate as meeting criterion (a), and if there is no other readily available remedy.

I consider that a motion relating to the matter raised by Senate Newman ought to have precedence, having regard to the criteria. The Senate has always taken very seriously any suggestion that misleading evidence has been given to a Senate Committee. Senate Newman has drawn my attention to the fifteenth report of the Privileges Committee, indicating the seriousness with which that Committee regards the obligation of witnesses to give evidence which is not misleading in any respect. I have had regard to that report in making my determination.
I therefore determine that a motion to refer this matter to the Privileges Committee should have precedence over other business.

The speech read as follows-
I have great pleasure, on behalf of the Liberal and National parties, in presenting the Flags Amendment Bill 1990.

This Bill provides for amendments to the Flags Act 1953 to ensure that the Australian National Flag is not altered except with the approval of the Australian people voting in a referendum, that the Australian National Flag is not supplanted by use of the powers under the Act, and that the appointment of other flags and ensigns is subject to disallowance by either House of the Parliament.

The Opposition believes strongly in the integrity of the National Flag as it is presently designed and responds to a strong feeling in the community that it should not be altered without approval from the Australian people at a referendum.
The Bill has already been introduced to the House of Representatives and I look forward to the opportunity to debate it in this chamber.

Some people today talk rather vaguely about having our own flag because we are now `grown-up' and `independent'. As somebody has already said, we gained our flag because we are already grown-up and independent.

In 1901 the Flag of Australia design contest drew some 32,000 entries and I understand five of the entries were considered of equal merit. The final design incorporated each of the features suggested by those five. As a symbol of a British settlement it made use of the Union Jack, in the form of the British Blue Ensign. But most conspicuously it displayed the five stars of the Southern Cross from which the early discoverers (Cook) of our land plotted their passage. An additional large, white star was placed in the hoist. This corresponds with nothing in the sky, it is purely symbolic of the Australian Commonwealth, its seven points representing the six States and the Territories.
The flag was created at the same time as the Commonwealth of Australia itself was inaugurated under the slogan `One people: One Destiny: One Flag'.

The Flag was accepted immediately by the people, and, although originally intended mainly for use by the Government and Armed Forces, by 1947 it had become so popular that Prime Minister Chifley announced it was to be flown `freely' and `with appropriate respect'. In 1953 Prime Minister Menzies and Opposition Leader Calwell both strongly supported the Flag Act, signed personally by Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II.

In Mr Calwell's words, `it represents something of immense value' and `therefore we ought to give it great respect and teach our children to feel that while it flies there is hope for Australia and its future'.

As a Queenslander I must add that the first official unfurling of the Australian National Flag, the Blue Ensign, was at the opening of the Townsville Town Hall on 16 September, 1901 by the Governor-General, Lord Hopetoun. Earlier that month Prime Minister Barton and Lady Hopetoun opened the ceremony for the naming of the winning design at the Exhibition Building in Melbourne and the flag was flown from the great dome.
I mention this history as the passing of time can lead to distortion and neglect. The creation of the National Flag is an important part of our history which should not be forgotten.
Every move by the Opposition to protect the flag and prevent it being changed without the approval of the Australian people by referendum has been thwarted by the Hawke Labor Government.
We have been trying to make legislative provision for such protection since 1985. But on that occasion and two subsequent ones Labor has blocked amending Bills.
Following his flurry of national fervour during the Bicentennial year Prime Minister Hawke would have us all believe the Labor Government and its apparatchiks in the Labor movement have no such wish.
But can they be taken at their word? As recently as 1981 the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) said:

. . . I think we can do rather better than the present undistinguished and indistinctive bit of cloth which we have inherited from our colonial past and which manifestly does not set anybody's pulse racing in the community at large except, perhaps the occasional Returned Services League blimp or a proportion of the tory backbench opposite.

This from the same Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade who wore a Ho Chi Minh badge whilst on official Australian Government business in Vietnam. Four hundred and twenty-four Australians sacrificed their lives in battle against Ho Chi Minh's Marxist Leninist revolutionary North Vietnamese forces. Tens of thousands of Australians of Indo-Chinese origin were forced to leave their homes in Vietnam, Kampuchea and Laos because of oppression by liberation movements generated by Ho Chi Minh and his ilk. Surely they would find the Minister's attitude sinister?

The Opposition has no doubt that the majority of Australians, of every differing status, race and creed, are drawn together by the symbol and history of our present National Flag. The Opposition also believes that the Labor Government and Labor Party have people within their ranks who cannot be trusted with the legislation as it now stands. We believe that in the event of a change the people of Australia must be consulted. We believe that the Flags Amendment Bill must be debated fairly, and as a consequence brought into law.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The Bill proposes a variety of amendments to Acts dealing with defence matters. The more important amendments:
A. Amend defence force retirement and death benefits legislation to increase the orphans' benefit from $702 to $5000.
B. Remove restrictions on the Chief of the Defence Force's power to make single service command appointments and organisational arrangements.
C. Modify provisions relating to the enlistment of soldiers and sailors to enable the open ended enlistment scheme to operate more effectively.
D. Amend Commonwealth acts to replace references to the Joint Intelligence Organisation with references to the Defence Intelligence Organisation.
Other amendments:
A. Remove redundant provisions dealing with seniority.
B. Amend the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 to replace obsolete references to the offence of rape with references to the current A.C.T. provisions that have replaced that former offence.
C. Amend the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act (No. 1) 1985 to remove an unnecessary provision dealing with allotments.
I will now deal with the more important amendments. The other changes are explained in the explanatory memorandum.
Orphans benefits

The increases in the orphans benefits proposed by the amendments in schedule 2 are those that the government announced in both Houses of Parliament on 11 May 1989 in responding to the report on personnel wastage in the Defence Force by the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade (the Cross Committee). As was then indicated the level of orphans benefits under the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Scheme and the Defence Forces Retirement Benefits Scheme were considerably less than those under the Commonwealth superannuation schemes. The increase of some $4300 for each orphan will correct the situation.
The total benefits payable in respect of the orphans of a deceased member or pensioner will be capped at the maximum rate of pension that would have been payable to the member or pensioner.
About 140 orphans will benefit immediately from the increases.
Command power of the Chief of the Defence Force

Current command arrangements allow the Chief of the Defence Force to command all operations conducted by the Australian Defence Force. These arrangements have been put into place as a result of the on-going process of refining the command of the Australian Defence Force. They are the result of implementing the recommendations of a study into ADF command arrangements conducted in 1987. The existing legislation obliges the Chief of the Defence Force to implement single service appointments and organisational arrangements through the service chiefs of staff. To provide the appropriate legal basis for the current arrangements, these restrictions upon the Chief of the Defence Force's command power need to be removed. The amendments make the necessary changes to the Defence Act and Naval Defence Act.

The amendments in no way detract from the provision for command appointments and organisational arrangements under the Acts, as remaining provisions will contain adequate authority for these matters. There will therefore be no need to replace the provisions that have been omitted or repealed.

The new operational command arrangements have been implemented with the support of the service chiefs of staff. While they no longer conduct operations, they continue to train and administer their respective arms of the Defence Force, and provide advice as the professional heads of their respective services.
Open ended enlistment

In 1987 the Defence Act and Naval Defence Act were amended to allow service administrators to offer enlistment to retiring age as well as enlistment for a fixed period. A soldier or sailor enlisted until retiring age may claim his or her discharge on giving an appropriate period of notice (which in relation to members of the permanent forces is 12 months or such lesser period determined by a chief of staff).

It was the intention of service administrators at that time to offer, initially, enlistment for a fixed period followed by the option of extension until retiring age. Service administrators now consider that it is more efficient to enlist a soldier or sailor initially until retiring age but require that a minimum period of service be required before a discharge may be claimed.

The amendments proposed to the Defence Act and Naval Defence Act include a provision so that a soldier or sailor of the permanent forces who has enlisted until retiring age does not have a right to claim a discharge during the first 6 years of service, or such lesser period as a chief of staff determines. Historically six years is the minimum initial period of service required to be served.

To enable effective implementation of the open ended enlistment scheme, the amendments proposed require that the approval of a chief of staff be required for any variation or withdrawal of a claim for discharge. This amendment is required to avoid manipulation of the procedure of claiming a discharge.

Factors required to be taken into account by a chief of staff in determining a lesser period of service before which a discharge may be claimed and in considering approval of a variation or withdrawal of a claim for discharge are included in the proposed amendments.
It will still be open to a soldier or sailor to request a discharge at any time.
Joint Intelligence Organisation

On 1 March 1989 the then Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley announced some changes to defence intelligence arrangements, and in particular the combining of the functions of the Joint Intelligence Organisation with those of the intelligence group in the Australian Defence Force headquarters. Mr Beazley also announced that this restructured body will be known as the Defence Intelligence Organisation the new name better reflects the body's central role in the preparation of defence intelligence assessments and the provision of operational intelligence for the Australian Defence Force. The amendments make consequential name changes to the various Commonwealth Acts containing references to the Joint Intelligence Organisation. These changes will enable the formal re-naming of the body.
Financial impact statement
It is estimated that the increase in the orphans' benefits will cost approximately $600,000 a year.
The other provisions of the Bill have no financial impact.

Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill proposes amendments to the Customs Act 1901 to repeal the current power to detain and search persons suspected of unlawfully carrying prohibited goods, and insert in its place new division containing a more comprehensive range of customs detention and search powers. The Bill gives effect to several major elements of the Government's anti-drug strategy. Foremost amongst these is:

The Government's decision to implement the legislative framework for the detention and, if necessary, search of persons reasonably suspected of importing narcotics by internal concealment, which has been settled in consultation with the Commonwealth-States Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy as one of the outcomes of the 1985 `Drug Summit', and

The Government's decision announced on 18 July 1989 to allow authorised customs officers to stop and frisk search persons for prohibited goods within customs controlled areas at international air and sea ports.

The Bill is substantially the same as the one which was introduced last session into the Parliament, with the exception of minor amendments which have arisen as a result of briefings on that Bill with the Law Council of Australia and the then Opposition spokesperson on customs. The amendments in particular provide:

an express right to an interpreter for detainees not able to communicate with reasonable fluency in English, to allay concerns that a detainee might not appreciate the consequences which flow from a failure to cooperate with a frisk-search, for example, by reason only of the detainee's inadequate knowledge of the English language. This new right appears in proposed new section 219zd, on page 16 of the attached Bill.

The other two minor amendments are to proposed sub-sections 219r (10) and 219v (11), and are explained in detail in the relevant notes on clauses in the explanatory memorandum which accompanies this Bill, on pages 20 and 26 respectively.

It is indeed an unfortunate fact of our modern-day life that there are persons who wish to corrupt our society by importing illicit drugs, and some of those persons will even go to the extent of concealing the drugs inside their bodies or force a courier to do the same, in order to escape detection. Tragically some of those persons or couriers pay for this very dangerous and difficult attempt to avoid detection with their lives.

The present Customs Act power to detain and search persons reasonably suspected of carrying prohibited goods has remained largely unchanged since Federation, and is currently contained in section 196 of the Act. The section however does not deal adequately with the problem of internal concealment in that it does not expressly provide adequate protections and rights either for the officers or suspects concerned or the medical practitioners who may be asked to conduct an internal search.

On the other end of the spectrum, the present detention and search regime is unnecessarily complicated for the simple frisk of a person at the customs barrier. With evidence to hand of a growing trend towards the importation of drugs using concealment on the body, and the community's expectation and legitimate demand when travelling for a speedy clearance through the customs barrier, a corresponding mechanism for the quick and efficient checking of persons reasonably suspected of carrying prohibited goods is necessary.

The proposed new division lB inserted by clause 8 of the Bill, proposes 23 new sections for part II of the Customs Act 1901, bringing together the full range of proposed customs body-search powers, from the least intrusive frisk, through external search, to the more intrusive internal search. By splitting the three types of searches into distinct subdivisions, the new division not only highlights the progressive strengthening of the statutory protections and rights afforded persons to be searched as the level of intrusiveness increases, but it also highlights the more rigorous legal requirements on officers of Customs and police as the searches become more invasive.

The first level of search, the frisk search, is set out in proposed new subdivision a of the Bill, new sections 219L to P. It is limited to customs controlled areas at international air and sea ports, and will be available to enable the detention of persons by customs where a customs supervisory officer suspects on reasonable ground that a person is unlawfully carrying any prohibited goods.

The search itself, which is a common and widespread barrier feature of most customs administrations around the globe, involves the quick pat-down of a person's outer garments and must be carried out as soon as practicable after the person is detained, by an officer of customs of the same sex as the detainee, and in private if so requested. The proposed regime includes the right of customs to require the production of any thing revealed by the frisk search, in order to determine whether the thing is, or contains, prohibited goods.

Failure to submit to a lawful frisk search, or to produce upon request a thing revealed by the search, shall constitute sufficient grounds for the next level of search, an external search, under proposed new subdivision B.

This second level of search, the external search, in proposed subdivision B, new sections 219q and r, effectively continues the current detention and search power in section 196 of the Customs Act, with minor drafting amendments to make it consistent with the proposed new frisk and internal search regimes, and express provisions to highlight a person's rights if detained for such a search. The initial decision to detain a person under this regime is one which must be taken by an authorised customs officer, an experienced officer of supervisory rank, or an officer of police, who must decide whether there is sufficient cause to suspect that a person is unlawfully carrying any prohibited goods.

Where a person is detained the detainee must be taken as soon as practicable to either a special detention place or a place that offers the detainee adequate personal privacy. The customs or police then must apply, as soon as practicable, for an order for an external search from a justice of the peace, the Comptroller-General of Customs or an authorised officer of supervisory rank, unless the detainee consents to be searched.

Special protection is provided for those detainees which the Bill describes as `in need of protection'; effectively those persons who because of their age, under 17, or mental or physical incapacity, are entitled to special rights. Consistent with the spirit of Australia's international commitments under human rights and privacy conventions, especially with regard to children, such persons may only be searched by order, and any search order is to be carried out in the presence of the detainee's legal guardian or another person capable of representing the detainee's interests, with that person, so far as practicable, being acceptable to the detainee.

Finally, similar to the frisk regime, where an external search is to be carried out on a detainee, the search must be carried out by a person who is of the same sex as the detainee. Further, an express right to an interpreter has been provided when communication with or by the detainee is to take place, for those detainees not able to communicate orally with reasonable fluency in the English language.

The final level of search proposed by the Bill is the internal search, proposed by subdivisions C and E, new sections 219s to 219z, and 219zf to 219zj. The term internal search has been defined as an examination by a medical practitioner of the body of a person, including an internal examination of the person's body, to determine whether the person is internally concealing a narcotic substance, and includes the recovery of any substance suspected on reasonable grounds to be so concealed.

The overriding policy of this proposed regime is that if a search is not consented to, it will only be ordered as a last resort. To give effect to that policy, the Bill provides for two periods of 48 hour detention, which may only be ordered by a magistrate or judge, to maximise the chances of any drugs being eliminated naturally.

The Government appreciates that the detention of a person on suspicion only is a serious and very sensitive matter, and were it not for the fact that the control of the importation of drugs requires strong powers, the civil liberties implications of detention represented by this regime would not have been countenanced. Therefore the Bill provides detention will occur only when that action is authorised by an appropriately senior judicial officer-that is a judge or magistrate.

In that respect, this part of the Bill is similar to the Customs Amendment Act of 1979 which proposed an internal body-search regime, but which was never proclaimed. The protections afforded suspected persons under the terms of that amendment Act were not considered adequate and, partly as a consequence, all the States and the Northern Territory were not able to agree to provide access to the necessary judicial officers before the Act could be proclaimed. As far as the detention and internal search provisions of this Bill are concerned, the Government has included specific provisions to protect the rights of persons detained, while retaining the practical and necessary flexibility for customs officers and police officers charged by the community with the responsibility of controlling the importation of narcotics. All States and the Northern Territory have been consulted on the terns of the Bill and are expected to agree, this time, to allow access to judges and magistrates to consider applications for orders to detain or search under the terms of the internal search regime. This exercise has been a protracted one and various amendments and suggestions made in the course of those discussions have been incorporated in the Bill.

In addition, consultations on the obvious privacy and human rights implications of this regime have occurred over the period during which this Bill has been settled, to ensure as far as practicable that the rights of the individual are not submerged by the community's interest to control the influx of drugs into this country. The rights in particular of a detainee at any time during detention under the internal search regime to consult a lawyer of his or her choice, to have adequate opportunity to obtain legal advice and legal representation in relation to detention and search order applications, and to have the services of an interpreter where the detainee is liable to communicate with reasonable fluency in the English language, are ample evidence of the civil rights emphasis proposed by the Bill.

Finally, I think it is important to put into context the frequency of current detention and search activity at the customs barrier, to allay any fears that the proposed powers in this Bill might in fact alter markedly the current practice of passenger processing.

The power of search of persons under the Customs Act presently is exercised mainly by customs officers and mainly at Australia's international airports. In 1988-89 the total number of persons searched was 2,505, which represents 0.06% of the total arriving passenger population of 4.2m. Of this number of searches, 102 persons where detained for internal search and, in most cases, those persons consented to x-ray by a medical practitioner. The figures clearly show that the present power is exercised in a judicious and controlled way, and it is not expected, as a result of this Bill, that the number of persons searched should show any marked increase.
Financial impact statement

The costs associated with this Bill relate to the provision of medical and judicial personnel for the internal search regime (new subdivision C and E of proposed new division lB). It is estimated the costs for medical personnel and facilities to carry out those internal searches which are ordered, and the costs of the States' and Territories' judicial officers to service detention and search order applications, will total $150,000 per annum.

Mr President, the Administrative Services Legislation Amendment Bill contains amendments to a number of Acts administered by the Administrative Services portfolio. The amendments are of a kind which, in recent years, it has been the practice to include in an omnibus Bill.
Amendments of the Archives Act 1983
The Government has decided that the Australian Archives should charge for certain discretionary services to Commonwealth agencies where such charges would promote efficiency and effectiveness.

Currently, the levying of charges by archives for any of its services must be prescribed by regulation in accordance with section 71 of the Archives Act. It is proposed that the Archives Act be amended so that the Director-General may levy charges on Commonwealth agencies without recourse to regulations.

The proposed amendment is designed to provide the Archives with the same degree of flexibility in its charging policy as will be available to any private sector competitors who are able to determine charges in accordance with market conditions. This amendment is necessary to enable the Archives to implement fully the Government's policy of using interdepartmental charging to impose economic discipline on both the suppliers and the users of common services with the Australian Government administration.
Repeal of the Naval Properties Act 1925

Mr President, this Act provides for ratifying agreements between the Commonwealth and the New South Wales Government for the transfer of Cockatoo and Schnapper islands from the New South Wales Government and part of Goat Island from the Commonwealth.
In 1985 the New South Wales Government granted an easement in gross which protects the Commonwealth's maritime rights. Thus this Act is no longer necessary and the Bill proposes that it be repealed.
Repeal of the Procurement of Goods, Works and Services Act 1981

The Procurement of Goods, Works and Services Act has two essential features. It provides a legislative basis for a preference scheme in support of the purchase of Australian goods by government authorities and a framework for centralised purchasing.

The legislation has been contentious since its enactment. It has since been overtaken by a series of purchasing reforms and new preference arrangements, developed following consultation with Australian industry, being phased in from 1 November 1989.
Amendments of Parliamentary Allowances Act 1952

Mr President, this Bill also seeks to amend the Parliamentary Allowances Act 1952. The Act provides for the continuation of salary payments to members of the Parliament from the date of dissolution of either House or of the Parliament until polling day, where members are to be candidates for election.
The Act also sets the circumstances under which additional salary and allowances determined by the Remuneration Tribunal are paid to certain office holders of the Parliament.

Currently the Act provides that additional salary and allowances are not payable to office holders with the exception of the President of the Senate, Speaker of the House and the chairmen of both Houses between the dissolution of either House and polling day.
It is the considered view that all office holders continue to exercise their responsibilities over the period in question and consequently that the Act should be amended to reflect this.
It is proposed that salaries and allowances payable to office holders who are candidates for election continue to be paid between dissolution of either House and polling day.
Amendment of the Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1) 1930 and Social Security Act 1947
These Acts are amended to remove reference to the Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services which was sold and is now no longer a Commonwealth instrumentality.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would not be evidence in camera if he was not going to object to it being made public.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it today the Airlines Agreement (Termination) Bill, which will repeal the Airlines Agreement Act 1981, the Airlines Equipment Act 1958, the Independent Air Fares Committee Act 1981 and related regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: It is one of those strange ironies that happen in political life that I have been asked to put the Opposition's case in supporting this legislation. Going back through Hansard, I found that there are only 16 senators now who were present when the 1981 Bill went through. There is more than a touch of irony in the fact that, if I had had one more vote in 1981, the 1981 legislation would not have gone through. I was very strongly opposed to it. I had to take the position of opposition, at considerable personal difficulty and stress, to my own Party, which was in government at the time, because I believed very strongly that what we were doing then was not in the interests of the Australian nation in a commercial sense.

As I say, the Bill passed through the Senate by a majority of two votes. If one other person had changed his mind at the time, the Bill would not have gone through. I believe we would all have been better off if the two-airline Bill had not been passed in 1981. In my judgment, by the end of the 1960s and certainly by the early 1970s, the two-airline agreement system regulating that there be only two major carriers within Australia had ceased to have any relevance or benefit. Today I am quite sure that, when the shadow Ministry asked me to manage this Bill on behalf of the Opposition, no one recalled the history of what was involved, in asking me to do that. I have much pleasure, therefore, in saying that the Opposition supports the Government in what it proposes to do with this legislation.

The legislation will mean that control over importation is removed. One of the ways in which the two-airline Bill was enforced was by having in the Customs Act a prohibition which denied any airline other than Trans-Australia Airlines- TAA, as it was then-and Ansett Airlines of Australia the ability to import aircraft into Australia. That meant that, if the legislation was outflanked by any means and a licence was granted to an airline, it did not help much because the airline simply could not get aircraft into the country.

The great benefit-and what I was arguing for in 1981-was that it may well have been that two major carriers were all we needed in this country, but we certainly needed the opportunity for a third or even a fourth carrier to be able to enter the market; and the threat of another carrier entering the market would have provided some stimulus to the smug duopoly that we have enjoyed in this country for decades.

I was also opposed to the introduction of the Independent Air Fares Commission, which was one of the consequences of the 1981 Bill. I have a view that it is not the business of a government-any government-to be involved in the commercial marketplace. I think that the market has its own systems of censure and reward which provide adequate guidance to commercial operators, and the business of deciding what an air fare should be should be left in the hands of those who are trying to make a living out of it. They have far more expertise than the best-intentioned public servant trying to sit in judgment on it.

The Government gave notice on 5 June 1987 of its intention to terminate the agreement. At the time, the Minister stated that the policy had `outlived its usefulness to the Australian public and was unduly restrictive'. The 1981 Bill provided that the two-airline agreement would stand until 1990, but that any of the three signatories to the agreement were able to give notice of termination from January 1987.

The two-airline Bill failed because it did not provide any avenues of commercial competition between the two airlines. In effect, the less commercially successful of the two airlines set a fare structure so that it could maintain some profitability. As I said in 1981, all that that Bill has produced in terms of competition has been a very phoney form of competition to see who could give away the most food and drink. That has only added to the cost of travel to the Australian public.

All the indices done on Australian airlines-I use Australian in a national sense; I do not mean Australian Airlines Ltd-show that in terms of passengers per employee and tonne miles of freight carried, the Australian domestic airlines shape up very poorly when compared with overseas competitors. These overseas competitors are not merely 50 per cent more efficient; American operators are probably many times more efficient. This has occurred because there has been no commercial pressure on the Australian domestic airlines. They followed whatever practices they wanted to because basically they were operating on a cost-plus basis.

As I mentioned yesterday when speaking on the report of the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots' Dispute, the lack of commercial pressures enabled the managements of Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines to indulge whatever demands their employees made upon them, not only during a one- or two-year period but over the decades. The airlines ended up with probably twice the number of employees that they really needed.

In the sequel to the pilots dispute we see that the airlines are now getting by with about 50 per cent of the pilots they had before, admittedly with reduced services and hours flown. I venture to suggest that if they were to adopt the same approach to the baggage handlers, the flight attendants and the maintenance people very significant reductions would be possible.
But all that will change in the period after the repeal of this legislation. The possibility for some competition will exist.

How did we get into this position? We have to look at the history of Australian main trunk carriers. In November 1944, during the time that a Labor government was in power, the Acting Prime Minister decided that the Government would set up a wholly owned statutory authority to operate the internal airline services, which meant that the then Australian National Airways (ANA) would be nationalised. During that period ANA was the major airline within Australia.

The proposal was thrown out because the High Court held that it was not possible for the Commonwealth to restrict trade between the States. The counter to that was to introduce the Australian National Airlines Bill, which created Trans-Australia Airlines Ltd. Trans-Australia Airlines was a very different airline from what it has become. It was staffed mainly by ex-Air Force pilots and officers. It was fairly well managed. At the time it was an aggressive and an innovative company. Through the late 1940s and the 1950s it provided a great deal of competition for Australian National Airways.

It was really the competition that it provided, coupled with the poor commercial judgment of Australian National Airways at the time, which led to Australian National Airways getting into very considerable commercial difficulties.

Australian National Airways failed to appreciate the changes in technology that were taking place in the late 1940s and the early 1950s, such as the introduction of pressurised aircraft. It persisted with DC3s and DC4s, which were eminently practical and suitable for the routes, but TAA came along with the pressurised Convair 240s and offered a better service to the travelling public.

We then had the introduction of the first of the turboprop aircraft. TAA was one of the early customers to buy Viscounts. The difference between the turboprop Viscounts and the DC6As and the DC6Bs, which ANA was operating at the time, was very marked in the eyes of the public. TAA got most of the passenger trade.

Finally, Sir Ivan Holyman, who was the principal force in the old Australian National Airways, died in Honolulu coming back from America. The company had also been under pressure from other lesser airlines, such as Ansett and Butler Air Transport in New South Wales, and the company simply could not carry on.

Reginald Ansett, as he was then, made an offer to take over the Australian National Airways company. This meant that he had to borrow a great deal of money, which he did not have. He simply would not go ahead and take over Australian National Airways without some guarantee from the Government of the day that he would not be run out of business by the Government putting all its resources behind a government owned airline which could afford to operate without respect to a balance sheet, secure in the knowledge that it could get whatever it required from the public purse to keep it going.

The Prime Minister of the day, Robert Menzies, very wisely said that he did not wish to see a monopoly develop in the internal air services. He did not want to support the merging of TAA with ANA as it was. Thank goodness he did not. If he had supported that, we would have ended up with air services as bad as those of Telecom Australia; again, we would have had a giant monopoly run by the unions, and it would have been so bad that we would probably all be driving between capital cities.

The two airline agreement had its origins in providing defence for the private or the public company competing with the government airline. However much the far Left of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) might hate it, this legislation seals the fate of Australian Airlines. As a consequence of this legislation, Australian Airlines must be sold at a future date, however unpalatable that might be to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), who is at the table.

The first of the two-airline agreements was put in place. There was a disparity with respect to equipment. The equipment that TAA had was far more advanced than that of ANA from a public appeal point of view. There was some rather unusual cross-chartering-maybe even sale-agreements where some of the TAA Viscounts were transferred to ANA and ANA transferred at least two of its DC6Bs to TAA. They were quite useful on the long hauls between Melbourne and Perth because they were pressurised and were long-range aircraft. They were more suited to that route than the early Viscounts.

Restrictions were introduced on competition. There had to be equal access to the routes on the major trunk sectors. There had to be equivalence in passenger capacity. In all ways, the Government tried to level the playing fields between the two airlines.

At the time that policy was eminently appropriate. It was successful. However, by the end of the 1960s the need for it had passed. By the time we entered the 1970s it should have been replaced by some other form, guaranteeing the opportunity for companies to provide internal services on the Australian trunk routes.

The final piece of legislation was the 1981 Bill, which I referred to earlier and which really set in place the earlier agreements. It provided that the two airlines could operate virtually without challenge from a third competitor. In a sense it made it worse in so far as it set up the Independent Air Fares Committee (IAFC) and thereby increased the possibility of no airline losing money on the system. The airline just had to appeal to the IAFC and say, `These are our operating costs. We therefore need a fare structure on these grounds to keep us solvent'.

Today, we have the withdrawal of that legislation and the prospect from October that third or fourth companies can enter the Australian internal trunk routes. The Opposition supports that because some years ago we came to the conclusion that was what was essential for Australian air travellers. There are certain consequences of that decision which we should spend a few moments looking at this morning.

It is inevitable that Australian Airlines has to be sold. One of the arguments that have been advanced in the public debate-and the Labor Party fights out all its factional brawls in public-is that it does need to be sold on the basis of equity capital alone. That is a very important point. If Australian Airlines, which is hugely undercapitalised at the present time, is to buy new equipment, it needs to have very large sources of money. It simply cannot get that from the Government. It has to go to private industry.

On the other side of the coin, the argument that led Reginald Ansett-as he was at the time-to demand that if he bought Australian National Airlines in 1957 he had to be protected against a government-owned airline which theoretically could lose money ad infinitum and drive any other airline out of business, is as valid today in 1990 as it was in 1957. That is a point that the government of the day, irrespective of its political complexion, has to cope with. That argument will resurface in time. It is not currently being debated on the public platform. But it is a very real argument that will have to be addressed.

I do not wish to descend to the level of entering into any of the rather vicious factional warfare that occurs in debates in the Australian Labor Party but I was interested to see the President of the Labor Party in Queensland talk about the impossibility of selling Qantas Airways Ltd because, after all, it was a national asset and it was developed by the people of Australia, the taxpayers, and it could not now be sold. Like the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, who is sitting at the table, the President of the Queensland ALP has very little depth to his aviation knowledge.

Qantas was started by private enterprise. An uncle of my wife was one of the first directors of that company in the early 1920s. It was largely private money from Queensland that led to Qantas being set up. Only after the Second World War did the Labor Party buy Qantas from private enterprise. Qantas was established not only as a private domestic airline but developed as an international carrier through private capital. There is nothing wrong with having private capital running airlines.

The Queensland President of the ALP, who is a member of the far Left and, as far as I can determine, has never taken any interest in defence matters, made the case that somehow or other it was important to have Qantas owned by the government because if we had a defence emergency that asset would be available to us. Qantas was a privately owned company. It lost aircraft during the Second World War. Many crew were killed. This private company served this nation as faithfully and as loyally as did the armed services. It is absolute nonsense to make the claim that because an airline might not be owned by the government it will not be available to us in times of emergency.

I now move to a second point that the Government has to address: the reform of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). The regulation system for aviation in Australia is very run down. We have a huge amount of overregulation which inhibits the operations not only in the commercial areas but in the private and recreational areas. The Government has made a constructive move in advertising around the world for the two senior positions in the Civil Aviation Authority. Personally, I am very optimistic that the Chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority, Mr Dick Smith, will bring long overdue changes to the regulatory system. The magnitude of some of those changes required is quite enormous.

If we look at the regulation of airspace, for example, we are still in a situation where many of the airspace requirements in Australia are arguably determined on the performance characteristics of aircraft in the 1940s. Quite huge blocks of airspace are reserved around our capital cities, for example, for the primary control zones. There is absolutely no need for this whatsoever.

In my own State the primary control zone for Brisbane Airport is so large that all the light aircraft traffic-of which about 98 per cent is single engine traffic-is forced to fly over some of the most inhospitable and dangerous terrain within about 100 miles of Brisbane. Those planes must fly at low level, at about 1,500 feet, over a tract of ground for about 20 or 30 miles where there is little possibility of a successful forced landing if an engine is lost. There is no reason on earth why the eastern boundary of the lane of entry to the north from the Brisbane Airport cannot be displaced three or four miles to the east. Instead of a ceiling of 1,500 feet, there is no reason why it could not be raised to perhaps 6,000 feet or more.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does that have to do with the termination of the two airlines agreement?
—If the Minister could follow anything, he would realise that I am pointing out some of the problems that are downstream for him. It is just not a matter of the Bills we have before us today.

SPEECH.PARA: We also have the problem of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC). It is all very well to say that we will get rid of the duopoly situation with respect to Australian Airlines and Ansett and allow third or fourth parties to enter into the provision of regular public transport services on main trunk routes. The passengers, and their baggage, have to get on those aircraft. This Government in collusion, principally, with Ansett has behaved very dishonestly with respect to terminals.

The Federal Airports Corporation legislation passed through this Parliament enabled that body to control a number of airports in Australia. Principally, the FAC controls the airports used by the two major internal carriers. The FAC, therefore, legally has control of the terminal buildings at Brisbane, Sydney, Melbourne and the other primary city airports. The Minister at the time, Senator Gareth Evans, entered into negotiations, principally with Ansett but also with Australian Airlines, which virtually gave them prior claim to the terminal facilities at the major capital city airports. Brisbane is about the only one where any capacity exists for a third or fourth airline to use the new terminal. We have the situation in Sydney where Ansett has blocked out the possibility of anyone else getting in.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a load of rubbish!

—The Government has blocked the possibility of anyone else getting in. Very belatedly, the Government-I want to emphasise this because the Minister obviously does not understand-intervened directly to tie up the terminals in defiance of the legislation which gave the FAC the power to do this and then presented the contracts to the FAC as a fait accompli.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation was belatedly amended to provide that new airlines should have some access to some of the terminals at the discretion of Australian Airlines and Ansett. Honourable senators can imagine what sort of accommodation those airlines will give. It certainly will not be on the basis of parity. Again, on the problem of the FAC, we see the way in which the Government has failed to cope with the huge costs to the Australian travelling public of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

The Fraser Government was prepared to act to resolve that eight years ago. We are now in the eighth year of office of this Government and we see procrastination after procrastination and huge fights within the Labor Party as to whether there will be a third runway. But nothing is being done to clear up the congestion in Sydney. The cost of congestion in Sydney is not 20 minutes time lost by the incoming traveller; it is the thousands of tonnes of fuel burnt needlessly each year and the thousands of air frame hours, air crew hours and maintenance hours.

I remember that in the early 1980s the estimate of the cost of congestion in Sydney was $25m or $28m. I have no idea what the cost would be today, but it may well be that a nought should be added to the previous figure. But the Government has done nothing and has no intention of doing anything to resolve those difficulties. Those difficulties, along with cleaning up the CAA and the FAC in order to make those bodies efficient, are some of the consequences of this legislation. Having made those points, on behalf of the Opposition, I wish this Bill quick passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: -Some people have been calling the Airlines Agreement (Termination) Bill 1990 the deregulator of the Australian airline industry. The fact is, however, that the industry will still be subject to significant regulation. State regulations will still apply to intrastate operations; Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines Ltd will retain long term leases over airport terminals; Qantas Airways Ltd will not be allowed to carry domestic passengers; foreign airlines will not be allowed to interline and there will still be limits on foreign investment.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation will, theoretically, allow the entry of new airlines to compete against Ansett and Australian Airlines. The Australian Democrats will be opposing this legislation in principle. We are doing so because we believe that the many benefits touted by proponents of deregulation will not eventuate due to the small size of the Australian market. We believe that it is a futile exercise which may-and I stress may-in the short term yield some gains but no long term benefits for the travelling public of Australia. We also believe that this has serious implications for the safety levels of the airline industry in this country and that the efficiencies we are seeking to achieve with this Bill can be obtained without such an open form of regulation. Ten years ago I, too, was attracted to the claims made for deregulation. It was easy to have a commitment to a theory, but we have now had enough time to see that, in practice, the theory does not always work.

Senator MacGibbon has given us an historical overview of how we have come to this piece of legislation, but he has not addressed the facts concerning what has happened in the United States, to which I now turn. Deregulation began there in 1978 with the only condition of entry being a fitness test on the general economic and community standard of the proposed entrant. The immediate effect of deregulation was the emergence of around 200 new operators. This led to significant drops in air fares over the major routes and a greater availability of discount fare packages.

Consequently, the United States is often held up as a shining example of the benefits of deregulating the airline industry. However, deregulation there has also led to severe congestion, causing flight delays at some airports, and to some substantial fare increases over the lighter routes. Importantly, it must be pointed out that the reduction in fares seen in the United States resulted, in the main, not from reduced inefficiencies but from the airlines negotiating more favourable wage deals with their employees.

In the longer term, the airlines maintained lower fares through delaying the replacement of their aircraft fleet-in many cases much longer than their designers intended. The ageing fleet evaluation program by the Boeing Commercial Aeroplane Co., completed in early 1989, found that more than 25 per cent of the Boeing 727 aircraft in use throughout the world were beyond the 20 flying years period for which they were designed; that 25 per cent represented more than 400 aircraft.

We are now seeing in the United States, as was predicted by industry economists when deregulation was first touted, a reconcentration of the industry. Ironically, the megacarriers that existed before deregulation are now, in the deregulated market, carrying a higher percentage of traffic. Ninety per cent of passenger traffic is now handled by just eight carriers, compared with 15 in 1984. Virtually all of the new entrants-over 140 companies-have either gone broke or have been taken over by the established megacarriers. The carrying patterns of the major operators have changed. The emergence of the hub and spoke networks has meant that major operators have become virtual monopolists in certain areas. So the concentration of the industry to the major players has actually increased with deregulation.

Furthermore, the barriers to entry to the United States market are now so great that there are unlikely to be any new entrants. Not surprisingly, this reconcentration in the industry and this monopoly power have been accompanied by increases in air fares, even on the trunk routes, and a decrease in the number of discount packages offered. These increases have been compounded by the need for airlines to finally purchase new aircraft after years of stretching out the use of old ones, as fare wars meant that there was underprovision for capital replacement and expansion.

In 1988 average United States air fares rose by 11 per cent and on some routes fares rose by as much as 33 per cent. Interestingly, there are now calls for some form of reregulation to be introduced to the industry in order to tighten entry controls, to relieve congestion and to allay fears of declining safety standards. So the United States' example shows that, while deregulation may bring short term benefits to the consumer in the form of lower fares, these benefits have not been sustainable and the customer may in the long run actually end up paying higher fares and having safety compromised.

I predict that the Australian experience will be that we can expect similar results on a smaller scale to occur here. Inevitably, there will be some new entrants-around 11 at the last count. But, given the dominance of the two existing airlines and the massive barriers to entry, new entrants will target their markets. We will not get competition across the board. Initially, the new arrangements will yield some cheaper air fares on major routes. However, contrary to Senator MacGibbon's beliefs, it is my contention that market forces will not be nearly as strong in Australia and that Australian companies will not be able to negotiate wage deals as favourable wage as those in the United States; thus fare reductions will not be as great. I do not believe it will be possible to sack maintenance, baggage and general staff and cabin crew, in the way Senator MacGibbon would like us to do, in the name of deregulation.

The new arrangements will also yield increased fares on lighter routes, for example, the Northern Territory, and a decrease in the quality of the services provided. For example, jet aircraft may be replaced by smaller propeller planes. The arrangements are also likely to worsen congestion problems which at Sydney Airport-as those of us who travel through there on our way home know-are absolutely woeful. Furthermore, the additional noise generated by a greater number and wider variety of aeroplanes must be closely monitored and controlled. Cheaper fares that do result will be sustained only long enough for existing operators to break or take over new entrants. Sir Peter Abeles has already said that he will kick the heads of competitors as they stick them up-this is, of course, the essence of true competition-and, with the backing of TNT Ltd and News Corporation Ltd, no doubt he will; and he will probably win.

Ansett and Australian already carry a significant number of passengers on discounted fares, and we have had some limited experience with competition in Australia with East-West Airlines Ltd. Between 1981 and 1986 East-West competed strongly with Australian Airlines and Ansett over various trunk routes offering a no-frills one-class service. In order to provide competition to the majors, East-West was reportedly losing over $1m per month and was inevitably taken over by Ansett.

In the deregulated environment, the Trade Practices Commission is to oversee the industry and supposedly prevent predatory pricing. However, the powers of the Trade Practices Commission are limited in this regard and they failed to prevent predatory pricing in the competition with East-West. The Trade Practices Commission's role in overseeing the newspaper and television industries is hardly a consoling example. In this regard I believe it is essential that adequate information be maintained and disseminated in regard to the economic performance of the industry.

The cycle of the United States will be repeated where large, existing operators are prepared to take significant revenue losses in the short term in order to cripple new entrants. Once they have, fare competition decreases and fares return to roughly pre-deregulation levels. Some may say, `Well at least we get cheap fares for a while'. However, it is not only fares that are affected by deregulation and this is where the Democrats have some real concerns.

Overseas experience has also shown that fierce competition has led to airlines short-cutting various procedures, in particular safety, in order to cut costs. In my first speech which I gave to the Senate last night, I mentioned the example of the American carrier, Eastern Airlines, which is currently facing 60 safety-related criminal charges including, incredibly, the faking of maintenance records. Reportedly, some United States airline companies have even calculated comparative costs of a hull loss versus the cost of compensation to the relatives of crash victims.

The safety standards of Australia's major airlines are presently second to none, and this is a tribute to the dedication of the pilots, engineers, maintenance and safety staff and cabin crew, and I commend the airlines for this. But in a deregulated environment the competitive forces may be such that some operators see potential gain in short-cutting procedures. I have been a passenger in a plane which sat on the tarmac for one and a half hours in St. Louis, in the United States of America, while those in charge decided whether to get a maintenance engineer out to look at a small problem. The crucial factor was that it was a Sunday and he was entitled to higher pay. Honourable senators will not be surprised to know, and I was not comforted by the thought, that they decided against seeking his advice.

The recent comments of the new head of the Civil Aviation Authority, Mr Dick Smith, to the effect that in the pursuit of affordable safety we can abolish over 200 existing safety regulations, do nothing to reassure me. It is true that the cosy duopoly referred to by Senator MacGibbon did have some problems but the Democrats feel it is a great pity that the Government did not choose either the revised regulation or even the partial regulation options of the Thomas May report of the Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation. The option chosen by the Government and supported by the Opposition will not, I believe, turn out to be in the best interests of future Australian travelling public.

If deregulation is to go ahead in the form proposed-as it obviously will with both the Government and the Opposition supporting it-I urge the Government to consider placing a freeze on our current safety regulations at least until the inevitable frenzy of a newly deregulated environment subsides. The safety of our travelling public must be guaranteed, and I ask the Minister in his speech to clearly enunciate what measures and financial resources the Government will be taking to ensure passengers' safety.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate. Senator MacGibbon has made it very easy for me to assist him in his desire to give this Bill speedy passage through the House by making 90 per cent of his speech completely irrelevant to the Bill; so there is nothing to respond to. So far as Senator Kernot's contribution is concerned, I am aware of the arguments canvassed by her and in fact agree with some of the things that she said. But the two issues I want to take up principally in respect of her contribution were the question of safety, which is an important public issue that must be addressed during this debate, and the reality of the Australian aviation market.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of safety Australia has-and it is well known-one of the strictest and most closely regulated aviation safety regimes in the world. That regime remains in place. It will be completely unaffected by the deregulation of the airline industry on 31 October this year. The two issues in respect of the Australian aviation industry are simply not connected in that sense. The safety regulations that the Civil Aviation Authority implements apply to a great many airlines currently.

Comparisons with the United States-I have made this statement before not just in relation to the aviation industry but to a whole lot of other things in terms of public affairs in Australia-are fraught with danger.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you doing it with Telecom?

—That also applies to Telecom. The comparisons are not valid because of the substantial differences in the market. It is simply not valid to compare the situation of the United States aviation sector with Australia's.
—Tell Mr Beazley.

—Mr Beazley is well aware of that, and that is why it is important-and I have said this many times during this public debate-not to make the extravagant and overstated claims as some have about the likely beneficial impacts of deregulation in the Australian market. That is why I said that I do partially agree with some of the things Senator Kernot said. We have a country the size of the United States with a population the size of the city of Los Angeles.

SPEECH.PARA: We have an aviation market in Australia which is tiny compared with the aviation market of the United States. Just one American airline-the major airline in the United States-has got 20 times more aircraft than the entire combined fleet of all airlines in Australia flying over the same distances. I raise this because in particular comparisons with air fares between Australia and the United States, so often made by our political opponents with Senator MacGibbon among them, are almost entirely not valid for the same reasons.

We are talking about a high quality service in Australia with one of the most modern airline fleets in the world, in terms of the age of the aircraft, servicing a great many ports with what is, by international standards, a very low volume of traffic. It is very easy from where I come from to run an argument and get lots of public support for it that the air fares from Darwin to Sydney or Canberra are, in comparison with the air fares from New York to San Francisco, very high. That is not a valid comparison because it is a different market with different commercial realities applying to it. There was a prospect raised by some that when the airline industry is deregulated on 31 October there will be a flood of applicants all falling over each other to get into the industry and compete with the majors that currently are in the industry.

I found it interesting as the responsible Minister, when the question was raised of deregulation and new entrants, that one of the first things that were asked of me in the very first interview I gave on the subject was: `Is the Government going to provide substantial financial assistance to the new entrants to provide an even playing field for them to compete with two airlines that have had a government guaranteed monopoly for 40 years?', which simply indicates the mindset that a lot of people in this country have about the role that governments should or should not play in this kind of enterprise. The answer to the question was: `No, we are not going to'.

What I said yesterday in a debate on telecommunications applies in this debate: there are two very important sectors of public activity in Australia, that is, the areas of both transport and communication, where for a very long time to come a natural monopoly applies. That remains in the airline industry. It is a very expensive industry to get into. The overheads are horrific in respect of the general aviation area, that is, charters and commuter traffic. The only reason that one would want to be an executive in that particular industry is if one loved flying very much indeed. One has to be pretty committed. It is a tough industry in which to succeed.

I have read everything that Senator MacGibbon has said in the Parliament on the two-airline agreement. He is perfectly correct in saying what he did about his contribution to the debate in 1981, but the two-airline agreement did serve the country very well for quite a long time. A myth has been created that today the two-airline agreement is still performing a useful social service, as was referred to by the Australian Democrats. The facts simply do not support that contention any longer. They did once. There is a myth that Australian Airlines, because of its government ownership, provides a useful social service in, for example, servicing ports which perhaps there is not a clear commercial reason to service. That is nonsense.

Currently Australian Airlines services 25 per cent of the ports that were serviced in the mid-1970s. For the last 20 years Australian Airlines has been taking decisions in terms of its operations that are entirely commercial, thank goodness. That is one of the reasons for the current very successful operation of Australian Airlines. I might say that Senator MacGibbon's claim that the sale of Australian Airlines is automatically predicated on the passage of this legislation and the new regime that operates after 31 October is nonsense. If the Government were minded to provide 100 per cent of the additional equity that is required by Australian Airlines, which the Government is not minded to do, Australian could continue to operate aggressively and successfully, as it is now operating against Ansett. There is no question but that the time has now arrived for that agreement to be concluded.

I am pleased to say, coming from the Northern Territory, that I was a member of the Government when it took the decision to give the necessary three years notice to terminate the agreement. The time has now arrived for the agreement to be concluded and for other entrants to be allowed the opportunity to participate.

I have received some criticism from some of these new entrants because I dared to discuss publicly the very things I am discussing now-that is, the reality of the Australian aviation industry and the very strong likelihood that there was not going to be an avalanche of new operators rushing to the gates to get into the airline business because of the cost of getting into it and the reality of the Australian market.

Some of those new operators took some considerable exception to the remarks that I made about the potential result of deregulation on the two major airlines. Senator Kernot quoted Sir Peter Abeles, apparently in some sort of criticism that he made this extraordinary statement that he was going to kick the head in of any competitor who tried to compete with Ansett. That is not a very extraordinary statement to make. I expect that he will, and so will Australian Airlines.

As I said publicly, it is going to be a very silly new entrant in the airline business in Australia who comes into it thinking that the two majors are simply going to continue to operate the way they are currently operating. They will be very much mistaken if they do. That is the purpose of this particular exercise-to change the nature of the Australian aviation industry to provide now for that additional competition, to sharpen up the activities of the two existing operators, and to remove that comfortable duopoly which Senator Kernot seriously wants to maintain. I am not sure why she has such a passionate enthusiasm for supporting Ansett. Nevertheless, the Government is not of a mind to continue to support the duopoly and we are going to allow some new entrants to come in.

I want to explain why the Government decided to opt for the decision it made to terminate the agreement and not simply to provide for a three-airline policy, which is what East-West Airlines wanted. Do not let anybody think that Mr Grey from East-West Airlines was interested in deregulating the airline industry when East-West started up in its operations against Ansett in Australia: it wanted a three-airline policy. We could have opted for that course, but it is the view of the Government-and frankly I think that that view is being sustained right now, even though it is only early days-that the regulator that is provided naturally by the Australian aviation market will be sufficient to provide for whatever regulation is required after 31 October.

There was some criticism that the arrangements that were made in terms of gate access, which is very important for new entrants, were not going to be sufficient. Today Senator MacGibbon delivered another piece of nonsense consistent with the trail of nonsense that he has delivered in aviation debates ever since I have been here. He said that these were outrageous arrangements. He painted a picture of all these new entrants waiting at the doors unable to get a gate. The reality is that that is rubbish. Currently, rather than the 11 new starters that Senator Kernot mentioned, as I speak the only new entrant on the blocks-not yet ready to fly but in a position where it certainly will be flying-is Compass Airlines. So far the only new entrant which is even in the process of negotiating for gate access at the airports is Compass Airlines-one entrant. If Senator MacGibbon has information about airlines that are currently unable to get gate access and are ready to start flying and using the gates-they are expensive facilities and Senator MacGibbon would be the last person to agree that they should not be used-I would like to hear from him which companies they are. I know that the response to that invitation will be a resounding silence.

So far as safety is concerned, there is also a myth, perpetuated and pushed to extremes all through the dispute by Senator MacGibbon's good friends, the executives of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, that deregulation in the United States has led to a drastic reduction in safety standards. The facts indicate precisely the reverse.

Honourable senators will be amazed to hear that safety was a matter of some concern in the United States of America and that American air travellers are just as concerned about their safety as Australian air travellers are concerned about ours. As a result of this concern, the President of the United States commissioned a major investigation into the effects of deregulation on air safety and a presidential report that was commissioned, and which I have read, indicates that, in the 10 years after deregulation in the United States, safety standards have improved compared with those in the 10 years prior to deregulation.

I hasten to add that the report was also careful to point out-and I make the point here-that that was not necessarily due to the magic of deregulation. There is no magic attached to deregulation. It could well have been due to a whole range of other factors which the report listed. But the argument that deregulation in the United States has led to a massive decrease in safety, and an increase in accidents, deaths, fatalities and injuries, is simply nonsense.

Senator Kernot mentioned a major airline operator in the United States who is facing a number of charges for the extraordinary crime of faking maintenance reports. There is nothing extraordinary about it; it is certainly heinous and deserving of the maximum penalties, but I regret to advise the honourable senator that it has occurred in Australia under the existing system. One operator in the Northern Territory was guilty of faking maintenance records by having a drawer full--

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about a domestic airline which will carry thousands--

—In respect of safety, it is irrelevant whether one is a passenger on an interstate or intrastate aircraft if one goes nose first into the ground from 10,000 feet and gets smeared all over the landscape. The safety regime in Australia applies equally across all air operations. It does not just apply to the majors. The Civil Aviation Authority and the Australian Bureau of Air Safety Investigation are responsible for regulating and investigating accidents in all aviation sectors in Australia, both interstate and intrastate.

SPEECH.PARA: Matters such as faking maintenance records are entirely relevant to the question of aviation safety. Things like that occur. The important thing is that they be discovered and the people responsible be prosecuted. That is exactly what happens in Australia. There is no reason whatever to draw a conclusion that the entry of additional operators into the market in Australia will lead of itself to a diminution of the current regime of safety. It will not. The reality of the Australian market will dictate that there will not be a flood of new entrants flying port to port over Australia.

Senator Kernot also raised as a criticism the fact that there is likely to be limited competition from the new entrants on certain routes in Australia. She said that they are not going to compete across the board. Of course they will not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you doing it, then?

—In response to the honourable senator's interjection, I will tell her why we are deregulating it. As regrettable as I might find it, a very large number of our citizens choose to live in Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, Coolangatta and Brisbane, and a very substantial number of Australians will benefit from deregulation after 31 October. In respect of the honourable senator's concerns for the Northern Territory-and I appreciate them-I assure her, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that I keep a very close eye on the loadings of aircraft in and out of the Northern Territory. I am in constant consultation, and I was before becoming the Minister, because of the concerns I have for the Northern Territory's interests and the kinds of loadings in the Northern Territory. They are holding up very well indeed, and as a result we are still getting very frequent flights of aircraft such as Boeing 767s into the Northern Territory, because the bums are there to fill the seats. At the end of day, that is what counts. Places such as Alice Springs, in particular, have nothing to fear from deregulation and its effects on the amount of traffic going through their airports. In fact, they have the prospect of everything to gain.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said again yesterday, there will be a shake-out in the industry; there is no question about that. What is detrimental to one interest will end up being beneficial to another. Yesterday Senator MacGibbon raised the question of Mount Isa in another classic piece of nonsense. He said that the port of Mount Isa is no longer serviced by major airlines because of the airline pilots dispute. He never addressed himself to the question of why they have not gone back there since the dispute was resolved.

As a result of that debate yesterday, someone spoke to me about recently travelling out of Mount Isa in an 18-seater commuter aircraft. That is exactly what will happen in some places. If jet aircraft do not service them because of the short distances involved and the low number of passengers carried, regional airlines will pick up the benefit and provide that service if the demand is there.

Having made those points, I stress again that on the question of air safety in relation to deregulation the Government has given very clear statements which will be implemented and which say that there will be no-I repeat, no-reduction in the standards of air safety applied in Australia after deregulation. As Senator MacGibbon has said in his contribution to this debate, the reason why this legislation deserves the support of the Parliament is that, despite the fact that the two-airline agreement did serve Australia well for a very long time, the time has now come for a new regime to be implemented to provide for additional competition. However, having said that, I stress that it is ridiculous in the same argument to overstate the case by suggesting that there will be massive decreases in air fares and avalanches of new operators waiting at the gates to get into the industry. There will not be. I believe that in the nature of Australia's aviation industry there will be a gradual change which will be to the overall aggregate benefit of a majority of Australians who fly. For that reason, I hope that the Senate supports this legislation.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and join Senator MacGibbon in hoping that it has a speedy passage through the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, under standing order 191, I seek leave to make a statement relating to explanation of speeches.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

—Mr Acting Deputy President--
—Order! I accept the Minister's point of order. Senator MacGibbon, if you believe you have been misinterpreted, make your point and we will continue the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: A Senator who has spoken to a question may again be heard, to explain some material part of the Senators's speech which has been misquoted or misunderstood, but shall not introduce any new matter, or interrupt any Senator speaking, and no debatable matter shall be brought forward or debate arise on such an explanation.
