TALK.START.PARA: —It falls to my lot to speak to the Australian National Maritime Museum Bill on behalf of the Opposition as during the period it was under shadow Cabinet consideration and party room consideration I was acting shadow Minister on behalf of my colleague Senator Michael Baume.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill provides for the establishment of the Australian National Maritime Museum at Darling Harbour in Sydney. More particularly, it outlines the functions and powers of the museum and provides for the establishment of the Museum Council to replace the Interim Council.

At first glance, the legislation itself certainly appears to be non-controversial. That is certainly not the case with regard to the issue of the establishment of the museum itself. Indeed, for some considerable time it has been fraught with controversy and disagreement between the present New South Wales Government and the Hawke Labor Government.

Certainly, while one could not question the establishment of such a museum and the benefits which will be derived by the Australian community through the establishment and bona fides of such a project, one can question very seriously the way in which the establishment of this museum has been handled by the present Federal Government and the previous New South Wales Labor Government. There is no doubt that as it has been established, in terms of its location and its development, it has been very much a creature of politics. Its initial establishment and announcement was an election ploy and, from the outset, this project has been manipulated to further political ends.

The decision to establish the museum at Darling Harbour was linked very closely to the political requirements of the New South Wales Wran Labor Government and in particular with its toy, the Darling Harbour development. In fact, the Director of the National Museum of Australia, Dr McMichael, commented to the effect that the initial announcement of this museum was a nice thing to say but not a decision that was made carefully.

It is because this initial decision was not made carefully that it has been fraught with controversy ever since that announcement. At the time that Neville Wran went to a State election in March 1984, Prime Minister Hawke promised him $30m to establish a maritime museum. However, this promised provision of $30m was nothing more than a guesstimate in terms of what the museum would actually cost. As I have said, it was announced at that time purely as an election ploy in support of the then Labor Government in New South Wales to assist with its re-election.

The memorandum of understanding that was agreed to between that State Labor Government and the present Federal Labor Government stated that all costs in excess of the original figure of $30m would be met by the New South Wales State Government. In effect, the then Premier, Neville Wran, and the responsible State Minister, Laurie Brereton, now a member in the other place in this Federal Parliament, effectively signed an open cheque with the Federal Government with regard to this project.

Of course, that was part of the overall mismanagement of the Darling Harbour project that was very much a feature of Laurie Brereton's administration as a Minister at that time. He was very keen on fast-tracking the development of this project and, of course, as part of that fast-tracking concept, the fast-tracking of the establishment of this museum was included.

The $30m that was agreed to be contributed by the then Federal Government was based very much on indicative plans. There was no detailed architectural plan, no detailed concept developed at the time at which the New South Wales Government agreed to accept an offer of $30m from the Commonwealth Government as sufficient to cover the cost of this project. Also, the $30m related only to the cost of the building itself. One can question the competence of people who entered into such an agreement and completely ignored the fact that, of course, further money would be necessary to establish the museum itself once the building was constructed. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest. There being no-one wishing to speak, the sitting is suspended until 2 p.m.

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, both in his personal capacity and as Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the recent collapse of the Pyramid Building Society with the consequent freezing of the savings of some 220,000 investors and the bail out operation by the taxpayers of Victoria. I also refer the Minister to the joint press statement issued by the Victorian Treasurer and the Attorney-General, on 13 February 1990, stating that deposits in the Pyramid Building Society were secure. I ask the Minister: Was he or the Government aware of the financial difficulties of Pyramid prior to 13 February, and was he aware in advance that this press statement was to be issued?
—Now we are on television, it is very difficult to answer the question in the way in which I intend, but the answer to both parts is no.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health whether he is aware of concerns expressed about the use of the Medicare card in proposals to reform the administration of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS). What is the Minister's response to these concerns?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health is, of course, very aware of concerns that have been raised on privacy grounds with the proposal to use the Medicare card to establish eligibility for pharmaceutical benefits scheme purposes. The measures announced in the Budget include very significant savings in government expenditure through administrative reform of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I wish to table a letter from the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, Mr Peter Staples, to the Privacy Commissioner which details the Government's intentions.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the PBS, pharmacists are paid by the Health Insurance Commission to recompense them for the difference between the cost of drugs and the amount patients have to pay for them. A pharmacist is entitled to a higher payment from the Commission for a prescription dispensed to a pensioner than for a prescription dispensed to a general user, and the Government believes no subsidy at all should be paid for non-residents of Australia such as foreign tourists.

To run a tight system, it is necessary that the Commission be able to accurately verify the amount a pharmacist claims, and that will depend on what drug has been dispensed and in what quantities, and the status under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme of patients-whether they are residents of Australia, whether they are entitled to a concessional benefit or not.

When patients present at a pharmacist claiming to be entitled to a subsidy that they are not entitled to, who then should bear the cost-the patient who is not entitled, the pharmacist, or the public? The Government believes the public should not have to. So, if the pharmacist is not going to be made to bear the cost, the pharmacist needs a secure method of satisfying himself or herself of eligibility.
It is in that context that the Government has proposed a system which will be entirely voluntary for pharmacists. No pharmacist will be required to use the Medicare card system.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do they get paid? If you don't use the system, you don't get paid.
—However, any pharmacist who does use the system will be protected. They will be paid by the Commission whatever subsidy the Commission tells the pharmacist they are entitled to.

ANSWER.PARA: In February, the Privacy Commissioner raised essentially two concerns with such a system: first, the flow of information from the Department of Social Security (DSS), which determines whether people are entitled to concessional pharmaceuticals, to the Commission and from the Commission to the pharmacist; and, second, the risk of embarrassment to patients when they claim a subsidy in the pharmacy, perhaps in the company of other customers, and are advised that it is not available. The Government has proposed to deal with those two concerns by legislation, to be introduced this sitting, which would, first, strictly define that the only information the DSS can provide to the Commission for these purposes is identity information and the status of the person under the PBS-DSS will not be permitted to provide any income or other information to the Commission; second, strictly define the information the Commission can provide to a pharmacist as being the PBS status of a patient inquired about; third, strictly regulate the use of Medicare identifier information by pharmacists and doctors and their staff; and, fourth, provide for the Privacy Commissioner to issue binding guidelines on the use of Medicare identifiers within pharmacies or doctors' surgeries following consultation with the relevant professional bodies. In practice, whenever a pharmacist knows his or her customer and is confident the customer is honest, there will be no need to use the system-and I think that answers Senator Boswell's primary concern-with the normal relationship between a longstanding customer and the pharmacist.

I think I have put the concerns that people have expressed in the proper context, and I believe my general answer yesterday still holds true-that, in trying to balance protection of the revenue with privacy considerations, quite clearly, the role of the Privacy Commissioner is going to be vital in determining the correct balance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, despite the fact that the Minister is on television, I noted that he studiously read word for word from a document, and I therefore ask him to table it.
—Whether the Minister tables the document or not is a matter for the Minister.

—I will table it, but I think that, for the benefit of viewers, it should be pointed out that I represent a Minister in another place and I am therefore taking the very prudent course of reading the brief provided to me.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to Senator Gareth Evans's statement in debate in the Senate on Tuesday that he believed a United Nations endorsement for military enforcement of sanctions against Iraq to be necessary and, in fact, to his understanding that the UN Security Council debate was then in progress. Regrettably, I now note the failure of the United Nations Security Council to resolve to enforce the sanctions or, I think, even to formally meet on the issue. I ask, firstly: How does the Government interpret this failure? Does it indicate a lessening of international resolve? What does the Government understand to be the obstacles being experienced in negotiations? Secondly, how will a failure by the international community to give UN sanction to the Gulf force affect Australia's role, particularly in light of President Bush's clear indications that he is running out of patience?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia would view with substantial disappointment any indecision from the United Nations, but I think in other public statements made by me, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade it has been indicated that the past history of the United Nations has not always been exemplary in trying to act with haste on these matters.

ANSWER.PARA: Whilst there is a general resolve in the United Nations to carry, I think, four separate items relating to condemning Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, imposing mandatory economic sanctions, going on to declare Iraq's annexation of Kuwait null and void and, finally, demanding that Iraq permit the facilitation of the immediate departure of foreign nationals, the Security Council has yet to grapple with what we all regard as the major issue: what good are economic sanctions without some enforcement? That is precisely the leadership that the United States has shown in this issue, and many other countries have responded. It is clearly the priority and the choice of the Australian Government to have UN sanction of that sort of interdiction. However, if it does not occur, we still believe that under international law the Americans are acting properly and we would continue to support their actions. The second part of the question--

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you know what the obstacles are?

—Thank you for reminding me of that, Senator. The obstacles are a fear of threat of veto by one of the nations involved that is showing disquiet. The reasons for that disquiet could be not even related to this particular issue, but a bargaining chip somewhere else. The matter, when it was deferred by the Security Council, hinged on Yemen's agreement to deferring an Iraqi ship from visiting its ports and, if you like, put the issue off. If there is anything further I can gather on the subject, I will let the honourable senator know. We would still hope, however, that the Security Council would tackle this issue, but, as it has only really shown its resolve to tackle an issue of this consequence once before in its 40 years, one cannot rely on it to do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. Is it a fact that Australia is still not self-sufficient in petroleum products, leaving us sensitive to international oil industry developments? If this is a fact, can the Minister advise honourable senators what plans the Government has to stimulate oil exploration in Australian territory, particularly in the light of the implications of such emergencies as Iraq's attack on Kuwait?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is equivalent to about 90 per cent self-sufficient in crude oil at the present time. However, the problem is that Bass Strait reserves are running down at a rapid rate and, despite the fact that the Timor Sea and North West Shelf recent finds are replacing that depletion, we will be facing about 35 per cent self-sufficiency by the year 2000. That is a reasonably bleak scenario. That will happen if there are no other finds of oil, and that is the important consideration. Of course, that has major implications for our security. It also has major implications for our current account deficit.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a lot of ill-informed talk about oil, and I just want to say this: there is really no need, if one is an Australian, to panic about the decline in self-sufficiency because Australia is a net exporter of energy. We are the world's leading exporter of coal; we are a major exporter of liquefied natural gas; we export uranium; and we export solar collectors of the renew- able energy sort. Our trade account balance in energy is in surplus and is expected to remain that way through to the end of this century.

What the Government has done in the Budget is to recognise what a prudent government should always do, that is, look at ways in which there could be some stimulation of exploration in Australia. There are three determinants of the amount of exploration activity that goes on. One is the price of a barrel of oil. We all know that has been low until recently, so there has not been a price fall to stimulate exploration. Another is the prospectivity of the land to be explored. Australia is a lightly explored country. In 1867 the United States of America had drilled 5,500 exploration wells. Until 1990 Australia had drilled the same number of wells. That gives an indication of how lightly explored we, as a country, are. The other determinant is cost, of which tax is a subset.

In the Budget on Tuesday night the Treasurer announced that there would be tax deductions for the removal of offshore oil platforms-a major concern for the Bass Strait producers in particular; that from 1 July there would be deduction across the company for costs against the resource rental tax payments for exploration; and that from 1 July resource rental tax would be introduced into Bass Strait. That would mean that Australia would forgo revenue of over $700m this year and next year, although in 1992-93 it would return a revenue positive result. We believe these steps will stimulate considerable new exploration in frontier areas that need to be explored.

I conclude my answer by saying that that is not just the Government's view-it is the industry view. Peter Willcox, who is the Chief Executive Officer of BHP Petroleum, in a press release on Tuesday referring to the Treasurer's statement, said:
BHP believed that this would result in higher levels of exploration . . . BHP agreed with the principle of applying an RRT in Bass Strait . . .
Speaking for his company, he said:
We believe this change will make a number of new oil developments in Bass Strait economic.

Most importantly, Keith Orchison, who is the Chief Executive Officer of the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association, a group that until now has been a trenchant critic of Australian government policy on tax as stimulant for oil production, told Alan Griffiths, the Minister for Resources, in a telephone call-and then said approvingly, `Yes, of course, you can quote me wherever you go'-that his view of the Budget measures was: `At the end of this century when we look back on last night's Budget it will be seen as the most decisive moment in promoting oil exploration in Australia'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of a parliamentary delegation from the Polish Sem led by the Deputy Marshall, Mrs Teresa Dobielinska-Eliszewska. On behalf of honourable senators, I welcome you to the Senate. I trust that your visit to Australia will be informative and enjoyable.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I preface my question by emphasising that I am asking Senator Button this question in his capacity as the Prime Minister's representative in the Senate. Firstly, does the Government believe that the protection of Australians in Kuwait and Iraq will be jeopardised by a military attack by Arab or United States (US) forces on one or both of those countries? If not, why not? Secondly, if war does break out, what changes will the Government make to the role and operating locations of Australian warships now en route to the Gulf of Oman? Thirdly, does the Government agree that a first strike on Kuwait and, possibly, Iraq would violate President Bush's assurance that US forces in Saudi Arabia are only fulfilling defensive roles? Finally, if so, was the Prime Minister misled on this critical point by President Bush in their phone conversation on Friday, 10 August?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time yesterday Senator Powell asked me a question about some of these issues which invited me to speculate on the views of a number of commentators, particularly in the United States, which she cited in her question. Today, again, each of her questions invites me to speculate on the possibility of an attack by the United States on Kuwait or Iraq and to speculate further on reactions by Iraq to such an eventuality.

ANSWER.PARA: I made it clear yesterday that I did not think that was a particularly productive exercise. I further made it clear that I thought it was not very wise to indulge in speculation on this matter. The situation in the Middle East is, as the Government has made clear on many occasions, a very tense and difficult one. To speculate about military escalation and, in particular, to say anything that might run any risk of increasing the danger for our nationals now in Iraq or Kuwait would, in my view, be irresponsible.

So far as the part of the question that relates to a repositioning of the role of the Australian defence presence in the region is concerned, that is a matter which Senator Ray dealt with yesterday and I have nothing to add to what he said.

The only comment I am prepared to make is that our hope and the aim of the policy-including in the interests of Australian nationals caught up in the situation-is, of course, for a peaceful solution. Australia's posture of supporting the sanctions by assisting in a multilateral effort to make them effective, accepting the need for the United States and others to deter further Iraqi aggression and playing whatever role we can in diplomatic efforts is all directed towards that goal of a peaceful settlement of the situation in the Middle East. I cannot see that public speculation about an escalation of that situation into open conflict could do other than work in exactly the opposite direction, which, I am sure, Senator Powell is concerned about. The proposition that the Prime Minister has been misled by President Bush is, as far as the Government is concerned, nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In light of the Minister's comments about any speculation jeopardising the safety of Australian and other foreign nationals in the area, does the Minister believe that an answer to the question I asked yesterday-in other words, a commitment from this Government against a first strike-would enhance the prospects of a safe exit from that area by Australian and other foreign nationals?
—That is a matter about which judgments have to be made by people in a much better position than I am to make those judgments, and I do not wish to speculate on that either.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. What extra international airlines are planning to use Adelaide Airport's international terminal in the next few months? After the inception of any new flights, how many international airlines in total will be operating through Adelaide Airport? Finally, which international airlines will have traffic rights into Adelaide after that time but will not actually be using them?

—I am pleased to advise the honourable senator that two international airlines-Malaysia Airlines and Thai Airways International-propose to commence operations into Adelaide very shortly. Malaysia Airlines intends to commence its services in November this year and Thai Airways International in January next. That will bring the total count of international companies operating into Adelaide Airport to seven. After the inception of these new services there will be a number of international airlines which have rights into Adelaide that they are not using-I might add that this is a common situation around Australia-and those in respect of Adelaide Airport will be American Airlines, All Nippon Airways, Canadian Airlines International, Continental Airlines Inc, Federal Express, Hawaiian Airlines, UTA French Airlines, United Airlines and Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd after 1 April next year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I refer to the Minister's answer given to Senator Boswell yesterday, concerning the massive extension of the tax file numbering system in the Budget, in which the Minister advised that assurances had been given by Ministers that it is their intention that Mr Kevin O'Connor, the Privacy Commissioner, be involved in the monitoring the way in which these provisions work. I ask whether the Minister is aware of Privacy Commissioner Kevin O'Connor's remarks in this morning's media, where he said:

QUESTION.PARA: I'm most concerned that pensioners are being caught up in the operation of the tax file number for purposes that are not in any way connected with tax. It is now a misnomer to call it a tax number.

Assuming that the Privacy Commissioner's concerns have some foundation, would the Minister agree that plans to extend the tax file number to all social security beneficiaries is already under serious threat? Is this a Clayton's Australia Card?

TALK.START.PARA: —It might suit the convenience of the Senate-I am not at all trying to avoid the question-if Senator Richardson, whose responsibility is social security, were to give a full answer to Senator Campbell. In so far as privacy matters are concerned, I have a fax here from the Privacy Commissioner, Kevin O'Connor. I would certainly table it but it may suit the convenience of the Senate if Senator Richardson were to answer the question and perhaps read the fax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the Privacy Commissioner's concerns. In fact, during the course of the Government's discussions about a month ago on what would be in this year's Budget I had a meeting with the Privacy Commissioner. Because we were aware that there would be privacy concerns which would result from any extension of the use of tax file numbers, he was consulted early. Unfortunately, there has been some misquoting of the Privacy Commissioner. In fact, while I was in Sydney this morning a fax arrived in my office. It is very short and I propose to read it:

ANSWER.PARA: Clearly, the extension of the TFN system raises significant privacy concerns.

As I have acknowledged consistently, it is up to the Government and Parliament to decide what is appropriate by way of-(1) use of numbering systems for specific administrative purposes; and (2) the need to implement effective systems for control of waste and overpayments.
I have not indicated at any time that there is any breach of the law involved in these proposals.
As I have indicated consistently, if these extensions occur and datamatching programs are increased, I will seek to ensure that strict privacy safeguards are applied.

The Privacy Commissioner made his concerns-they are very proper concerns-clear to me some time back. Ever since that moment, the Government has been keen to act in accordance with his wishes. He will be circulating a discussion paper which will go into the kinds of guidelines that the Government should observe in the extension of this system. We will be very happy to implement guidelines proposed to us by the Privacy Commissioner once he has been able to undertake those consultations.

Furthermore, we have provided resources to him to make sure that he and his staff can monitor whatever my Department does in this respect to ensure that people do not have to worry about their private affairs being exposed.

There will be no linkages between departments. The important thing to note here is that magnetic tapes will be carried between departments and information on them matched. Information will be destroyed every three months. There will be no central data bank. I might say that personally I would not have a bar of one, anyway.

Innocent people have nothing whatsoever to fear. The Privacy Commissioner will be peering over our shoulder every second to ensure that, as he should do. We have made sure that extra resources are provided to him for exactly that purpose. Those senators opposite will not need to worry about it; neither will any Australian. The only people who need to worry are those who are ripping off the system.

One does not come up with a figure of $400m a year for the next few years that one can get from cheats, unless one is confident that this new kind of technology, this high-speed computer matching, will catch many people who have ripped off the system. We will catch those people who might be receiving an unemployment benefit and are declaring other incomes. We will catch those people who are claiming somebody as a dependent spouse even though they are getting a sole parent's pension. A whole range of people who are rorting the system can now be caught by the use of new technology. From the very first second of its implementation, privacy has been uppermost in our mind. Privacy concerns will not be ignored.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations: Do the figures recently released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) concerning labour costs in 1988-89 show that the proportion of employees covered by superannuation has risen considerably in the past three years? Given that a key objective of the Government is to extend superannuation cover to all, who are the beneficiaries of this policy? What are the implications of the ABS survey?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 August the ABS published a survey on major labour costs. It showed a number of interesting features, one of which, by way of an aside, is that the cost of workers compensation in Australia as a component of overall labour costs has declined, indicating that at least in the area of compensation greater efficiency has been achieved.

ANSWER.PARA: Given that in 1985 the percentage of the work force covered by superannuation was about 40 per cent, it showed an increase in 1988-89 to 54.6 per cent of the Australian work force now having some form of superannuation cover. It indicated that 80 per cent of workers covered by awards of either the State or the Federal Commission are now entitled, as a consequence of the national wage case decision in December 1986, to superannuation.

That indicates an immense and significant social change for Australia. It is one that the Government has supported on social justice and equity grounds. It is one that we have supported on the basis of encouraging people to make proper provision for their retirement so that in their old age they can enjoy a higher standard of living than they might have otherwise anticipated.

Of course it is proper for a government to do that on the basis that we recognise that the greying-that is, the ageing-of the Australian population will impose on future governments significant retirement costs.

However, one of the elements of the survey indicates that while 80 per cent of workers covered by awards have access to superannuation, only 75 per cent of those with award coverage are receiving superannuation. That indicates a high level of non-compliance. When that level of non-compliance is disaggregated, we find that there is very high to almost perfect compliance in extending superannuation provision in the public sector. But in the private sector there is less than full observance of the award entitlement by private sector employers.

This raises an important question. Superannuation, where it appears in the award as a prescribed right, is a legal obligation on employers. It is an offence not to provide it. Where it is not being provided, those employers can be prosecuted and the workers obtain a payment to a recognised superannuation fund. The employer can then be fined for not complying with his legal requirement.

As a consequence of observing this indication in the statistics, the Commonwealth Government is now forming a national strategy to encourage compliance with the law. Any individual who finds in his particular case that the law has not been complied with is free to prosecute to obtain compliance, and should do so.
Opposition senators-Come on!

TALK.START.PARA: —It may not be of any interest to honourable senators opposite that people are being duped out of their legitimate legal entitlements; but it is a concern to a government with a social conscience which wants to see that employees receive their due entitlement.

ANSWER.PARA: I conclude by saying that it is my very firm advice to employers who are in any doubt about their legal obligations to contact either my Department or the Confederation of Australian Industry-indeed, join it and receive its industry service. Otherwise they will be liable to prosecution and, having now been warned, they will have no further excuse.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health to a letter going out to all pharmacists from the Manager of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Branch concerning Health Insurance Commission initiatives announced in the Budget. In part, the letter states:

QUESTION.PARA: To enable pharmacists to confirm the eligibility of patients to general or concessional entitlement, the Commission will move to an interactive processing environment whereby pharmacists can be connected on-line to the Commission's computer system.

I ask the Minister: Will this mean that every time elderly pensioners, war veterans or the average family with a safety net card go to their pharmacy to get their pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) medication, they will first have to wait for their identification details to be checked via computer against other government records before the pharmacist is authorised to dispense their prescription? Is this not the same system that was canned by the previous Minister, Dr Blewett, just prior to the Federal election because of the concerns held by the Privacy Commissioner, Mr Kevin O'Connor, and because of protests from the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and the Australian Medical Association that the Government was trying to introduce an identity or Australia card by stealth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the capacity of a pharmacist to use the system of checking on the identity of a person by use of the Medicare card is, as I said previously, purely voluntary. A pharmacist will not have to adopt that process at all when an old age pensioner, a veteran or an ordinary member of a family in the district with whom he has a good relationship and knows well comes into his pharmacy. The pharmacist will know the person and know that he is entitled to the PBS benefit. Therefore, the pharmacist will not be taking any risk in dispensing the prescription with the expectation of payment under the PBS at the level to which that customer of the pharmacy is entitled.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no need to fear a growing queue of the elderly, the infirm, veterans or ordinary family persons approaching a pharmacist. I am sure this matter is one where commonsense will prevail. As Senator Boswell has indicated, the local pharmacist will know his customers very well and will be able to process their prescriptions without any need to use this system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Since the general eligibility of people receiving PBS benefits is to be brought into line with Medicare requirements which restrict entitlements to Australian residents, will the Minister clarify whether that means that every person, whether receiving some government benefit or not, will have to be checked against Canberra computer records before being allowed to purchase a script, even those who pay the maximum patient contribution of $15? The scheme includes every single Australian man, woman and child, does it not?

—I think that I allayed the fears of most people by my previous answer. Senator Boswell has really only dressed up his previous question in new rhetoric. I believe that my previous answer is sufficient.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate of the presence of the Hon. F. M. Mulikita, Speaker of the National Assembly of the Republic of Zambia, and on behalf of the Senate I extend to him a warm welcome to Australia and to the Senate. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite Speaker Mulikita to take a seat on the floor of the chamber.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Speaker Mulikita thereupon entered the chamber, and was seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware that there are now at least 130,000 displaced persons inside Cambodia, displaced from their homes by the increased military activity of the Khmer Rouge? It is clear that unless significant humanitarian aid is provided, a major human catastrophe is inevitable. Irrespective of the diplomatic difficulties, will the Australian Government make a significant humanitarian aid contribution to assist these people? Further, will Australia ask other governments to make humanitarian aid available to people in these displacement camps? Will the Australian Government condemn the Khmer Rouge for its increased military activity which has directly led to these displaced people being forced to live in appalling conditions? Finally, in terms of Australia's peace settlement plan, can the Minister advise on the ramifications of reports in today's press that China has now pressed the tripartite coalition to agree to negotiate on a United Nations plan to end the 12-year war?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am no expert on the Cambodian situation, so I appreciated Senator Schacht giving some advance notice of the content of his question. Hence, I am able to give him an adequate answer.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of reports that between 100,000 and 150,000 Cambodians have been displaced as a consequence of the recent intensification of fighting within Cambodia. In May this year the Government provided $158,000 to the Australian Freedom from Hunger Campaign for emergency food assistance for displaced persons in Cambodia.

This followed an appeal from Phnom Penh through international agencies and non-government organisations. During 1989-90 Australia provided a total of $6.6m for humanitarian basic assistance within Cambodia through non-government organisations and international agencies. The Government is prepared to provide further emergency assistance.

A representative from the Australian Freedom from Hunger Campaign is currently in Cambodia to obtain details of what may be required and to prepare a proposal for the Government's urgent consideration. I can assure the honourable senator that the Government will consider sympathetically and urgently the proposal when it is received. Australia would also welcome contributions by other countries.

Australia very much regrets that the intensification of fighting has brought further suffering to the Cambodian people. This has been largely as a result of increased military activity by the Khmer Rouge. These developments make it imperative that international efforts focus on achieving a comprehensive settlement as that is the only way of bringing an end to the conflict.

I can confirm press reports that China's Premier, Li Peng, has told the Cambodian resistance leader that the time was right for a political solution to the Cambodian problem and that China was willing, along with other concerned parties, to make efforts for a comprehensive, just and reasonable solution. In a statement issued in Beijing, the Cambodian resistance said that they supported a vital role for the United Nations and a comprehensive settlement; that they were willing to attend a meeting of Cambodian parties to be organised by the Paris conference co-chairmen-Indonesia and France-and to discuss, in a spirit of compromise, the establishment of a supreme national council at the earliest possible date; and accept that the agreements of the permanent five constitute the framework of a comprehensive political settlement in Cambodia. This is in accordance with the ideas for a comprehensive settlement which Australia has been actively pursuing.

I welcome the statement by both China's Premier and the Cambodian resistance. The endorsement by the Cambodian resistance parties of the permanent five agreements and the efforts of the Paris conference co-chairmen could be an important step towards bringing about a comprehensive settlement with an enhanced United Nations role as a vehicle for settlement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Is it a fact that a Tasmanian State Liberal member of parliament for the electorate of Lyons prior to his election approached the Minister regarding the Electoral Commissioner's refusal to allow him to vote in the 1987 Federal election? Is it true that this Australian citizen, born in Australia with an Australian passport, enrolled on the Tasmanian State roll for both Houses of parliament and now a State member of parliament, was again denied a vote in this year's Federal election? Can the Minister tell the Senate what action he has taken to make sure justice applies in this situation and that the Constitution of Australia is adhered to?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Decisions as to who should be on the electoral roll for elections to the Australian Parliament, to participate in that vital part of the democratic arrangements in this Commonwealth of Australia, are matters for the Chief Electoral Commissioner-now Mr Cox. I believe the previous Chief Electoral Commissioner made a decision in regard to the member for Lyons in the House of Assembly in Tasmania, to whom Senator Walters refers. This question is best answered by the Minister with responsibility for the Australian Electoral Office, Senator Bolkus.

ANSWER.PARA: I will say that the person to whom Senator Walters refers styles himself the Duke of Avram, and he wished to be placed on the Commonwealth electoral roll under that name. The reason why I am somewhat concerned about this matter is that this person in the Advocate-the north-western regional newspaper of Tasmania-accused me of being involved in a criminal conspiracy to keep him off the electoral roll. I held myself in check and did not issue a writ, which I could have made a fortune out of. If this person uses Senator Walters or anybody else outside this chamber to accuse me of a criminal conspiracy to prevent him from voting in a Federal election, I assure honourable senators that I will take such action.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister was asked by the member for assistance and that the Australian Constitution be abided by. The Australian Constitution states:

QUESTION.PARA: No adult person who has or acquires a right to vote at elections for the more numerous House of the Parliament of this State shall, while the right continues--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Walters, you are making a statement; you are not asking a supplementary question.
—I am asking a supplementary question in accordance with the Constitution. That is why I addressed my question to Senator Tate, who represents the Attorney-General. The Constitution continues:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . be prevented by any law of the Commonwealth from voting at elections of either House of the Parliament of the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. You have already commented on Senator Walters's alleged supplementary question and, with respect, I think you should enforce your ruling. It is not a supplementary question and I do not think it should be allowed.
—Order! Senator Walters, you will ask the supplementary question and make no further statement.
—I have quoted the Constitution. I ask the Minister--
—Order! Senator Walters, I am asking you to ask the supplementary question.
—I ask the Minister, who represents the Attorney-General, why that member was denied a vote at the last Federal election.

—In accordance with longstanding practice, it is not my intention to give any legal advice to this member of the House of Assembly. As a Minister within the Attorney-General's portfolio, it would be quite wrong for me to offer any advice.

—Is the Minister for Social Security aware that some pensioners are very concerned about the possible effect on their incomes of the decision in the Budget to deem a rate of return of 10 per cent on bank accounts over $2,000? What steps has the Government taken to explain this change to pensioners and to provide advice on the operation of the income and assets test?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly many pensioners are expressing some concern about that decision and are displaying a degree of confusion. That is not too surprising. It is a complex matter to explain to anybody, particularly to those in the community who are the most vulnerable and in that sense have the most to fear. However, on this occasion every person who will be affected by this decision to assume an income of 10 per cent on all funds over $2,000 will finish up with more disposable income and obviously will then be better off. Their pension may be reduced, but the private income they earn, even after tax, will mean that every single pensioner affected by this measure is better off.

ANSWER.PARA: One concern that has come through very clearly in the last two days is that pensioners might lose fringe benefits. Obviously that is important to many pensioners. They lose fringe benefits once they earn over $95 a week for a single pensioner, and I think $160 a week for a married couple. Because the Government knew that that would be a concern, there were long discussions about it and we have ensured that no pensioner who is receiving fringe benefits will lose them, irrespective of what interest may be assumed from any deposits that he or she has. So many, or most, of the concerns that pensioners have been expressing present no real reason for worry. I have spent quite a bit of time trying to put that to them.

In terms of giving pensioners some advice, a financial advice system for pensioners-the financial information service, or FIS scheme-has been operating within the Department of Social Security (DSS). It has been operating for some time and 25,000 pensioners have taken advantage of it. There were only 25 officers around the country but we have increased that number to 65. So if pensioners wish to ring their local DSS offices, they will be able to be put in contact with people who will give them very good advice-much better advice, I might say, than that given by those who have been getting pensioners to stick their money in accounts at interest rates of 3 or 4 per cent, actually depriving themselves of income. People who are on pensions are not having a dream run in this society and we ought to do all we can to encourage them to use their money better and hence to be in possession of more disposable income and have a bit better time of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy a question about the Iraq trade sanctions. While I support the imposition of the sanctions, I ask: Firstly, does the Minister accept that the costs of such sanctions should be shared by the whole community and not borne by the industries or individuals so affected? Secondly, in particular with regard to the wheat industry, which provides 90 per cent of our exports to Iraq, is the insurance cover for past sales to Iraq valid? What arrangements will be made to compensate the wheat industry for the $123m that is not covered by insurance? What action will be taken to alleviate the costs incurred because of the potential loss of 2.1 million tonnes of wheat sales to Iraq? What action will be taken to alleviate the costs incurred by other industries, particularly the live sheep trade with Kuwait?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge and congratulate Senator Crane on what I understand to be his first question in this chamber. Trade with Iraq has been the subject of a number of representations by rural organisations to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin. This is one of the themes of Senator Crane's series of questions concerning wheat, and that commodity has been the subject of particular representations to the Minister.

ANSWER.PARA: I inform Senator Crane that the Minister indicated in a press release on 7 August that it is too early at this stage to consider specific compensation measures; that the Wheat Board has confirmed that no losses have been sustained at this stage; and that the Government and the Australian Wheat Board are monitoring the situation closely. He went on to say that any substantial reduction in wheat grower returns from previous year pools is protected by the underwriting arrangements-I understand that that is one of the elements of the honourable senator's question-and that these are unlikely to be triggered. He said that the Government naturally assumes that Iraq will honour its debts, and that there is a possible contingent liability under the national interest provisions of the Export Finance Insurance Corporation if it does not.
There is also the question of outstanding existing contracts, which total some 356,000 tonnes of wheat and 22,000 tonnes of rice. The Government will be looking at both these issues in due course.

I might say that Australia has had a substantial trade surplus with Iraq. In 1989, Australian exports to Iraq totalled $340.3m and wheat accounted for approximately 96 per cent of exports. The Australian imports from Iraq were negligible. In relation to the question of live sheep to Kuwait, it is my understanding that a shipment of live sheep was heading or was in the process of heading to Kuwait. That is to say that it may be leaving for Kuwait, as I understand it--

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean?
—What I mean is that it is either on the water or about to go.
—But you aren't sure?
—I am not sure, that is right.
—That is what you should have said in the first place.
—I am glad the honourable senator assisted me in sorting that question out. The question of its being diverted to Saudi Arabia is, I understand, under consideration.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I would like to refer the Minister back to the first part of my question and that was: Does the Minister accept that the costs of such sanctions should be shared by the whole community and not borne by the industries or the individuals so affected? In view of the answer I would further ask: Is it a fact that the payments from reserves from Iraq held in the United States have ceased in terms of payment for Australian wheat?

—On the first part of the question, I have said that the Minister is monitoring that situation and will make a decision in due course. Before one gets too excited about what the cost might be, I point out that it is indeed prudent and reasonable that a government take some time to assess the situation. It is speculation at this stage as to whether there will be a cost at all. It is not appropriate therefore to address ourselves to a hypothetical question. I will have to take the second part of your question on notice.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of the tax avoidance scheme effectively converting income normally taxable at the various marginal rates, or in the case of company tax at 39 per cent, into interest earned by non-residents and thereby being taxed at only 10 per cent? Is the Minister also aware of Australian trusts directing profits to foreign charities, thereby avoiding Australian income tax and being reimbursed by those charities outside Australia? Is the Minister also aware that Mrs Barbara Smith, a Melbourne academic specialising in taxation, has estimated that these practices lead to losses to the taxpayer of up to $1.8 billion based on internal Australian Taxation Office documents? Finally, is the Minister aware that in addition to the above matters, the Taxation Office estimates that between $95m and $130m of additional withholding tax is evaded, that is, not paid each year? I ask the Minister: Can he advise the Senate why the Treasurer in the Budget has not addressed these tax avoidance rorts?

—I am aware of all the things that Senator Spindler mentioned in his question. I am aware of them because his former Leader for a brief period, Senator Macklin, asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, an identical question on 15 May 1990. The answer to that question appeared in the Senate Hansard on Tuesday, 21 August and I refer Senator Spindler to that answer which I believe answers his question.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When does the Government intend to take action on the matters raised?
—I have nothing to add to my former answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the earlier question by Senator Kemp on the Pyramid Building Society. The Minister indicated that neither he nor the Government was aware of the financial difficulties of the Society. The Treasurer indicated in the other place today that he was informed as events unfolded and that dealings did occur between the Victorian and the Commonwealth Governments at officials level. I ask the Minister: How does he explain the inconsistent answers? In view of the fact that the Government and its officials were informed, according to the Treasurer, why did the Government refuse to take any action to protect the depositors?

—It all depends at what time information was made available, but the original question directed to me by Senator Kemp related to the statement made by the Attorney-General and the then Treasurer in the Victorian Government in February or March of this year. My advice as of yesterday was that prior to the statement made by those two Ministers of the Victorian Parliament there was no information available to the present Government here.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the Minister to a report in the Gold Coast Bulletin of 30 July 1990 which suggests that the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) removed hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of sand from a national heritage listed Aboriginal site west of the Coolangatta airport. Can the Minister advise whether the report is accurate and, if so, what were the circumstances which led to this action?

—The situation is that a considerable amount of sand was removed from a site which is now known to be a site of significance, but the sand was removed for the simple reason that it was not known at the time that it was a significant site. This particular area was nominated for listing on the heritage register in November 1987. At the time that nomination was made, the FAC manager of the airport at Coolangatta issued a written instruction to all staff that the site that was undisturbed was not to be interfered with, and no further sand was to be taken. Indeed, the FAC has taken some measures to protect the area and is taking additional measures by erecting a fence to further protect the area. There was some confusion because some sand was stockpiled at the site which had been taken from the broadwater and that sand was taken. However, that sand did not come from any area that is the subject of any heritage protection.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In light of the previously announced rise in the price of the 41c postage stamp next month to 43c, does the decision to abolish the 1c and 2c coins mean that in fact the cost of postage stamps will rise to 45c?

—Because that question requires both philosophical and arithmetical understanding, I could handle either on their own but I cannot handle both. I will seek an answer from the Treasurer and provide it as soon as possible.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is a question which the Minister may be able to answer. Has the Government taken into account the inflationary aspects of price rises associated with that removal of those 1c and 2c coins, or does the Minister believe that all prices will be lowered down rather than upwards? What is going to happen to the expression, `If you look after the cents the dollars will take care of themselves'?
—That is your second question, Senator Brownhill.

—It is not a supplementary question, but what I think is best for me to do is to provide the honourable senator with a comprehensive answer to all his problems. It will cover pages in his case, but I will do that as soon as I can.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. During the parliamentary recess the Government released a discussion paper on ecologically sustainable development for public comment. Can the Minister outline the process, the public involvement and the timetabling, including any meetings, which will be organised to develop a government strategy for achieving ecologically sustainable development, particularly now that responses to that discussion paper have been received?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —A discussion paper was released for public comment on 25 June. The public have been commenting in droves to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. The position the Government adopted was to set up some sectoral groups to examine how ecologically sustainable development might be implemented in those sectors. Those groups will be given the assistance of some eminent persons, and they will be announced in the near future.

ANSWER.PARA: It has become obvious that there are concerns that there are a number of very serious cross-sectoral issues that may not be addressed by this sectoral approach. For that reason we have to be very careful to ensure that the terms of reference for these groups make it clear that cross-sectoral issues have to be addressed. We also need to make sure that these eminent persons will have cross-sectoral issues fully canvassed at each of the meetings. We intend to ensure that that is done. As well, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories will be represented on all of the sectoral working groups and will provide input on those cross-sectoral issues.

Since the start of this process, though, the Prime Minister indicated that he would convene a second meeting of all the participants, all those with a vital interest in the debate, after that first one some time back. We are certainly not walking away from that second meeting. I believe that the Prime Minister will announce its convening very soon.

Once again, all those Australians from primary industry sectors, mining, agriculture and environment-all those with an interest-will have an opportunity to air their views to those people who are in positions to make decisions that affect not just their sectors but the lives of Australians through the wealth that they create.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time today Senator Kemp asked me a question and Senator Hill asked me a complementary question relating to the Pyramid Building Society and the statement made, to depositors essentially, on 13 February by the then Treasurer and then Attorney-General in the State of Victoria. I was asked whether I or anyone in the Government prior to 13 February knew of the difficulties of the Pyramid Building Society. To that question I answered no. I answered no on the basis of information given to me yesterday. I did not add, in answering the question, that I believe the Ministers in Victoria concerned gave some knowledge of the matter to the Reserve Bank or had some discussions with the Reserve Bank. The question was whether I or Ministers in the Government knew. That was the question upon which I obtained advice yesterday and was told that the answer was no.

DEBATE.TITLE: ULLADULLA HINTERLAND BROADCASTING TRANSMISSION STATION ENVIRONMENTAL INQUIRY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The decision by the Government to clear VHF channels 3, 4, 5 and 5a of television transmissions to permit extension of FM radio broadcasting is resulting in a degree of disruption to television reception on the south coast of New South Wales, particularly affecting the transmission of WIN-TV, the television station that is based in Wollongong. Its signal had emanated from Knights Hill near Wollongong and, as a result of the change and because of the local topography, about half of the resident population cannot get adequate reception of the new UHF signals from Knights Hill. This is a major inconvenience to the region.

The Government has now decided to try to resolve this problem by recommending that a UHF transmission site be found on the south coast to allow the UHF signal to be repeated in this area. The ideal site for this is in the Moreton National Park. The New South Wales Government has given formal approval for an area of the Moreton National Park to be made available for this purpose, provided the environmental problems are adequately examined and resolved by the Federal Government.

This report is the report of the inquiry into this matter. One would have hoped that it would have resolved it. Unfortunately this report has not resolved it. Although it does say that there are two points in the Moreton National Park that would be suitable-and it gives a preference for one-it nonetheless suggests that there should be another inquiry to examine whether or not a different technical system might be adopted to bring this signal in in another way, and that the costs of such a different technical solution should now be examined.

As the shadow Minister for heritage, I am naturally concerned that the Moreton National Park be retained as a very important part of our heritage. Nonetheless, I also recognise the proper demands and requirements of people in the area who are being disadvantaged by a governmental decision. I simply ask the Government when it is considering this report that, if it is to inquire into the costs and disadvantages and advantages of this alternate system as recommended in this inquiry, it does so with remarkable speed, with more speed than it has shown in its approach to this matter in the past, and that it resolves the matter before any signal changes permanently disadvantage people in the region.

My own view is that ultimately the Little Forest Trig site is the one that is likely to be followed. It is the one that I understand suits both the transmission operator, WIN 4, and the community better. It involves very little ecological interference. There is not much, I must say, upon a quick reading of this report, that shows that there would be major damage to the region if this course of action were pursued. If the Government is going to have a supplementary inquiry into possible alternatives, it should, for heaven's sake, do so quickly and stop the disadvantage that would be there for residents of the south coast.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I would like to draw to the attention of the Senate that the plan of management submitted by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) into the Ashmore Reef national nature reserve is one of significant constitutional importance to Australia. The Ashmore and Cartier islands have had a very complex history. I note that on page 12 of the plan of management there is a very abbreviated statement with regard to sovereignty.

Given that the plan of management has been prepared by the ANPWS, which has always shown a contempt for others in the Northern Territory with regard to land grabbing for national parks and, in particular, the aspirations of the Northern Territory Government with regard to the Ashmore and Cartier Islands, I am very suspicious of this plan of management. Many honourable senators would be aware that at the time of self-government for the Northern Territory in 1978, the Ashmore and Cartier Islands were in effect annexed by the Commonwealth, which assumed responsibility for them. This action was taken by the Commonwealth in 1978 without consultation with the Northern Territory at the time of self-government. The issue became very controversial and was addressed.

The Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, the Hon. Marshall Perron, made a major submission to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in June of last year with regard to full self-government for the Northern Territory. That submission included a complete chapter, chapter 10, on the Ashmore and Cartier Islands, which addressed the appropriateness of re-incorporating the Ashmore and Cartier Islands into the Northern Territory, where there exists the appropriate constitutional framework for the management of laws and the appropriate management of the reef.

What concerns me is that that document has been on the Prime Minister's desk since June 1989, yet I note that in the proposed plan of management the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service gives no consideration to these constitutional issues. It does not address the fact that the Government ought to be giving attention to the appropriateness of the constitutional status first and foremost. It is not in any way addressed in the plan of management; it is not even addressed, and perhaps rejected, in the eyes of the Commonwealth.

If the plan of management is to be implemented, it would have effect for 10 years until the date specified in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette stating that the plan had come into operation. Ten years is a long time. Given that the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory made a submission to the Prime Minister in June of last year in order to resolve this issue, I am most concerned that this matter has not been addressed. It appears to be another usurping of functions by a Commonwealth agency to bypass the proper arrangements that ought to be made between the Commonwealth Government and the Northern Territory Government.

Of course, the report addresses many other proper environmental issues that should be addressed. I have not had time to go into a great deal of detail with regard to the environmental aspects of the report. I am sure that, given that professional aspect of the work of ANPWS, I would not want to question many of the issues relating to fishing, the environment or perhaps many of the very necessary issues that have to be addressed.

I am deeply concerned that the constitutional issue has been bypassed, that the ANPWS has not engaged in and reported on a process for full and proper consultation. The plan of management just appears to be another greedy, nasty, sneaky means of the Hawke Government to bypass a proper appropriation of land and further administration to the Northern Territory Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to address the plan of management for the Ashmore Reef National Nature Reserve plan of management. The foreword to the report in front of us says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Ashmore Reef National Nature Reserve with its major breeding colonies of seabirds and coral reef ecosystems is a biological resource of >utstanding value.

The important issue before us is that that area be adequately protected and managed. If I might reflect for a moment on Senator Tambling's remarks, it is clear that in the past this area has not been adequately protected. Slightly after the section to which he drew our attention on sovereignty the report deals with the weather station and says:

An automatic weather station was erected on West Island in 1962. By 1970 all equipment had been stolen and the inner walls removed. The station was refurbished in 1971 but pilfering and vandalism again resulted in the destruction of the station. It was abandoned in 1973.

If the Commonwealth does not have the resources to adequately supervise these islands, one wonders just how well the Northern Territory might be able to manage that task, given that we are looking at a very small group of islands and a very extensive reef system which is closer to Timor than it is to the Australian mainland. The report says:

The islands and waters of the Reserve support extremely high concentrations of breeding seabirds, many species of which are nomadic and have their main breeding sites on small isolated islands. The islands are important as staging posts for the migration of those birds which migrate between Australia and the northern hemisphere.
The report goes on:

Forty-three of the seventy-eight bird species recorded from the Ashmore Islands are included on the Japan-Australia and the Australia-China Migratory Birds Agreements. These Agreements oblige Australia to protect the environments of the listed migratory and endangered bird species.

These statements make it quite clear that this group of very small islands play an extremely valuable role in conservation, not only for Australian biology but also for the protection of species which do not recognise national boundaries. The report says:
Large colonies of Sooty Terns, Crested Terns, Bridled Terns and Common Noddies breed on East and Middle Islands-
two of the three islands-
with the number of breeding pairs ranging up to 50,000.

It is of concern, therefore, that in the past, as I have already said, the islands have come under extreme pressure, particularly from over-exploitation of the fishing reserves, from the poaching of eggs and adult birds by visiting fishermen and by the destruction caused by introduced species, particularly the common black rat, Rattus rattus.

It is encouraging that we have a plan of management for this area but at the same time rather concerning that the level of surveillance which is necessary to ensure the success of that plan of management will not be carried out sufficiently. It is essential that the Government not only proclaim a plan of management for an environment of significance-the environment of Ashmore Reef-but also provide sufficient resources properly to monitor and manage that environment. Without proper resourcing the destructive practices which we have seen in the past on the reef will simply continue, and the reef system and its bird populations will further decline.

I understand that the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service is confident that the current management practices will be sufficient to protect this reserve from illegal fishing. However, I am not convinced that adequate measures exist to control the illegal fishing industry on other offshore islands in the Timor Sea.
