TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The achievement of good industrial relations in Australia is essential for the success of our economy and the furtherance of social justice. This is even more the case during a time when the Australian economy is being fundamentally reformed. The reform objective is crucially affected by the operation of our national industrial relations system. Such a system should be capable of being an effective instrument for change in a way which is fair to employers, workers and their unions, while safeguarding our national economic and industrial interests.

The Hawke Government has, since taking office in 1983, sought to ensure that this is achieved. Our considerable success in improving Australia's industrial relations performance is on the record and has been internationally recognised. Credit must be given to the union movement for its restraint and preparedness for reforms in the national interest. Employers and their organisations are generally demonstrating a constructive approach towards economic and industrial change. Broadly put, a substantial degree of consensus has emerged that micro-economic reform is a key national priority and that industrial relations has a key role in it.

No sector of industry is immune from the need to become more efficient and competitive. Governments, employers and workers must be partners in achieving reform quickly, fairly and without industrial friction.

Trade unions which choose to participate in our national industrial relations system must have the capacity for constructive participation in the reform process. Their capacity depends to a crucial degree on the relevance of their structure.

The need for a more rational union structure has been recognised and appreciated for some time now by almost all involved in industrial relations. It has been emphasised in no less than five major economic reports to various Australian governments. The Jackson report on manufacturing industry in 1975, the report of the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration in 1977, the Myers report on technological change in 1980, the report of the Hancock Committee of review of Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems in 1985 and this year's report by the Australian Manufacturing Council all agree on this point: that the multiplicity of unions is an impediment to industrial and administrative efficiency.

The union movement itself recognises that there is a need for its rationalisation along broad industry lines and that the process of reform should not be complicated by the involvement of numerous unions in the requisite negotiations and bargaining between the parties.

It is clearly in the interests of workers that they share in the benefits of economic restructuring. Those benefits will be maximised if their unions are to have the capacity and organisation to identify more closely with the interests of individual industries and enterprises.

The major thrust therefore of the measures which I am presenting today is intended to reform the national industrial relations system in ways which will meet these needs. An inter-related package of legislative and administrative measures is to be implemented. Changes will be made to the provisions of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 which affect the size, number and industrial coverage of federally registered unions. The amendments are designed to encourage:
* a substantial reduction in the numbers of such unions; and
* those unions being more oriented in their industrial operations towards particular industries and sectors of industry.
The main elements of the amendments are:
* additional objects in the Act;
* new requirements as to the membership of unions for their registration or continued registration under the Act;
* the recognition of federations of organisations proposing to amalgamate;
* revised procedures to bring about speedier amalgamations;
* changes to the powers of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to make orders altering the coverage of work by federally registered unions; and
* some revision of the Act's preference provisions.
New Objects
In exercising their powers under the Act, the Commission, the Federal Court of Australia and the Industrial Registrar must have regard to the scope and purpose of the Act.
This is reinforced by the Commission's express statutory obligation to take account of the Act's objects, which include those expressed in section 3.

Two new objects are to be included in that section. One is to encourage and facilitate amalgamations under the Act. The other is to encourage and facilitate the development of organisations registered under the Act, particularly by reducing the numbers that are in an industry or enterprise.

These new objects reflect the underlying intention of the Bill, namely to assist in the rationalising of organisations, particularly unions, in a way which is consistent with our national economic, industrial and social interest. I must emphasise that the objects are not intended to be read individually. To the extent that it is appropriate, they are to be taken and applied together.
Size of Unions

At present to be registered a union must, unless there are special circumstances, be industry-based and have at least 1,000 members who are employees or whose usual occupation is as an employee. Existing registered unions with fewer than 1,000 employees will have their continued registration reviewed from 1 March 1992.

These requirements are to be changed under clauses 12 and 14 of the Bill. The figure of 1,000 will be altered to 20,000, but a union with a smaller membership will be able to be registered if it can show that its registration is justified.

For existing small registered unions, the 20,000 membership requirement is to be phased in, so they will be subject to a two-stage review. The existing review relating to unions with fewer than 1,000 members will proceed in 1992. A review of the continued registration of unions with fewer than 20,000 members will commence on 1 March 1994. In either case, the union's registration is to be cancelled if it cannot be shown that there are special circumstances which justify its continuation in the public interest.

I emphasise that cancellation of a union's registration will not be automatic. There will be due process. Each small union will be given an opportunity to present its case. Decisions will be reviewable on appeal. It will be for the Commission to decide on an appropriate order according to the circumstances of each case. The Commission could, in some cases, be influenced by the absence of another union which could properly represent the interests of employees in a particular industry. It may consider the industrial or economic consequences of deregistration, particularly if the small union concerned is the major union in the particular industry or sector concerned. In appropriate cases, the Commission may take into account the views of the workers affected as to how their industrial interests should be represented.
It is also noted that the minimum size requirement does not affect the existence of a union, or its operation, outside the federal conciliation and arbitration system.
The new provisions will encourage small unions to consider their place in the national industrial relations system, and put the onus on them to justify it.
Federations

A new provision will be included in the Act's revised amalgamation Division to permit the recognition for the purposes of the Act of a federation of registered organisations proposing to amalgamate within a prescribed period of three years.

Such a federation will be voluntary and the organisations concerned will be able to dissolve it, if they wish. While the federation exists, however, it will be able to represent for the purposes of the Act all or any of its constituent organisations, for instance, in proceedings before the Commission. A federation will, however, not be capable of being a party to an award.
This measure will help registered organisations, whether of employers or employees, to prepare for amalgamation.
Amalgamations

The voluntary restructuring of the union movement should be encouraged. To assist unions to rationalise, the Act's amalgamation provisions are to be completely revised. Their operation will be quicker and more adaptable. Mechanisms for avoiding or minimising technical difficulties and other problems will be provided.
Clause 15 of the Bill repeals the Act's existing amalgamation Division. The new Division has several notable features.

A statement of legislative intention is to be included. This will emphasise the importance of the Act's new objects relating to amalgamations and the development of organisations as well as the existing object concerning the efficient management of organisations. Speed and the avoidance or minimising of problems in the amalgamation process will be emphasised. Reference will also be made to the existing object concerning the need for democratic control of organisations.
This will provide guidance to the Commission and the Federal Court of Australia when they come to exercise their powers in relation to amalgamations.

The existing amalgamation procedures will be telescoped and modified to overcome their current unnecessarily protracted and sequential operation. Amalgamation proposals which now can take anything up to two years to be decided under the Act should be able to be completed in a few months at most. This will also be assisted by a provision giving a Presidential Member wide powers to resolve any difficulties encountered in the process.

A designated Presidential Member of the Commission will be responsible for hearing and determining certain matters before a proposed amalgamation may be submitted to ballots of members. Among other things, the member will deal with any application for a declaration of a community of interest between the organisations. Such a declaration will result in less onerous requirements for approval of an amalgamation ballot.
The existing provision relating to a community of interest is to be changed in a number of ways.

To provide greater flexibility in the processes, organisations proposing to amalgamate will be able to seek a declaration before formally lodging a scheme for a proposed amalgamation, or at the same time as the scheme is lodged.
The community of interest test itself will be changed to improve its operation. There will be specified criteria which if met will lead to the making of a declaration.

The Commission will also have a discretion to find a community of interest in other circumstances. The criteria themselves will be changed to make them more practical. At present, they are effectively inoperative where a very large organisation seeks to amalgamate with a small organisation.

To overcome this, a substantial number of members of one of the organisations will have to meet the criteria. Currently a substantial number of members of all the organisations must satisfy those criteria.
This is in line with views expressed in 1980 in the National Labour Consultative Council and supported by a Full Bench of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in 1984.

Another change will be to dispense with the present requirement that the Commission be satisfied that the amalgamation will further the objects of the Act. It is considered that this will be redundant, given the Act's new explicit objects and the statement of legislative intention to which I have referred. To the extent that the objects are applicable to a community of interest matter, they must be considered.
Some changes are proposed to the requirements for amalgamation ballots which are to be conducted by the Australian Electoral Commission.

It will be possible to have a secret postal ballot or a ballot at meetings of members with secret voting. In the latter case, a Presidential Member must agree and there must be appropriate protection for members, such as provision for absentee voting. The Federal Court may inquire into any alleged irregularities.

At present, if a Presidential Member approves, a ballot need not be conducted of members of a large organisation which is amalgamating with smaller organisations. Such an exemption may be granted where the membership of the smaller bodies does not exceed 5 per cent of the total membership of the proposed amalgamated organisation.

The figure will be increased to 25 per cent. There are practical difficulties, including problems of organisation and cost, where a very large organisation is proposing to amalgamate with smaller organisations. The higher figure balances such practical considerations against the effects of an amalgamation on the interests of the members of the larger organisation. An exemption will still be subject to approval by the Commission.

New provisions are also to be included to provide for the automatic succession of an amalgamated organisation to the rights, liabilities and property of an organisation which is deregistered when an amalgamation takes effect. The Federal Court will have power to resolve any difficulties that may arise.

There will also be new provisions which validate unintended irregularities in the amalgamation process. Irregularities in ballots cannot be validated in this way. The Federal Court will be able in appropriate cases to overrule the validation of an irregularity.

Another change is to be made to assist the amalgamation process. A committee of management of an organisation will be able to use the organisation's funds and other resources to support a proposed amalgamation up to the close of the ballot, provided the committee so resolves. Members will need to be given reasonable notice of such a decision. This provision is intended to address difficulties arising from a recent Federal Court decision which restricted the period in which resources could be used in this way.
Orders changing union coverage of work

If union rationalisation is to be effective and occur quickly, there must be an effective mechanism for adjusting the rights of unions to represent the interests of particular classes or groups of workers. At present, the Commission may only make such adjustments to resolve actual or likely demarcation disputes. This is too narrow and some technical legal problems have arisen.

Accordingly, a new provision is proposed which will permit a Presidential Member or a Full Bench of the Commission to alter a union's representative rights by making those rights exclusive, removing them or conferring them. That power will be exercisable on application by an organisation, an employer or the Minister. In exercising it, the Commission will be obliged to have regard to the public interest and to the Act's objects. One of the new objects will be especially relevant. That object relates to the development of organisations, particularly by reducing their numbers in an industry or enterprise. Even so, the objects of the Act as a whole should be considered.

The power to adjust union coverage will be available to prevent or settle disputes, but it is to be hoped that Australia's industrial parties are sufficiently mature to address issues of union coverage in a rational, constructive way. Agreed changes can be implemented under this provision. A greater industry orientation for unions, which is widely supported, should be achievable.

Larger unions are more likely to take part in voluntary changes of coverage than smaller unions. That situation will be brought about by smaller unions taking advantage of the new amalgamation provisions.
Preference

Some changes are proposed under clause 11 to the provisions of the Act governing the power of the Commission to award preference. To clarify the provision, specific examples are to be given of the types of matters which can be the subject of preference orders. These matters are within the scope of the Commission's existing powers. In addition, the Commission will, if it thinks fit, be able to require preference to be given to persons who have applied for membership of federally registered unions. At present, preference can only be awarded to particular unions or members of unions. It will still be a matter for the Commission to decide whether preference is warranted in particular cases.
Non-legislative initiatives

The amendments that I have outlined will provide the necessary legislative framework to enable restructuring to take place. To reinforce the effectiveness of the changes, increased financial assistance will be available, as announced in this week's Budget, to help federally registered unions to meet the considerable costs involved in amalgamating. Amalgamation negotiations are at a critical stage in a number of industries. Successful amalgamations depend on rank and file support. The Government's budgetary allocation for 1990-91 will help unions to promote the amalgamation process among union membership.

A new Deputy President of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission will be appointed to assist specifically with union amalgamations. The position will be located in Melbourne and complement the existing Sydney based Deputy President dealing with amalgamations. The establishment of this new position will ensure that appropriate resources are dedicated to the Government's priority of rationalising union structures.
The Government will also, if necessary, enhance the resources of the Australian Industrial Registry to enable it to perform its functions effectively following the amendment of the Act.
Other Amendments
The Bill also makes a number of other amendments of a minor policy or technical nature and includes appropriate transitional provisions.
Financial Impact Statement

The new amalgamation provisions provided in the Bill are likely to have the effect of encouraging a greater number of amalgamations between organisations than has occurred in the past. An increase in the number of amalgamations will result in additional cost to the Commonwealth, as it meets the cost of amalgamation ballots conducted by the Australian Electoral Commission.

It is not possible to give a reliable estimate of the increased costs which may result, given the difficulty in judging the impact of the new legislation on the number of amalgamations between organisations.

The Government is confident that this Bill will be seen as a pivotal development in the history of industrial relations in Australia. It seeks to be a profoundly significant agent of reform at a time when reform is rightly judged to be the pre-eminent economic challenge before us. It provides the process by which the Australian union movement can be both part of, and facilitator of, this reform. With the significance of this development in mind, I commend the Bill to honourable senators. I present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.

SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON ANIMAL WELFARE TABLING STATEMENT-INTENSIVE LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION REPORT

The report that has just been tabled on behalf of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare was prepared by the Committee in the previous Parliament under the Chairmanship of Senator Ray Devlin now retired.
This Intensive Livestock Production Report deals with animal welfare aspects of intensive production in this country of pigs and the domestic fowl-layers and broiler (meat) chickens.

The report highlights the importance of these industries which contribute significantly to the economy and to the daily diets of most Australians. They provide food, employment and generate activity in the millions of dollars.

The inquiry into intensive livestock production was undertaken because of the developing perception in Australia that the welfare of our domestic livestock is being jeopardised in many of the housing systems operating.

Intensive animal husbandry has become a controversial issue in most developed countries around the world. Physical and psychological stress associated with close confinement, high stock densities, lack of access to outdoors and certain surgical husbandry practices underlies much of the concern about intensive production systems.

The benefits of intensive husbandry from the human point of view is the encouragement of maximum production; efficient food conversion, due partly to the controlled environment and partly to the improved genetic make-up of animals; the maximum utilisation of equipment and buildings; and a reduction in the number of workers needed to look after the livestock.

Benefits for the livestock are freedom from predators, malnutrition, vagaries of the weather, and parasitic infestation. Such benefits inevitably involve some degree of restriction on activities and some modification to the environment.

Critics consider that the extreme forms of intensive husbandry which have evolved in recent years and which restrict movement, space allowance and social contacts raises quality of life questions for these food animals.

Submissions were first made on these matters in 1984 shortly after the Committee was established. While evidence has been taken and establishments inspected over several years, competing priorities has meant that the Committee could not concentrate on the subject fully until 1989.

As the Senate is aware this Committee has to date tabled five inquiry reports, Export of Live Sheep from Australia; Dolphins and Whales in Captivity; Kangaroos; Animal Experimentation; and Sheep Husbandry.

The Intensive Livestock Report focuses on the three areas of most concern in intensive livestock production-the pig, chicken meat and egg industries. It outlines the development in Australia of intensification and economic and social pressures including farm cost input and consumer interests and concerns.

It presents the key issues in the welfare debate including the various welfare assessment standpoints. It is a complex field involving both ethical and practical considerations. The concept of physiological and behavioural needs of animals is generally accepted in Australia. The debate today centres around whether there are specific conditions that result in physiological or behavioural responses that are in themselves the result of undue suffering or are indications of such a state.
The fundamental issues confronting this Committee in its inquiry were whether:
* intensive systems deny the welfare of animals;
* animals should be able to undertake particular innate behaviours;
* an animal bred and reared in a series of generations really does suffer some sense of deprivation about the things it is denied access to;
* the proposed alternative systems can produce the quantity and quality of food that society seems to demand;
* they are capable of producing this food at a price society is willing to pay;
* alternative systems have a true welfare advantage for the animals.

The Committee came to the conclusion at the end of investigation that intensive systems are appropriate if the health of the animals or birds are not affected and if their behaviour is not disturbed. But it also recognised that while trauma in intensive systems is clearly recognisable in some circumstances in others it is not observable or easily measured.

The recommendations contained in this Report are directed at improving the social and physical environment of intensively housed livestock and at exploring viable alternative husbandry systems.. They include recommendations on welfare and welfare assessment, housing systems evaluation research, stockmanship, education and training, legislation and regulation, standards husbandry systems, tax incentives, and off farm handling.

Recommendations relating to the domestic fowl include reductions in the stocking density for caged layers, ways to overcome the problem of overstocking, and improvements to cage design, alternative housing systems, husbandry practices (beak trimming and induced moulting) and handling and transport.
Recommendations on broiler (meat) chicken production are concerned with reviews of stocking densities and improved processing practices.

Recommendations on pig production involve research and development of alternative housing systems, stocking densities and the consequences of pen space, stocking rates and group sizes, and husbandry practices (tail docking and teeth clipping).

Recommendations concerning breeding sows includes the encouragement of alternative approaches to accommodating these animals through their various life stages and the improvement in husbandry skills needed to avoid welfare problems associated with close confinement. The Committee has recommended a move away from individually-confined stall systems for housing the dry sow and a complete ban on tethering.

Mr President/Deputy President animal welfare is part of the growing community concern for the environment and for the quality of life of both humans and animals. This report documents those concerns and proposes reform in specific areas.

Whether radical reform, of the kind that has been proposed in Tasmania and several European countries, can and should occur depends on complex social and biological priorities. Incomplete knowledge about the technical, economic and positive welfare potential of different methods of husbandry compounds the problem.

Mr President/Deputy President I was appointed to this Committee on 31 May this year the day this Inquiry Report was finalised. I congratulate those involved, past Senators Ray Devlin, John Morris (past Chairmen) and Norm Sanders, my colleagues Senator David Brownhill (Deputy Chairman), Senator Paul Calvert, and Senator Barney Cooney, long serving and active members of this Committee, and recent appointee Senator Robert Bell.

The Report provides a much needed review of the economic, scientific, ethical, aesthetic and practical concepts associated with this controversial subject and it underlines the need for close liaison between governments, producers, scientists, and animal welfare groups to ensure that animal production remains sustainable in the face of mounting community concerns about animal welfare.
I commend the Report to the Parliament.

In some of those other countries lobby groups have forced the closure of, or brought about substantial reform to, those industries. For example, the Committee did not support a ban on cages in the laying hen industry, which other people had been promoting and which other parts of the world had been moving towards, because we believe a return to the free range system in Australia to be neither economically feasible nor necessarily a sound welfare advance. The free-range laying hens which we looked at in South Australia and New South Wales were found not to be as good as people would have thought. In fact, in some areas they are clearly substandard. The birds were in muddy, exposed yards with little access to clean laying boxes. Basically, in many cases, the eggs were not as nice as those found in some of the caged systems that we looked at.
Animal Welfare Committee

If people who gave evidence that they bought free-range eggs were to see the conditions under which the free-range hens lived, they would be horrified. That is why the Committee recommended that the caged system remain. However, it is not without fault. This was reflected in the Committee's recommendations on cage size and design. In the caged laying hen industry we recommended that there be a change in cage sizes. The recommendation was that we take an initial step for the maximum stocking density for cages with three or more birds be reduced from 52 kilograms per square metre to 46 kilograms per square metre. That does not sound like a great difference. I know that some people in the industry were concerned about that. They believed that extra costs would be involved and that there would be extra problems for the industry.

However, we also recommended that there be tax incentives to increase the size of those cages and that people be allowed five years in which to bring about the changes in the cage sizes. The change in the cage sizes for laying hens constituted quite a big part of the report.

We also considered the banning of laying cages when it could be demonstrated that viable alternative systems can be developed suitable to Australian conditions and these alternative systems have positive welfare advantages. As I said, during the inquiry we did not find that there would be any great advantages by moving away from the caged system to a free-range system.

As I said, we do not expect the industry to change overnight. We also think that it should receive assistance by way of tax incentives and that these changes should be introduced over about five years. At all times the Government should be providing incentives to help people with better animal welfare practices.

We were concerned about the number of broilers and the way they gained in size when they first go into the shed system. At the end of the inquiry, I had a second look at broilers when they were in full size to see whether there were any problems and whether each bird had less space. I was satisfied that the industry is looking after its birds, both those in the caged laying hen system and those in the broiler industry.

The Committee said that research work and constant revision of housing design in the pig industry indicated the growers' awareness and the importance of optimum housing and living conditions. The pig industry has made progress on this and it is to be commended for it. Some people in that industry are very forward looking.

The pig industry also is one in which there are free-ranging animals. Under Australian conditions this is not always the best way to go. There are good farmers and there are bad farmers. In our report we say that progress is being made and that the pig industry should continue with the evaluation and upgrading of housing systems.
In these intensive and extensive animal industries, stock husbandry is obviously of paramount importance. We made comments about its being the essential item.

No system-no matter how sophisticated it is-is of any benefit to animals, or to anyone, if the staff members are not skilled in handling the animals and do not understand their needs. People in the industry, especially those in the intensive industries, should be well educated in the needs of their animals and in looking after them.

It is very difficult to work out how to legislate to ensure that a producer does not employ staff who have no understanding of the job and little love of the animals. Obviously people who engage in animal industries will employ skilled staff for the benefit of their animals. At the end of the day it is the good, well cared for animal that will produce the best and do it most economically. Anyone who has had anything to do with animals over the years knows that if animals are not looked after, the best result is not achieved. We must ensure that animals in intensive animal industries are looked after. The Committee believes that that is the way to go.

We believe that the tethering of pigs should be banned. More work should be done on stalls and farrowing crates. More notice should be taken of body dimensions of the sows. In some instances, they appear to be cramped although they seem to be content. More evaluation of their movement and their need for freedom has to be undertaken.

The Committee has played a very big role in the welfare of animals. The new Chairman, Senator Burns, who has just moved the adoption of this report, will enjoy himself on that Committee because its members and staff work very well together. Before the Committee winds up at the end of the next year, we have other inquiries to make. I believe we have played a big part in helping the intensive animal industries and the other industries we have looked at in the past. I commend this report to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS IN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! On behalf of Mr President and pursuant to the resolutions of the Senate of 9 May and 1 June 1990, I lay on the table the report of the Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia, together with the transcripts of evidence which were presented to Mr President on 31 July 1990. In accordance with the terms of the resolution of 1 June 1990, the President has authorised the printing and circulation of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

On 31 July I presented the report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia to the President of the Senate pursuant to the resolution of the Senate of 1 June 1990. Before addressing the recommendations and the conclusions contained in the report, I would like to comment briefly on the background to the inquiry and the conduct of the inquiry itself.

Honourable senators will recall that the detection of chemical residues in beef exported to the United States of America in 1987 prompted the Government and the Senate to initiate reviews of the regulation and use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals in Australia. In 1988, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) requested that the Australian Science and Technology Council undertake a study of chemical residues in agricultural products. That study concluded:

The development and implementation of standards for chemical residues in agricultural products are satisfactory and chemical residues are not an undue health hazard to consumers of Australian agricultural produce.

In November 1988, the Senate, when passing the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988, resolved to establish a select committee to inquire into and report upon the following matters: The adequacy of arrangements for administration and coordination systems under the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988; the efficacy of pest management systems; and the economic, social and environmental impact of agricultural and veterinary chemicals and their alternatives.

When the Committee was established it was suggested by some that the inquiry would provide a forum for emotional radicals wishing to attack the chemical industry. It was also suggested that the inquiry had the potential to cause great harm to Australia's hard-earned reputation as a world leader in the production of clean agricultural products. As Chairman of the Select Committee I am pleased to report that these forecasts did not eventuate.

The Committee received 256 submissions and held 18 days of public hearings. Contributors to the inquiry included several Commonwealth Government departments and agencies, State and Territory governments, chemical companies, rural organisations, consumer and environmental groups and interested individuals. On the whole, evidence presented to the Committee attempted to reconcile rather than perpetuate differing points of view. A common theme running through the evidence was that more needs to be done-more openness, more information and more research.

The Committee, comprising members from the four major parties represented in this chamber, has presented a unanimous report. I consider that the Committee's report represents a significant and wide-ranging response to issues relating to the regulation and use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals in Australia. The report contains 45 recommendations and 18 major conclusions. When taken together, these recommendations and conclusions provide a sound basis for the effective and efficient regulation and use of farm chemicals in Australia. I also consider that the implementation of the Committee's recommendations will allay many public concerns about aspects of the regulatory system, the use of specific chemicals and certain practices.

The Committee's report recognises that agricultural and veterinary chemicals contribute significantly to the production of quality food and fibre and to the prevention and alleviation of disease and suffering in animals. Nevertheless, the use of these chemicals should be neither pre-eminent nor exclusive but rather should be an important tool in an integrated approach to pest management. The Committee's report stresses that farm chemicals should be applied judiciously and responsibly and that research and farming practices should aim to reduce the use of pesticides wherever possible.

As I mentioned earlier, the Committee's report contains 45 recommendations. These fall broadly into the following seven categories: the legislative and administrative framework for regulation; information; monitoring of residues; research; alternative pest management strategies; specific public concerns; and education and training. I do not intend to review all of the recommendations contained in the Committee's report as I am mindful that other members of the Committee may wish to address specific findings of the Committee.

I would like to address five general issues raised in the report. Firstly, the Committee concluded that the new arrangements for the clearance of farm chemical products established under the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988 are welcome. Nevertheless, the Committee considers that the regulatory processes can be improved. In particular, the report concludes that the regulatory system must be more open, accessible and accountable and must be seen to be so. To achieve these objectives the Committee makes recommendations for consumer representation on the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council and formal consultative arrangements between the Council, industries, interested groups and individuals.

Secondly, the Committee's report recognises that more information on the regulatory process, toxicological assessments and the safety, health and environmental aspects of agricultural and veterinary chemicals should be made publicly available. The Committee makes positive recommendations on how this should be achieved.

Thirdly, the Committee notes that organic farming methods, although practised by only a small percentage of producers, have a legitimate role to play in Australian agriculture. Growing interest in these techniques should be reflected in government research, extension and export assistance programs. In particular, the Committee recommends that a uniform system of standards and guidelines for the production and marketing of organic produce should be developed. The Committee also recognises the need for further research into biological control strategies, integrated pest management techniques and minimum tillage.

Fourthly, during the inquiry the Committee became aware of public unease and, in some cases, anger about particular social and environmental issues, specific chemicals or certain practices. Four matters were consistently drawn to the attention of the Committee. These were aerial spraying, the use of organochlorine pesticides, pest control and the possible long term effects of pesticides on public health. The Committee considered the evidence on these matters and has made constructive and appropriate recommendations that will allay many concerns.

Fifthly, the Committee was told that, although the regulation of agricultural and veterinary chemicals in Australia is as stringent as in other developed countries, these chemicals must be used safely, responsibly and in accordance with local directions. Therefore, education, training and safety courses are essential to improve occupational health and to ensure safety and the responsible and judicious use of chemicals. In particular, the Committee formed the view that education and training programs must recognise the significant role that rural women, as partners in agricultural enterprises, can play in this regard.

Finally, as Chairman of the Select Committee, I wish to commend the other members of the Committee for the positive and constructive approach adopted during the course of a topical and sometimes complex inquiry. In particular, I would like to thank my Deputy Chairman, Senator Brownhill, for his assistance during the course of the inquiry. On behalf of the Committee, I express our thanks to the Committee's staff for their invaluable assistance. I commend the report to the Senate.
