Consultative committees are to be established and chemical products need labelling improvements. I would mention the role that housewives have to play in relation to chemicals that are used on farms. Integrated pest management has already been mentioned, as well as the national standards for pest control officers and the regular testing of people who are tied up with the industry.

One area that concerned me about the pest extermination industry was household spraying. We received in evidence numerous examples of what was basically over-servicing and the use of chemicals that could produce excessive amounts of residues in houses. People should self-regulate in that area. I do not believe in regulation all the time; I think that we should be self-regulating. If we have a good neighbour policy, there is nothing wrong with chemicals being used now and in the future, as long as they are used judiciously. If they are used in a safe and proper manner according to the directions, they will be here for a long time to help the welfare of animals and humans and to make sure that we produce good clean produce that is acceptable on all the world markets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is particularly pleasing to rise to comment on the report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia because two things became apparent during the genesis of the report and during the considerations of the Committee. I remind the Senate that the initiation of this inquiry was at the instigation of Senator Powell.
—We had a motion on the books too.

—At that stage Senator Powell had the carriage of agricultural matters on behalf of the Australian Democrats. When Senator Powell initially raised the proposal for this Senate select committee inquiry it was supported by the Australian Labor Party but resisted, as Senator Panizza has interpolated, because the Opposition sought much narrower terms of the inquiry. A number of farms in Australia had been quarantined as a result of the use of organochlorine pesticides, and excessive residues had appeared in the meat from some of those farms. As I understand it, the Opposition's alternative motion was a much narrower one-framed merely to see how one would adequately compensate the farmers who had been so affected. The Labor Party then withdrew from its initial support, and it took Senator Powell some 12 months before the Labor Party agreed eventually to this inquiry, with its wider terms of reference.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Brownhill has already indicated, it is particularly pleasing that, despite that somewhat shaky beginning, the members of the Committee worked extremely well together; in the end a consensus report was accepted by all members of the Committee. The fears which had been expressed by some members of the Opposition-and, indeed, outside the Parliament by the agricultural and veterinary chemical industry, for instance, and some farmer groups-that this Committee inquiry was merely a witch-hunt were not realised.

There were three strands which came together and led to the necessity of a committee such as this one. Since the Second World War we have seen the increasing chemicalisation of agricultural production. In view of a number of hazards to human health and the environment which had become recognised over those years, it was appropriate that there be a wide-ranging inquiry. In late 1988 we saw the Federal Government assume under its legislation the Federal registration and regulation of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. That was supported by all parties in the Senate and was generally recognised as a good thing. As I have already indicated, we then saw significant damage done to Australian exports by restriction on the ability to export beef from Australia and the quarantining of certain farms. Those things came together and indicated that then was the time for a wide-ranging inquiry into all aspects of agricultural and veterinary chemical use.

The Committee worked extremely well, as I have already indicated, under its Chairman, Senator Colston, and has come forward with an extremely useful report which has indicated a number of areas in which improvements need to be made.

Some of the evidence which came before the Committee indicates the importance of the Committee. When the Western Australian Department of Agriculture came before the Committee and was questioned about the early evidence of the damaging effects of organochlorine pesticides-this is evidence which went back to the early 1960s-it indicated that it was aware that there were damaging consequences flowing from this and that as early as the late 1960s and early 1970s it believed that it was necessary to phase out the use of these materials.

The Department then went on to indicate that had the beef export problem not emerged when it did, but had its officers had another year, the persistent organochlorine pesticides would have been phased out and the problem would not have arisen. That indicated to the members of the Committee the laxity which has pervaded the control of the use of these agents in Australia over many years and the slowness with which bodies that have been charged with the protection of public health and environmental health have acted to execute their responsibilities. The evidence that has been taken by this Committee and the report which we have before us today may well go a considerable way towards changing that situation.

Senator Brownhill has already drawn attention to some of the evidence that was put before the Committee in relation to aerial spraying, particularly in Tasmania. We heard evidence of very nasty practices in relation to overspraying of schools-and spraying under conditions in which material should not have been sprayed. The report specifically recommends that that whole area be tightened up and that if that cannot be done, perhaps consideration should be given to banning aerial spraying altogether.

The report also draws attention to the inadequacy in the past of the processes gone through by the various committees of the National Health and Medical Research Council, the inadequacy of the funding, and the speed and professionalism with which those bodies can carry out their tasks. The Committee recommends that more resources be devoted to this very important task. It also recommends that more attention be given to alternative non-chemical and less chemical intensive methods of agriculture and that extension services and educational services which give alternative advice to farmers be expanded.

One thing that came quite clearly out of this whole inquiry is that Australia has not become as chemically dependent as many other countries. If we choose to go down the road of using as little chemical as possible, and using no chemical in situations where that is indeed possible, we place ourselves in a very favourable situation with respect to acceptance of our production on world markets. It is in the economic sense that we should avidly pursue the sorts of recommendations that are made in this report so that Australia not only protects the health of its people and its environment but also continues to produce clean and safe food which is as little chemically tainted as possible and which is as acceptable as possible on world markets and, therefore, does not face the problems which we faced during the closure of our beef export markets. That is the economic future which is suggested if this report's recommendations are carried out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to rise to speak to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia and add my remarks to those of my colleagues on this Committee. Perhaps Senator Brownhill put it more succinctly than I might be inclined to when he said that the Committee was born out of anger. I forget the rest of what he said, but it was not only succinct, it was also civil. The truth was elaborated a little more by Senator Panizza by way of interjection when Senator Coulter was speaking. The facts are that it was born out of a lot of annoyance and anger at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: One sadness about the references now coming to committees is that they tend to emerge out of brawls in the Senate and not out of considered deliberation on what might be an issue of some major significance. There seems to be the use of numbers to crunch references through rather than a consensus on the importance of the issue. I am advised by colleagues older and wiser than I-or at least who have been around here longer-that this used not to be the practice in times past. Of course, what used to be the practice in times past is usually tempered by the gentleness of time. I am not going to push them on the truth and I have not repaired to the Senate Hansard of the time to make sure that that is always true.

Whatever the circumstances of this Committee's origins, it is certainly true that it proved to be very constructive. If there was any ill will about the Committee's origins, that was never reflected in its business and the way its members conducted themselves in its hearings and deliberations. Perhaps that should be said at this point.

I appreciate very much the way we functioned as a committee. I think it would be appropriate to ascribe at least some of that to the chair, Senator Colston. In thanking him, it seems to be now voguish to add my congratulations to his succession to high office. I also thank my colleagues on the Committee. In particular, I thank the very hard working secretariat: Neil Bessell, the secretary; Dr Brian Sanderson and Mr Doug Hynd, the research officers; and Mrs Ros Franklin, the executive assistant. I know that those of us who have ever worked on committees appreciate the services provided by secretariats. But I place that on record for anyone who is listening and may not know just how demanding the work of a secretariat is. I would particularly like to thank them.

While I appreciated the assistance from all those people, honourable senators will shortly understand why I particularly make reference to Mrs Ros Franklin. This was not a high profile inquiry for women and that is a bit of a shame. So I was delighted to be able to wink at Mrs Ros Franklin from time to time when we both clearly understood the issues. I then proceeded to gently suggest a different view or perspective to some of my colleagues on the Committee. I would particularly like to highlight those aspects. I do so not because the others are not very vital issues-they certainly are-but I think they have been already very well canvassed by other speakers in this debate, including you, Mr Deputy President, Senator Brownhill, and Senator Coulter.

The reason I say that is that time and again-and I have already had an experience today along these lines in another committee in a different place-issues in our society that are regarded as very important or stern are perhaps neuter in terms of sex, but in the end `and women' is tacked on to them. So, economics is not a matter for women but, ultimately, one might have to look at the effects on them. Agricultural chemicals is not a matter for women, but in the end we might have to consider some specific effects on them. I must say that I find it very surprising to find that after all these years we are still talking about women and their involvement in the community as though they are a kind of adjunct to mainstream society.

In particular, in terms of economic recovery I read the wonderful line this morning-as I said, in another place-that the most important issue confronting a particular country is economic recovery, and that once that was in place we could then turn ourselves to the concerns of women. Where, may I ask, do we belong in terms of economic recovery? Do we not contribute to productivity? Do we not sometimes cost in terms of outlays? I cannot understand how we continue to have this thinking.

In particular, I am very pleased that groups representative of women, such as the Country Women's Association and a number of other people-men and women-made submissions in which they were at pains to bring to the Committee's attention the consequences of the use of chemicals on men and women and the important role played by men and women in their proper use.

I suppose I am always shocked-but, again, I was shocked at the committee meeting I attended this morning-to find that deformed children are more the responsibility and concern of women in our society. I still find that quite shocking. Why should it be so? We know that that would be a matter of the gravest concern and pain for the mother of a deformed child. I should imagine it is probably that way for the men and boys in such a family. But to keep on talking in this society as though deformed children, perhaps as a consequence of the use of chemicals, are really a woman's issue is really to miss the point. To the extent that there might be any thinking like that residing in Australia, it is time it ceased. This report goes a long way to saying that that kind of thinking can no longer continue. I suppose-and I say this with somewhat of a wry smile, Mr Deputy President-that I could have perhaps pursued that with a little more rigour in the Committee, but it would be mere meanness even to make issue of it.

Environmental issues are critical issues for men and women in society. The use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals is a critical issue for men and women in our society, and this whole report has to be seen in that way. I emphasise that the various references to women throughout the Committee's report are not sops to that adjunct in our society called women.

They are, I think, perhaps in a good way, represented by the very first recommendation of the Committee, which is that the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988 be amended to include in the membership of the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council one member nominated by the Commonwealth Minister for Consumer Affairs to represent consumer interests. That is something we felt was very critical. That point was brought to the attention of the Committee in submissions and was certainly raised by members of the Committee.
I want to place on record recommendation 3, which states:
. . . that the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Consultative Committee include members from groups representing
* farmers;
* manufacturers, distributors and transporters;
* workers;
* veterinarians;
* consumers;
* environmentalists;
* other user groups; and government agencies.
The recommendation continues:

The Committee recommends that the composition of the consultative body should provide balanced representation of interest groups and individuals and should include a reasonable representation of women.
`Reasonable' here, I think, refers to the number, not to their capacity. Are there any other than reasonable women?

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—I thank Senator McKiernan. Of course there are not. I take his laugh to be assent. The matters referred to by previous speakers have touched on these points, but they are very important and I would like to highlight them. Some of the women from the Country Women's Association and the National Women's Consultative Council in their submissions to the inquiry made some very interesting points going, for example, to the labelling of products.

SPEECH.PARA: The first problem was whether all parcels of all sizes of any chemical are adequately labelled. According to the evidence, in some cases small parcels are very adequately labelled, while very large supplies of chemicals do not have anything like the same depth or highlighting of labelling. That labelling, of course, includes safe handling instructions.

The women asked, for example, whether or not labelling ought to include any instructions about disposal. One woman told us that her husband, going out to use chemical, was advised that for every packet of the chemical he should have a change of clothing so as to minimise the possibility of absorption through the skin. She asked what he was to do when he got home and, in particular, what she was to do with five sets of clothing soaked with a chemical. There were no instructions about how to wash them.

Many people on rural properties do not have access to a sewerage line, so the water runs either into some kind of sewerage system they have or onto the vegetable garden. The questions literally were, `Can we use the water from the washing machine to water our vegetables as we have done through time?'. The chemical instructions were silent on these matters. The question arises: Can we wash other clothes with these chemicals too? In case anyone should think this is to trivialise the issue, I think we have only to reflect on the consequences of Wittenoom.

The Wittenoom experience has been that many people who are now suffering from mesothelioma are the wives and children of miners, who could probably have come into contact with the asbestos fibres only through the process of domestic treatment of clothing, through laundry and so on. It is not a matter to be treated lightly.

Time and time again the Committee was confronted with the economics of this matter. We were told that if we impose all these restrictions, with too much labelling, too many restrictions and so on, this will become too expensive.

In reply the Committee and I say: Look at the Wittenoom example. What is the cost to individuals in terms of pain and suffering? What is the cost to consumers? What is the cost to this world? The cost to the shareholders of CSR Ltd is positively measurable at this point. There has been a long and disgraceful lag time before the consequences of continued contact with asbestos has been seen to be part of the equation.

The Committee was very concerned that the economic modelling should be looked at too. We cannot work only on the consequences that are obvious now. We have to consider the huge economic consequences of health problems and downtime due to illness.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate passed earlier today, the sitting of the Senate is suspended until 8 p.m.

—I had been speaking to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia, and I was first of all wanting to add my comments in support to those made in this place on this report by yourself as Chairman, Mr Deputy President, and by Senators Brownhill and Coulter to this point, and I would be surprised if Senator Panizza was not going to endorse most of those comments.

SPEECH.PARA: I had also made the point that this report is very important for any number of reasons, many of which had been canvassed by earlier speakers. But one of the points I wanted to raise was the importance of this report in terms of its effect and the involvement of it for women-not because I want, in any way, to trivialise the issue or, I suppose, because it is somewhat regrettable that I should have to worry that mentioning women in referring to a report like this might be seen as a possibility for trivialisation. Indeed, I was very delighted in making my earlier comments that when I mentioned the problem of how one washes clothes that are soaked with chemicals, Senator Patterson opposite wanted to say, `Well, of course, many people in rural Australia would run washing-machine water on to their vegetable garden'-and, indeed, just that very point had been raised as a matter of concern by the some of the women putting submissions and evidence before the inquiry. In fact, those are areas where labelling, in particular, and advice to users of chemicals is still insufficient and, of course, the Committee in its report made recommendations that those matters should be taken very seriously and addressed.

I had also canvassed the problem of the effect of such requirements on costs and mentioned that, in fact, many of the assessments of the value of a chemical take into account only the current day costs, because we do not yet have any sufficient model for costing in the complications, the ill health, the disease and death, for example, that may occur down time. But, lest I should be seen to consider costs in terms of only illness or sickness or disease-all of which I think are absolutely critical-I would like to say that, of course, as was already mentioned by Senator Coulter and others, this inquiry was born out of the problem confronting Australia with organochlorins in beef. Of course, that is another cost that has to be considered in the use of chemicals: the cost of loss of export dollars to this country and, of course, the loss in terms of land that cannot be used, if not forever, at least for a very long time until such chemicals that are very heavily present in the soil are wasted away or lost from that soil. So the costs and our economic models have to take into account long term or down-the-line consequences of the use of chemicals and, indeed, I would hope to see continuing research in this vital area taking those sorts of considerations into account.

I had also mentioned the problem of deformed children and how often such children are seen to be a women's issue. I do not believe that is really true of our whole society, but it is certainly the way it is represented, and it is still certainly the way in which it tends to be debated: that is, the main users of agricultural and veterinary chemicals do not seem to argue, in defence or in anxiety of the use of their chemicals, the consequences on such things as the normal birth of babies.

I wanted to turn, by way of concluding remarks, to some of our recommendations and comments about the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) and its involvement in the clearance of agricultural and veterinary chemicals, particularly in terms of the health consequences inasmuch as they can be reasonably assessed. The report says, at page 71:

For example, the Federated Association of Australian Housewives, Tasmania, was so concerned about recent decisions of the NHMRC that it recommended the establishment of an independent review board to evaluate the findings NHMRC. The Association had also called for an independent judicial inquiry or review of the NHMRC.
This was particular evidence in response to evidence given to us that betrayed a concern about, I suppose, a lack of confidence in the research data coming from the NHMRC.

It is important for anybody who might want to raise this not to take those remarks of mine as conclusive. I would urge them, if they are going to follow that point at all, to read all of the report, but particularly pages 71 and 72-and I do not want to read that all into the Hansard. But, in fact, the Committee concluded that the NHMRC, while it is doing a very adequate job, should certainly be encouraged, and we make recommendations for it to continue its research and that that research should be properly resourced.

But in fact the point I wanted to make, particularly in terms of the problem of ill health or deformities and so on that we have had much discussion of in the press over time, is what I would call the problem of the reverse onus of proof. In some ways, what is required of citizens is that they must prove that `the chemical'-whatever the chemical might be-is causal of those deformities. I think that at some stage we have to address the question of why we do not require the chemical company to prove that it is safe, that it ought not be a charge against the consumer or the parents or people in the society to prove it is causal. What we have to have is a return to what is, I think, the proper onus of proof-that is, that the chemical companies have to be able to prove it is safe.

But I think the Committee-and I would certainly want to agree with this-appreciated that it is very difficult to prove total safety, and we appreciated evidence given to us on that matter. Dr Black said:

It is not possible, under any circumstances, ever to demonstrate safety. One has to consider these matters in terms of hazard, relative hazard and the acceptability of risk. All chemicals, not just agricultural and veterinary chemicals, are potentially hazardous; and if they are to be used, one has to assess the toxicity of the substance and the way in which it is to be used, to arrive at an estimation of whether or not it is acceptable . . . it is not possible to prove . . . absolute safety under all conditions.
That is a quote from page 71 of our report. It is a lift from Dr Black's evidence. It is certainly not all that the Committee heard on this issue.

I would simply say that, if we are being asked-and I think it is reasonable that we should be asked and I think it is reasonable that we should accept that one cannot conclusively prove absolute safety-then at least we should be saying that it should not be a charge against citizens to absolutely prove cause. We should at least be able to settle for a reasonable likelihood of cause. But again, I would prefer to see the charge being put back against the chemical companies, rather than an onus on the consumers or citizens in this regard-not that this was something that was canvassed at great length during our hearings, but it certainly was an issue of concern. I think those consumer concerns were very much, as previous speakers have said, present in the minds of the Committee all the time during its hearings.

It is of considerable historical relevance, I suppose, that this inquiry did happen, notwithstanding the process of its birth that we have already alluded to, but there is an ever-increasing concern in the community about the safety of agricultural and veterinary chemicals-and about a lot of others besides. In fact, the Committee was concerned to take evidence about the allergenic properties of some of these chemicals and a variety of health issues concerned with their use. The important thing, I suppose, is to appreciate that we do have an individual response amongst humans to the use of chemicals, but this does not mean that claims by people that they are allergic to, or actually suffer ill health from being around such sprays should be dismissed as, one, a false claim or, two, not really very important because they are a very small percentage.

On those issues and the questions and concerns surrounding them we have made recommendations to be taken up by the NHMRC, and we would hope to see the consequences of our recommendations and, indeed, perhaps a response from the NHMRC over time.

Other issues that were broadly canvassed were the environmental issues. The relevance of this inquiry in a piece of history when environmental issues have suddenly and, I think, with great appreciation become a serious matter for consideration meant that we were very concerned to address those issues.

I could add to the remarks by Senator Brownhill about the concern the Committee had about the safe use of chemicals. We heard evidence from people who reported that drums which had contained chemicals-mostly empty, but certainly not necessarily washed out-were left on dumps, or put down one end of a property or perhaps even dropped in creeks. We appreciated that this was not necessarily the general practice in rural Australia, but it was a matter of considerable concern and the Committee wanted to give some serious thought to the matter of disposal of not only the chemicals but also the containers of those chemicals. Indeed, I think my colleague Senator Panizza not only offered to the Committee his own wisdom but also led-if I can use that word in the best sense-some of the witnesses to this very issue by his questions to them.

Senator Brownhill has also alluded to the concern we had about the use of chemicals to eliminate pests in houses around urban Australia. That is a matter of great concern. Very many private operators-we concluded from the evidence we were given-are not necessarily adequately trained or educated as to the proper use of the sprays they are using, not only in terms of safe use for the occupiers or those soon to be the occupiers of those households, but also for their own health and safety.

Not all of those people would insist on covering themselves with protective clothing. Many of them seemed to be at pains to say, `It is perfectly safe; I have never been sick'. The Committee was concerned that such bravado should not persist, and that there is considerable evidence that the chemicals may be very dangerous not only to the householders, as I say, but also to the users.

We have recommended that there be training and education programs for the providers and for the companies providing those chemicals to spray in households. But I want to say, perhaps even more sternly than Senator Brownhill, that the Committee was of the view that, if self-regulation was not instituted and was not able to be seen to be effective, clearly further regulation in the industry would have to happen-not necessarily because we believe in regulations or because it is a good thing, but because, much more seriously, one would want to consider the questions I was raising earlier about the long term implications of the use of these chemicals for health and illness and their cost.

In closing, while many of us might have had a doubt about why this inquiry should have happened, like many inquiries in this place it does give substance to the value of an inquiry, being as comprehensive and, I think, useful as it is. I certainly think it is a very useful document for anybody with any kind of concern and, certainly, any interest in this area. I suppose it will join those volumes on the shelves of either government printing offices or the offices of members of parliament-and, no doubt, other relevant places-as an excellent reference, an up to date review, of the process of regulation, testing and assessment of the chemicals in agricultural and veterinary areas, along with the recommendations that we have proposed.

I will be very interested to see the Government's response to these recommendations. It has been a useful inquiry. I think it is very useful extra resource material in this area, and I certainly believe that those in the community who have a concern about things environmental, and about the use of chemicals, will find it an excellent extra resource.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia, I would like to add my remarks to those made about this report and briefly touch on things dealt with during the inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I get on to that, I would like to delve into the past and examine the reasons that we started this inquiry. I would add that the members of this Committee certainly worked well together over the period and in the different places we visited. At no time was there any attempt at political point scoring, except for this evening when my friend Senator Coulter tried to shift all the credit for this inquiry on to Senator Powell. He advised us that it was totally due to the Australian Democrats' efforts, and their efforts alone, that this inquiry got up.
To put the record straight, I will now read a motion from this side of politics that was moved on 15 December 1987 by Senator Lewis. The motion stated:

1. That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Agricultural Chemicals, be appointed to inquire into and report upon regulation by governments of the sale and use of agricultural chemicals in the beef industry, the use of such chemicals by governmental instrumentalities and questions of compensation and assistance for growers.
2. That provision for the composition and powers of the committee be contained in a subsequent resolution.

On that same day a motion was moved by Senator Powell along the lines of this inquiry. Those two motions sat around for six months until 19 April 1988. I can tell you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that the only reason why that one got going on 19 April 1988 was that the Government needed numbers on some other Bill and, because the Australian Democrats were able to supply those numbers, they got this inquiry up on their terms. So much for that. On that basis, I think I have put the record straight.

I will now go back to the reasons for this inquiry. I think it was spelled out in the terms of reference. It was because of the pesticides in beef which caused consternation and loss of sales to the United States of America. It mainly affected the beef growers in the south-west of Western Australia. I know that Senator Knowles was down there and did a lot of work with them.

The biggest problems seemed to come from the fact that much of the pesticide found in beef was a residue of dichlorodiphenyl-trichloroethane (DDT) that was used in the horticultural industry a number of years ago. In fact, in some places DDT had not been used for horticulture for nearly 25 years, yet it was there.

It has always been my belief that DDT had that big build-up because of its cheap price at the time. There was a certain lack of proper controls when it was applied. It was cheap and it was just fed into the irrigation lines instead of being applied through ordinary spraying, and that is how it got a big build-up. There was a great loss to farmers in that area and, I believe, in Victoria as well to a certain extent, so we decided to ask for an inquiry.

I know that the compensation clause in our motion did not get up-it was not accepted by the Government-but that does not mean the problem is not still there. In fact, today there is a problem with a farming couple in the south-west of Western Australia-I think around Donnybrook. Public instrumentalities used this chemical-whether it was Telecom or the State Energy Commission, I am not aware-and when it was used by them it infiltrated the ground. Although that couple did not lose their herd altogether, it was impounded for quarantine and it cost them I do not know how many dollars to put right.

The point is that there was an inquiry in Western Australia because that couple tried to get reasonable damages from the instrumentality that was responsible. There was an inquiry by the State Government, and after that the State Government Insurance Office declined to pay out, but this couple could never get hold of the report, and it is still doubtful whether they should not have been paid. In other words, I believe they had a case. Unfortunately, there will be no freedom of information in Western Australia until the legislation is passed there. It is about to come before the Parliament but, Premier Lawrence tells us, it will not be retrospective. The problem regarding full compensation still exists in some parts of Australia. The Government could look at the idea.

I know that many things have already been said about this report, but in the short time available to me, I will go briefly through a few points. Chemicals are an important part of the Australian economy, not only because they are used on the crops-I will come to that matter in a moment-but also by virtue of their manufacture.

In 1987, $457m worth of agricultural chemicals were sold and $189m worth of veterinary chemicals were sold. In 1988, when we started this inquiry, sales of agricultural chemicals had risen to $547m and sales of veterinary chemicals had risen to $249m. I can quite easily explain why the sales of agricultural chemicals rose. It occurred because of the very wet season earlier that year, which meant that more pre-emergent sprays were applied, so more chemicals were sold. I have no idea why the sale of veterinary chemicals rose by approximately $61m in 12 months.

Those figures show that chemicals are an important manufacturing commodity in Australia. By the same token, their biggest value lies in the extra production they help farmers achieve. If farm chemicals were not used, 30 per cent of the world's agricultural production would be lost in addition to the 20 per cent to 40 per cent that is lost already because chemicals are not used. Chemicals certainly form an integral part of any farming system, especially in grain growing, where they are most important of all. They are especially important in land conservation, which is a major issue these days.

There is a trend towards minimum cultivation in the grain growing areas. It is virtually impossible to have a clean crop with minimum cultivation and without chemicals. Should one try to eliminate the chemicals, whether for pre-emergent or post-emergent, one has to turn back to intensive cultivation, which means more stirring of the soil. This requires more use of fuel which, with current world events, may turn out to be a scarcer commodity than we think. The Committee accepted that in recommendation 28. We spoke on page 117 of the value of chemicals, both to the manufacturing sector and to production.
Recommendations 2 and 3 are also very important. These were part of our terms of reference. Recommendation 2 states:
. . . that the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988-
which we have not long ago put into force-
be amended to establish an Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Consultative Committee.
This Committee would include representatives from different groups so as to get a wide cross-section of people involved. Recommendation 3 states:
. . . that the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Consultative Committee include members from groups representing
* farmers;
* manufacturers, distributors and transporters;
* workers;
* veterinarians;
* consumers;
* environmentalists;
* other user groups; and-
I do not know who the other groups would be-
* government agencies.

That shows that this Committee accepted many submissions from many people to cover as wide a range as we could. We got people involved so that they could have a say as to how chemicals would be used in the future.

I will briefly refer to recommendations 29 and 31. These relate to efficacy of non-chemical management systems. There is an encouragement to people to get away from chemicals. The very high price of chemicals does encourage people to cut down on their use. That in itself tends to keep down the quantity of chemicals used, or to stop their overuse.

As I mentioned earlier, I think there was a DDT build-up because it was too cheap. Recommendations 29 and 31 aim for a reduction of chemical use and to turn to organic farming. My best wishes and good luck go to those who want to use organic farming. The Australian Democrats seem to prefer organic farming. Unfortunately, with the way our soils are and because of our rainfall, it will be a mighty long time before organic farming can be profitable in Australia.

Various groups that spoke to us recommended giving certain incentives to undertake measures. I certainly believe in incentives by encouragement, research and the use of Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) findings. But I certainly do not go along with taxing some producers in order to give the others a handout to help them on their way and have them compete with conventional producers.

Senator Crowley mentioned the disposal of containers. The problem of empty chemical containers has been around as long as I have had anything to do with local government. A certain amount of money was always available in Western Australia to develop a vehicle with a machine on it to crush empty containers, get them into smaller sections and then properly dispose of them. But that has never been done.

That problem will pass fairly soon because there is a push into concentrated crystal-type chemicals in small containers. Madam Acting Deputy President, you yourself may know that because of your agricultural background. One particular chemical used as a post-emergent on crops comes in a container about 15 centimetres high. Each container has enough chemical to cover about 50 hectares of crop, thus eliminating the necessity to use at least four 20-litre drums. If there is any crystal left, it can be destroyed by being burnt in a proper made-up area measuring one metre by one metre. Even on big farms the containers can be burnt for the next 30 years.

I know that the chemical companies, encouraged by the CSIRO and the different departments of agriculture, are heading that way. I can assure Senator Crowley that fortunately we are well on the way to solving the problem that she mentioned.

In conclusion, I consider that in years to come we will find that this has been a worthwhile report. We do have a long way to go. We have received all the submissions and have put all these recommendations in place. I certainly hope that the Government will consider them and act on them. It will have to be an ongoing inquiry-not by this Committee; this Committee will wind up-to make sure that things stay on track. We have had problems in the past. There were problems because of the overuse of chemicals, problems with meat not being tested before it left Australia and problems in aerial application.

I was interested in the submission from the cotton growing industry with which I had had nothing to do before joining this committee. They are using helicopters, aeroplanes and drop-jet boom sprays in their activities across the country. I believe that with this report and the other legislation we brought in in 1988 it will make it easier to register chemicals in a centralised way. We also now have more knowledge of the side effects of agricultural chemicals.

I return to my earlier comments that this inquiry was commenced because of the discovery of pesticides in beef exported to the United States. At that time I said, and I still say, that this issue was a scaremongering tactic by certain unknown people to damage our trade with the United States. I spent 16 days in the United States. Recently I looked at the beef industry in the mid-West where the biggest feed lots in the world are located. I spoke with the packagers during that visit. The people I spoke with did not remember, until I mentioned it, the issue of pesticides in the beef imported from Australia. However, they did remember the kangaroo meat that was exported with beef. That episode does not seem to have been forgotten. The packagers asked me when we were going to stop exporting kangaroo meat in that way. I told them that I always believed that that was done as a sabotage move. If the farmers and the packagers in the mid-West knew about the pesticides in Australian beef, they certainly have forgotten it now. All they remembered was the kangaroo meat scandal.

I would like to conclude my remarks by congratulating the chairman of the Committee, Senator Colston, and thank him for the impartial way in which he conducted this inquiry. He is a chairman who always gave other Committee members adequate time to question the witnesses rather than to take control of the questioning himself. I was very impressed with his chairmanship. In his absence, I congratulate him on his election to the position of Deputy President of the Senate. I express my thanks for the cooperation that I received from other members of the Committee. I look forward in the future to working on some other committee which will look at the improvement in the use of chemicals in Australia for the betterment of all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words about the report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia. I congratulate the Committee on what it has reported. I consider that it is a very balanced report that vindicates the continued constructive use of chemicals in Australian agriculture. It is certainly a rebuke to those in the Australian community and those senators who may from time to time espouse the view that agricultural and veterinary chemicals are somehow harmful per se.

SPEECH.PARA: It is sensible for the report to recommend that consumer interests be represented together with agricultural, veterinary and environmental groups on an agricultural and veterinary chemicals council. Other recommendations of considerable significance call for expeditious evaluation of chemical and veterinary products, for review of clearance procedures, for expansion of monitoring of chemical residues and also for the monitoring of international developments in this area so as to be forewarned before problems arise with agricultural trade.

I strongly endorse these particular findings as I am very conscious of the losses that were borne by farmers in my State of Western Australia who had followed all proper advice and direction in their previous use of chemicals to discover that they were bearing the cost of an unacceptable level of residue in beef exports. It is to be hoped that those recommendations designed to prevent the recurrence of this situation will be put into effect as soon as possible. We certainly do not want a repeat of a situation where DDT and dieldrin, prohibited in the United States in the early 1970s, were not banned in Australia until 1987.

It was a shame tonight that Senator Coulter had to distort some of the facts coming from Western Australia, alleging misuse of chemicals. He suggested that the community had been advised that the chemicals had been withdrawn. In fact, they had not been advised until many years later.

In October 1988, when the Senate was debating the establishment of this inquiry, I expressed concern on behalf of Western Australian agricultural producers that the terms of such an inquiry might encourage a negative witch-hunt against the use of agricultural chemicals in general. Today I am glad that this report has not done so.

Central to the report are the conclusions in chapter 9, that agricultural chemicals contribute significantly to the production of quality food and fibre and alleviate suffering in animals. I think it is important that one should dwell on that because it is a very critical part of a very positive report. The use of these chemicals `is an important tool in an integrated approach to pest management'. These balanced statements refute extremist and alarmist suggestions that agricultural and veterinary chemicals are a blanket threat to health and should somehow be dispensed with.

I note that there are senators in this chamber who have that opinion and I encourage them most sincerely to read this report because that might enlighten them about what is best not only for the agricultural producers in this country but also for Australia as a whole.

Chapter 9 also summarises valuable evidence supplied by the National Farmers Federation, concluding that the world demand for food would accelerate from 1995 to 2025 and that Australian farmers had already moved their emphasis from gross output to production efficiency.

The Senate should also note the evidence from the Bureau of Rural Resources that if farm chemicals were not used, 30 per cent of world agricultural production would be lost together with the 20 to 40 per cent already lost through weeds, pests and diseases. It should be understood that withdrawal of chemicals would badly affect the quality as well as the quantity of production. With our balance of payments and current debt crisis, quite frankly that is the last thing we can afford.

There will be widespread support also for the conclusions of chapter 13 regarding the economic benefit of agricultural chemicals, and the need for quantitative assessment of their impact. As a senator for Western Australia I take special note of the fact quoted in paragraph 13.34 that the failure to use herbicides would reduce the State's wheat harvest by 32 per cent through competition with wild oats, by 24 per cent from barley grass and 8 to 20 per cent from rye grass. Uninformed critics of agricultural chemicals should be more conscious of such facts and remember also that within two years of ceasing chemical control Australia would lose the entirety of its export apple market worth $206m in 1988. That is yet another thing that I do not believe Australia can afford to lose. They should also read paragraph 13.22, that reports the statement of the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations that the use of pesticides has benefited consumers through reduced livestock losses, reduced pest damage to crops, lower per unit production costs and longer shelf life. These are all positive aspects.

The Government now has the responsibility to act on these sensible recommendations, the implementation of which will protect the livelihood of producers, the export trade, public health and the environment. The Government also has a duty to ensure that the balanced view of the overall use of chemicals as presented by this report prevails over irresponsible and unsubstantiated attacks on the proper utilisation of chemicals in agriculture. Not least, it is pleasing to see that the Committee has rejected the bureaucratic option of licensing all users of these chemicals. That would be a really retrograde step. Correctly, the option of improved education and training is preferred. Had proper information been available to Australian farmers before the 1987 crisis, I am convinced that those problems would not have arisen. I congratulate the chairman, the deputy chairman and the Committee members on this excellent report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address a few remarks to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals. As one who was not present at the time, it is interesting for me to watch several speakers now falling over themselves to take credit for the establishment of this Committee. That indicates to me that the Committee's work is acknowledged to be worthwhile and that it is work worth being associated with. Whatever the permutations, combinations and strategies employed to bring it about, as Senator Panizza reminded us a short time ago, the inquiry was established on Australian Democrats' terms.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome this report because, as was mentioned by several previous speakers, the Australian beef industry was under real threat in 1987 and the residues in export meat had created international problems for Australian farmers. The response by the Democrats, through Senator Powell, was to move a motion in this chamber that the Senate Select Committee which has prepared this report should be established. Whatever tactics were employed, it was established.

In the opinion of the Democrats, excessive use of chemicals damages our resource base, our soil and our water, not to mention the potential hazards they create for farmers and their families. An inquiry was long overdue. But it was important to the Democrats that that Committee should focus on issues which were broader than just the beef pesticides residues crisis, and that it should look specifically at the wider social, economic and environmental consequences of chemicals.

Many might say that the Committee merely scratched the surface of the issues that it was charged to examine. For example, those people affected by drift from chemical spraying in north-western Tasmania are saying that the Committee should have recommended against aerial spraying. However, the Democrats are satisfied that the conduct of this inquiry was worth while.

The Committee has recommended that the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988 be amended to include a representative of consumer interests on the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council and that an agricultural and veterinary chemicals consultative committee should be established. Moreover, it has recommended that this committee should include members from various groups, including environmentalists and a reasonable representation of women. We wholeheartedly support those recommendations.

The Committee has made a number of important recommendations concerning the system regulating the introduction, monitoring and use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. It noted that more and better disseminated information was needed. It recommended an improvement in the labelling of chemicals and that the feasibility of a comprehensive system of reporting industrial exposure to chemicals be established.

The Committee has noted that increasing numbers of farmers are converting to organic methods of farming, and has recommended that further research and development of organic farming methods and sustainable agricultural systems be undertaken. The Democrats particularly welcome the recommendation to assess the overseas market prospects for organic produce.

However, the Committee found a serious lack of data about the impact of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. The Committee was surprised that an overall quantitative assessment of the impact of farm chemicals on Australia had not been undertaken already. The Committee was not able to assess the social impact of chemicals, although it did recognise that the community holds serious and well-founded concerns about the long term effects of pesticides on human health.

Perhaps the Committee's most important recommendations concern the need for further assessment surveys and research into the economic, social and environmental impacts of the use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. Again, as Senator Panizza has said, that indicates that the work of this Committee-not so much the Committee itself-should be continued, and the numerous sorts of research that should be undertaken might branch out into a variety of responsibilities for a variety of other committees or government instrumentalities.

If the recommendations of this Committee are acted upon, they will involve the Department of Community Services and Health, the National Health and Medical Research Council, the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council, the Department of the Primary Industries and Energy and the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association Task Force. The Australian Democrats welcome these recommendations and will work to ensure that they are fully implemented. The findings of the Committee fully vindicate Senator Powell's concern when she first called for the inquiry two years ago.

This report gives us yet again compelling evidence that as a society we do not monitor our products, processes and institutions very well. In fact, the report shows us that we are very prone to introducing models, processes and products without fully testing their effects. As the Democrats spokesperson on primary industry, I will be fully monitoring the impact of this report. The gaps, defects and concerns that it identifies are far too serious for us to ignore.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has submitted the report on Annual Reports. In accordance with the resolution of the Senate of 14 December 1989, I present the Second President's Report on Annual Reports.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the Public Service Act, I present the annual report of the Department of the Senate for 1989-90.

INTERJECT.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I will be very brief, but I wish to record a couple of views about the annual report of the Department of the Senate. It illustrates the continuing enhancement of the provisions in respect of the Department of the Senate, but it inexorably leads one to recognise the intrinsic and unique role of the Senate in the Parliamentary process. It raises the fundamental question, which I notice is also before us today in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing, concerning the funding of the Senate.

In this chamber we are confronted with those who have a very strong and passionate view that the Senate ought in some way to be subjugated by government and the House of Representatives, and through the House of Representatives the Speaker, until we are but an addendum to the functioning of the parliamentary system. A strong strain of opinion runs through a part of the Australian Labor Party that the bicameral system is not appropriate and that the Senate is an anachronism.

Can I just record the view, which I put before with some vigour, that the Senate has to maintain its intrinsic right to assess and establish for itself its own level of funding, its own requirements, its own obligations and its own responsibilities. If any member of this chamber who cares in any way for the functioning and responsibilities of this Parliament is not cognisant of the attempts to reduce not only the integrity but also the autonomy of this Parliament, he is doing less than his responsibility. It is not without significance to note the increasing role that the Senate has played in the process of the Parliament in the last two decades.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —-On behalf of the President, pursuant to standing order 19, I present the annual report for 1989-90 of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing.

INTERJECT.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Again, with brief eloquence, let me say that this report, in its two or three pages, summarises some of the problems and disparate views that have been held by the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing. It is not without significance as I read this report to be reminded that it now has a new member in the form of Senator Walsh, who replaces somebody less distinguished. I cannot remember who it is. I am sorry, I hope I am not being uncharitable or unkind to any honourable senator from the other side. Oh, yes, it is the honourable senator from Tasmania, the little man with the grey hair, Senator Coates. I have moments when I look at Senator Walsh and I am refreshed to see him there and then I have memories of his previous performances from time to time and I miss Senator Coates, so it is the curate's egg.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to talk about the report at all?

—If the Minister can just hold his breath for a second or two longer I will do exactly that. I do not want to overplay the significance of Senator Walsh being on the Committee, but it really is germane to this whole debate about this Committee. Senator Walsh has always held the view that it is not the Parliament and it is not the Senate that are entitled to make appropriations in respect to the funding for the Senate. Senator Walsh has always had the view that the Executive Government has exclusive power and responsibility for determining the level of funding and, tied to that, the capacity and the ability of the Senate to fulfil its obligations and responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a time when the Stuart kings held pretty much the same sort of view which was that the level of capacity for democracy to function in a proper way was exclusively dictated by the king of the day. In other words, if the king cut the funding off, he cut off the Parliament, and if the Parliament is cut off, then one cuts off what was purported to be the human face of democracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —So they cut off his head.

—Yes, they cut off his head, that is absolutely right. I am reminded of one occasion where the Australian Democrats had the audacity to move for a select committee, and Senator Walsh said, `If you persist with that proposition I will ensure you do not have adequate funding to pursue the select committee'. He saw that as a frolic of the Democrats-not a view I shared. But on sober reflection after the events of the last couple of days I am starting to wonder whether Senator Walsh has been a bit compelling in his arguments and I have not been objective enough in accepting the point of view he has been putting forward.

SPEECH.PARA: If one accepts that governments can decide exclusively the required levels of funding, then one has to accept that they can decide what the role and responsibility of the Senate ought to be, and that is what Senator Walsh says. It is a view articulated with less clarity, but I think with the same vigour, as the majority of the members of the Australian Labor Party. I shall watch with some interest over the coming period to see whether the members of the Democrats on the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing have the vigour and the competence to ensure that the funding for the Senate is not hijacked.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will.
—That is not something that I noticed in the last few days as a top of the mind agenda item.
—You should have looked at our alternative Budget.
—After I got past the first $30 billion, I have got to say that I just got down to other issues.
—That's your problem.

—It is not my problem. The one political party that obtains the greatest benefit from the Senate having proper funding is the Democrats. If Senator Spindler had read the Hansard of two days ago when Senator Coates was suggesting that there should not be some continuity of some resolutions, it was Senator Colston for whom the Democrats voted and who argued against my proposition. Perhaps with a bit more experience some of those things might be looked at so that blind prejudice and bias does not influence all their judgments.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the responsibilities of the Appropriations and Staffing Committee is to ensure that there are no significant or consequential changes in terms of the responsibilities of the Department of the Senate. It is mentioned in this report that there was a transfer of the Parliamentary Information Systems Office (PISO) to the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff. That was undertaken without proper consultation with the Appropriations and Staffing Committee.

I have written to the President because I understand that there is some suggestion that there ought to be an amalgamation of certain services and responsibilities by at least three of the departments in terms of their administrative rearrangements. The President assures me that it is not an initiative of his or the Speaker's but rather an initiative of the departmental heads. That is a matter that I intend to pursue. I want to satisfy myself that the Presiding Officers are not unilaterally and independent of departments directing the Department of the Parliamentary Library or Hansard or any other department that they shall have an amalgamation.

The present matter is that of corporate services. The President has absolutely reassured me that a commitment he gave at a recent meeting of the Appropriations and Staffing Committee was still in place.
I wish to make one final observation, that is, that I notice Senator Coates has an absurd motion before us-that certain resolutions showing in the Standing Orders should not be of an ongoing nature.

TALK.START.PARA: —He withdrew it this morning.

—I am grateful for that because Senator Coates was seeking to obliterate the resolution of former Senator Georges, Australian Labor Party, left wing, Queensland, who moved in general terms that there be no changes to the responsibilities or duties of any of the parliamentary departments without the approval of the Senate. PISO was transferred into Hansard from the Library without consultation of even a modest nature. In my view, that flies in the face of the resolution of Senator George Georges, as he then was. If we obliterate that resolution on a continuing basis, we then allow the Executive to do as it will with the parliamentary departments.

SPEECH.PARA: All Senator Coates would need to do is to seduce the Australian Democrats and the resolution could not be carried back in the Senate again. With respect, it has to be an ongoing resolution, totally practical. Senator Coates suggests that there are a number of those resolutions that should not be ongoing. To sustain that argument we have to do away with the capacity of the Senate to have privilege, to be able to call witnesses, to subpoena documents and, in other words, to fulfil its normal obligations. I am pleased to hear from the Whip, Senator Margaret Reid, that that motion has been withdrawn.

I conclude by saying that this year for the first time we have established a baseline figure, on recommendation by the Committee, for a suitable appropriation for the Senate. The report concludes that it is not a satisfactory criteria, it is not a satisfactory figure, and that in due course it will require a change. The great difficulty in establishing a baseline figure for the Department of the Senate is that, because we moved from the old Parliament House to the new House, there is no normal average criteria that can be drawn as to the requirements of the Senate. The Department of Finance, and Senator Walsh in particular, have sought to claim that by now we should have a baseline figure. There is still one inherent difficulty in all this-that is, in terms of new items there is no provision in the baseline figure.

The report goes on to say somewhere amongst its words that the Appropriations and Staffing Committee unanimously does not accept the figure as a necessarily appropriate figure. It points out that there is no natural process for new items. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
