TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, in accordance with the provisions of section 81 of the Reserve Bank Act 1959, I present the report of the Reserve Bank of Australia Board on the operations of the Bank, together with financial statements and the report of the Auditor-General for the financial year 1989-90.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report is astounding. It is astounding on several grounds. Firstly, it is astounding the way this year's report has been sanitised compared to the report that appeared last year. Last year's report was an honest, straightforward and very detailed criticism of the Government's economic policy. There has since been a change at the top of the Reserve Bank of Australia, a change which was very controversial and a change which involved the Secretary to the Treasury being taken from Canberra and pushed into this job, pushing aside the senior people in the Reserve Bank who had every right to expect that they had a reasonable chance of becoming the chief officer of that Bank.

I am quite frankly appalled at the collapse of the independence of the Reserve Bank revealed in this report. No longer do we have a Reserve Bank that is prepared to criticise this Government in the terms of last year's report. Instead, under the ex-Secretary to the Treasury we have exactly the sort of acquiescence to the Government's failed economic policies that one would expect from someone who has worked so closely with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in creating those policies. Every fear that was expressed in this chamber about the consequences of this appointment to the Reserve Bank have now been realised. I will deal with that in some detail later.

Firstly, however, I want to deal with another specific matter relating to the Reserve Bank's involvement in the collapse of the Pyramid Building Society. We had the most extraordinary Question Time incident today when Senator Button, when asked a very clear, direct, uncomplicated question, answered it in a way which was totally in conflict with the way in which exactly the same question was answered by the Treasurer. Senator Button said that neither the Government nor he as a Minister knew of any financial difficulties relating to Pyramid prior to 13 February-when, the Senate will remember, a joint press statement was issued by the Victorian Treasurer and the Attorney-General stating that deposits in the Pyramid Building Society were secure. I remind the Senate that 13 February was some five weeks before the Federal election, in which, I might also remind the Senate, the Labor Party was so on the nose in Victoria that the coalition won nine seats.
Having set that time scale, let us go over the question again. The Minister was asked:
Was he or the Government aware of the financial difficulties of Pyramid prior to 13 February . . .?

Senator Button said no. He corrected that later on, after Senator Hill had asked a subsequent question pointing out that Mr Keating, in the other place, had given a very different reply altogether and had in fact indicated that he had been informed as events unfolded and that dealings did take place at officials level on this matter, clearly before the statement on 13 February.

The answer to another question asked of the Treasurer revealed that contacts had been through the Reserve Bank and that the Reserve Bank had cleared those sections of the Victorian Government's extraordinary statement that related to elements of concern to the Reserve Bank. The Treasurer went on, as I understand it, to say that, while the Government and the Reserve Bank had been informed of developments, they did not advise or write the statement.

There is no doubt that it was a political advantage to the Labor Party-though not sufficiently politically advantageous to prevent it from losing nine seats-that its monumental incompetence in managing the financial environment in Victoria-including institutions such as building societies, which are under the so-called regulations of an incompetent administration, should not become known before the Federal election on 24 March. It was in the Labor Party's best interests that any such disaster as Pyramid should not appear before that date.

We had the statement on 13 March saying that all was well, at a time when, it has become evident, all was not well, when the supervising authorities-the Victorian State Government-should have been capable of recognising that all was not well, and when it appears there was evidence that the Commonwealth was aware one way or another, through either its officials or its Reserve Bank, that all was not well with the Pyramid Building Society.

It is very interesting to read the Reserve Bank report on this issue because the Reserve Bank has a way of dealing with the trading banks. It draws things to their attention. It never actually tells them what to do specifically; it `reminds' them or `advises' them; but this is Reserve Bank `slanguage' for what is, in effect, a direction.

It is interesting to note that on page 38 of the Reserve Bank Report and Financial Statements, 30 June 1990 there was some discussion of the role of the Reserve Bank when non-bank financial institutions experience difficulties, as, of course, has occurred to excess, basically in States other than New South Wales, where that Government has exercised in the main a far more effective control over institutions such as building societies than the Victorian Labor Government appears capable of undertaking.
As I said, I draw attention to sections of the Reserve Bank annual report. It says:

. . . if banks decide, on the basis of their commercial judgements, to provide short-term liquidity support to a non-bank financial institution in need and in so doing run short of liquidity themselves, the Reserve Bank would fully support those banks.
It goes on:
While the Bank-
that is, the Reserve Bank-
does not expect banks to provide support to others against their own commercial judgments-
and I stress this next part-
it does expect them-
that is, the trading banks-
to respond sympathetically to requests for liquidity assistance from otherwise soundly based institutions; this has been longstanding policy.
I stress the last paragraph, which says:
The Bank has reminded banks of this position in recent months when some building societies in Victoria came under pressure.

I think the Senate is entitled to ask-and I believe the Reserve Bank and the Government should answer-whether or not that is bank language for the Reserve Bank in fact having asked trading banks to help Pyramid out of a mess in the run-up to the Federal election. That is the inference in this statement.

It may well be that the Reserve Bank did not know how deep the problem was at Pyramid. It may be that the Victorian Government's capacity to provide any kind of effective supervision of non-bank financial intermediaries is so slight that it had no knowledge of the fact that it was a sinking ship. But there is real concern here, I believe, that the Reserve Bank may well have encouraged banks-if one interprets its particular form of language-to tide over Pyramid, whether or not Pyramid was headed for the rocks.

I would be all in favour of the Reserve Bank and the banking system seeking to protect the interests of the 200,000-odd depositors in Pyramid. Had they been capable of being rescued, I believe that everything should have been done to try to rescue them. However, there is a clear dividing line, I believe, between trying to rescue and making efforts to protect the interests of 220,000 depositors on the one hand and trying to paper over a crack for political purposes on the other.

I cannot tell what was in fact going on at the time. All that is clearly evident is that this Government or its officers knew that, at the time the statement was made on 13 February, people's deposits with the Pyramid Building Society were secure. At that time Federal authorities of one kind or another knew there were problems at Pyramid. The Government and the Reserve Bank had better tell us how much they knew of those problems because, if they have stood by and allowed a false statement to be made by Victorian Labor politicians, then they are culpable.

This raises some other interesting questions about the extent to which the Treasurer himself either was advised or should have been advised at an official level about the nature of this problem. I remind the Senate that the Secretary to the Treasury is in fact on the Reserve Bank board. I do not know to what extent he would report to the Treasurer any knowledge, if he had it, of this situation. It is interesting to note that the Treasurer in his answers in the other place did indicate some knowledge of Pyramid's problems prior to 13 February-I repeat, the time the statement came out saying that deposits were safe.

It may be that the statements of the Treasurer and Senator Button were in conflict because once again the Treasurer did not speak to John Button. There is nothing new about that. Perhaps in this case Senator Button could feel a bit aggrieved because, had the Treasurer told Senator Button, maybe Senator Button would not have been in the situation of losing his money in Pyramid. Looking at the statement of pecuniary interests of Ministers, I note that Senator Button was unfortunately a depositor in the Pyramid Building Society. I hope his political judgment is better than his financial judgment. He has not shown much evidence of that, but I still retain that hope.

It seems to me extraordinary that if there were problems emerging the Treasurer would not have known about them and would not have drawn them to the attention of his Government. After all, this has been a major disaster, not in terms of a huge failure of some big entrepreneur but because it affected 220,000 depositors.

I now want to turn to another matter that relates to the nature of the economic comment in this report. I hope that Senator Short, who has a great interest in this matter, will be following my remarks in this area. I find it quite remarkable that this annual report manages to be objective about the mess this Government has got us into in a way which looks like beating Mr Keating with a feather duster.

Following last year's report, which I must say was a revelation in terms of the freedom that the Reserve Bank felt it had to comment on the wrong direction, the lack of action, the failures of the Keating economic policy to do the fundamental things that are required for this nation, all we get this year is that the Reserve Bank is disappointed. Actually, it is disappointed twice. It is disappointed on page 13 because it found `the balance of payments outcome in 1989-90 was disappointing'. In other words, it was a major muck-up by the Treasurer, a huge mistake, a clear collapse of policy, an absolute failure. The Reserve Bank, under its new direction, rouses itself to a frenzy of disappointment. In the context of its preparedness to criticise the very thrust of Government policy last year, this frenzy of disappointment is a pathetic and sanitised response-sanitised by an inappropriate appointment to the leadership of the Reserve Bank.

By the way, I understand that the Button who is on the list of investors in Pyramid is Senator Button's wife rather than Senator Button. To that extent, I apologise to Senator Button. I certainly hope that our wives' activities are not matters for which senators are automatically responsible.

The balance of payments outcome in 1989-90 was disappointing, according to the Reserve Bank. It then sets out in the report this year to undermine the very sound point last year that the Reserve Bank had made about the balance of payments and how having a high interest rate policy was exactly the wrong thing to do to resolve the balance of payments problem. I remind the Senate of what the Reserve Bank said last year. It said:
In fact . . . there may be perverse effects on the balance of payments if higher interest rates produce an exchange rate appreciation.
It then went on:

On its own, monetary policy will not produce the longer-term structural benefits Australia is seeking. Beyond a point, it may even inhibit the structural change because of the effect of high interest rates on investment of all types.

Let us take the way this report seeks to undermine those very clear and sensible comments last year. The Reserve Bank report this year, in another point about `following another little bit of a disappointment', found:
The rates of increase in prices and wages remained disappointingly high in 1989-90.

Disappointingly high? The previous report, by the way, said it was absolutely vital, that it was imperative that there be a return to progress in reducing both the rate of inflation and the current account deficit in the current year. What was imperative last year was not met. The Government failed, and what has the Reserve Bank found? This year it is a bit disappointing. This wimpish, sanitised report is a disgrace. Let us go on to see how it in fact seeks to undermine conclusions in last years report. The Reserve Bank goes on in this year's report:
After the initial tightening of monetary policy to counter these inflationary pressures, the exchange rate rose and this may have increased imports somewhat.
Darn right it did! Now get this:
However, the increase in imports . . .
In last year's report it was shown as a perverse impact and meant we did not achieve objectives. This year it is described as . . .
. . . an important safety value during this time increasing supply and limiting domestic inflationary pressures.

In other words, because the Government so mishandled the economy, it was a useful device, according to the Reserve Bank, this year that that demand could flow out into imports and so worsen our balance of payments, the very thing-reduction of the balance of payments-which was supposed to be crucial in our economic survival. It is a useful safety valve this year. What an extraordinary change in atmosphere and in tone.

I am intrigued to note that the Treasurer says he expects a fall in inflation from 7.5 per cent or so this year. I notice that the Reserve Bank of Australia says that last year's figure was overstated-that in fact it was not 7 per cent but less than that-because of a few influences. The Reserve Bank states:
In broad terms the rate of inflation in Australia in 1989/90 was about 7 per cent or a little lower.

If the Treasurer expects inflation to be a little lower than 7 per cent, it will be just about the same as last year's figure, allowing for Reserve Bank adjustments. It does not look to me as though the Treasurer will achieve what he claims he is going to achieve in his Budget Speech, and the Reserve Bank seems to imply that quite clearly.

I do not want to delay the Senate. There are many other points I would like to make about this matter. Senator Short has a real concern about the nature of this report. He has a remarkable background in this area as a former Treasury officer, and is our shadow Minister for Finance. He is here and I would rather he pursued this matter.

I am just expressing my concern that all the problems that we on this side of the chamber pointed to last year when what we thought was an inappropriate appointment to the Reserve Bank took place appear to have been confirmed. I regret that and I hope that next year the Reserve Bank once again discovers its independence and rediscovers its internal fortitude.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the Senate for too long this evening on this matter, but there are some points about the annual report of the Reserve Bank of Australia released today that I feel I must comment on. In doing so, I would first of all fully underline, endorse and support the comments already made by my colleague Senator Michael Baume.

SPEECH.PARA: The Reserve Bank annual report is always an important document. Indeed, it is one of the most important economic documents tabled in this Parliament in the course of any year. It comes a couple of days after the presentation to the Parliament of the Budget documents and, taken together, the Budget Papers and the Reserve Bank annual report constitute the economic thinking and policy views of the Government and the public sector. By and large they are more important than any other documents that we receive in this place each year.

That leads me to a point that I would like to make at the outset. It relates to the very first page of the Reserve Bank report. It is a page that is there every year. It has been there every year in every annual report since the Reserve Bank was founded in 1959. It is a quotation from the Reserve Bank Act 1959 concerning duties of the Board of the Reserve Bank. Of course, it is the Board's report that we are considering tonight. The Act states:

It is the duty of the Board, within the limits of its powers, to ensure that the monetary and banking policy of the Bank is directed to the greatest advantage of the people of Australia and that the powers of the Bank under this Act, the Banking Act 1959 and the regulations under that Act are exercised in such a manner as, in the opinion of the Board, will best contribute to the stability of the currency of Australia; the maintenance of full employment in Australia; and the economic prosperity and welfare of the people of Australia.

I believe that those facets of the duties of the bank are going to subjected to increasing debate and scrutiny in the period ahead. We have already seen the start of that debate in recent months and I think that is going to continue. The coalition is on record as saying that we believe that the independence of the Reserve Bank of Australia has to be greatly strengthened. With that increasing independence for the bank will come debate on several major issues.

There are many inconsistencies in the quotation from the Reserve Bank that I have just alluded to. For example, is it always consistent for the bank to act in a manner that will best contribute on the one hand to the stability of the currency of Australia-and that means keeping inflation down, keeping value in the dollar-and on the other hand to the maintenance of full employment in Australia?

The Act was proclaimed and produced in an era when very different views from those held today were expressed on the whole question of economic policy and economic management. In those years we were still very much steeped in the precepts of Keynesian economics. Today, Keynes would be largely discredited as the source of thinking for economic policy. I think Senator McMullan would agree that that would be the view on both sides of the Parliament.

The concern that I have and that the coalition has about the trend in economic policy thinking and debate over recent years is reflected, I think, in the schizophrenia that has been exhibited in recent times in some of the statements by bank spokesmen, and certainly spokesman for the Government, about the significance that ought to be attached to the control of inflation rather than the other issues of economic management.

We have, in my opinion and in the coalition's opinion, devoted far less attention than we should have to the significance of inflation in this country, particularly in recent years. In a very notable writing earlier this year it was pointed out by a former research director of the Reserve Bank, Dr Peter Johnson, who left some time ago, that inflation is a theft on the people. Unless government and the community recognise that and concentrate more on the insidious nature of inflation and the damaging effects it has on the whole structure not only of our economy but of our society, then we will not be performing our duties adequately.

The Reserve Bank annual report, as I said, complements the Budget documents in terms of coming together at the same time. It does not always support them. Honourable senators who were here last year will well recall, as my friend and colleague Senator Michael Baume pointed out in his remarks, the extraordinarily damaging criticism that the Reserve Bank annual report of 1989 made of the Government's economic policies.

I well remember it because Senator Baume and I, along with our former colleague Senator Stone, were so moved by the strength of criticism in that report about the Government's policies that the day after it was tabled we submitted a very important matter of public importance for discussion in this chamber in the following terms:
The repudiation by the Reserve Bank of the Hawke-Keating Government's economic policies.

Never, I think, have we seen a public document so lambasted, so critically analysed and destroyed-the whole underpinning of a government's economic strategy-as we saw in last year's annual report of the Reserve Bank of Australia, and, as Senator Michael Baume said, the criticism turned out to be absolutely right. It was spot-on. All the things that the Reserve Bank criticised the Government for last year have come home to roost. The chickens, as a result, have come home to roost and, as a result of that, we are now facing, as a nation, the greatest economic crisis that we have faced at least since the 1930s.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it turned out to be right.

—There are two very different conditions applying today from the 1930s. Indeed, if one looks at the degree of crisis in this country, one has to look not only at the 1930s, but at the former Great Depression, the other great depression we had in this country, in the 1890s. The common characteristic between the 1890s, the 1930s and today is that we have, in each of those three periods, a level of foreign debt as a proportion of our total economy that has got to a level which has become almost unsustainable.

SPEECH.PARA: The difference between the 1890 and 1930 situation from today is that those situations occurred at a time when the whole world was in great trouble. Today, our situation of crisis in Australia-an unsustainable situation in terms of our debt-has occurred after a period of almost a decade of unbridled growth in the world economy and in world trade which has never been more conducive to producing a better, prosperous, faster growing Australia than one could imagine.

The crisis that we have today is a home-grown crisis. In the 1930s and the 1890s, they were crises that were arguably imposed on us from outside-not only arguably; I think quite certainly they were imposed from outside. The crisis we have today is absolutely a home-grown crisis that the Reserve Bank pointed to in its annual report last year and about which, as we have said and seen, the Reserve Bank was absolutely right. It is a mark of the greatest indictment of this Government that it did not listen to its Reserve Bank, its monetary authority, last year; that it has continued, instead, to ignore the warnings about the problem of debt and inflation in our economy.

As a result of that, we face a situation today, 12 months later, in which that debt is at a far greater level than it was last year, both in absolute and in relative terms; in which inflation has barely improved, despite the fact that the economic situation on an international basis has been conducive to an improvement; where we have interest rates still at the highest level in the Western world; where we have productivity that is lagging below virtually every other Western country, and certainly most of the major competitors in our region of the world; and where nothing at all that this Government is doing in its economic policies will lead to a solution to those problems.

What the Government is doing today is strangling the economy in terms of squashing demand, trying to kill demand, but it is not doing anything at all about the real thing that has to be done to get this country going in a sustainable way, and that is to enhance the opportunity for an increase in the supply of goods and services produced in this country. The only way we shall do that is to improve our productivity and improve our international competitiveness.

That can often sound a little bit like dry economics, but it really comes to the bottom line as to the sort of society we are going to have in this country over the decade and beyond into the next century. If we do not introduce the necessary policies and pursue a culture of improved competitiveness, productivity, and greater supply of goods and services, we shall never be the society that can care, as we want to, and provide, as we want to, for all the people of our society, regardless of their economic circumstances or their station in life within our nation-and we have a responsibility as a nation to all of those people.

The Reserve Bank report, as I said, was very strong last year on many of these points of criticism of what the Government is doing. I agree with my friend and colleague Senator Michael Baume that this year we have a very sanitised report. It has obviously been worked over very carefully by the new Governor of the Reserve Bank, Bernie Fraser. Last year's report, I think, was produced in the hiatus between the retirement of Bob Johnston, the former governor, and the taking up of the reins by Mr Fraser. John Phillips was the acting governor of the Bank in that period.

I part company a little from my colleague in terms of the degree of sanitisation that has occurred in the Bank's report this year. In many respects, it has returned to the very cautious wording of Reserve Bank annual reports preceding 1989. In many ways, the 1989 report was a one-off report. Reserve Bank annual reports are always written in a fairly elliptical, delphic sort of manner, and one normally has to read between the lines to really get at what they are about. Last year one did not have to read between the lines because it hit one right in the eyeballs. This year one has to go back to reading the report a little along the lines of the pre-1989 reports. If one does that, one finds that there is a large degree of criticism-it might be a little more gentle than Senator Baume and I like-but, nevertheless, a lack of full agreement with the approach that the Government has been adopting to economic management over the last 12 months.

Let me just have a look at some of those. I do not want to speak at great length, because many of the points that I would raise will really be the subject of debate on the Budget, which we will be kicking off here tomorrow, but there are a couple of points that I would like to mention in so far as the Bank's contribution is concerned. The report's second paragraph is important in itself. It says:
The combination of sustained monetary tightness and economic slowdown has squeezed profit margins for many businesses.

I do not hear the Treasurer (Mr Keating) saying too much about that. I hear the Treasurer running around the countryside saying, `The profit margin and the proportion of profits in GDP is now back at record-ever levels, and what on earth are businesses about in complaining about the state of the economic environment in which they are working'. The Reserve Bank says very clearly that profit margins are being squeezed for many businesses. That, in Reserve Bank language, means that many businesses are suffering appallingly as a result of the high sustained monetary tightness that the Government, through the Reserve Bank, has been pursuing. It is a policy that the Reserve Bank has been pursuing on behalf of the Government because of the pressure that the Government has been putting on the Bank to pursue this monetary tightness because the Government has not had the wit or the ability, given its divisions and factionalism, to take the necessary measures of a complementary nature in fiscal, wages or any other forms of policy, particularly in the areas of micro-economic reform, that would enable it to take the running away from monetary policy a little, and to get interest rates down to levels that will not squeeze businesses out of existence. We have seen a 43 per cent growth in bankruptcies in my State, Victoria, in the last 12 months alone.

We have seen an increase of 26 per cent in bankruptcies nationwide in the last 12 months. Why has that happened? That has happened fairly and squarely because this Government has not had the guts or the ability to take the measures in areas other than monetary policy which would allow that easing of monetary policy which would, in turn, allow those businesses to be competitive and profitable again, and to stay in existence.

That is the reason why there has been in this country in the last 12 months-in fact, less than the last 12 months-an increase in unemployment of 100,000 people. And the Treasurer had the gall the other night on television after the Budget-and, indeed, he was reflecting on what was in the Budget-to say that there could be a further increase in unemployment this year. What is he budgeting for in terms of an unemployment increase this year? He is budgeting for an increase of 26 per cent in unemployment beneficiaries this year, and he says that that is really not something that ought to concern us. The Reserve Bank is pointing to that very clearly.

It also points, in many other comments in these pages, to the fact that monetary policy is not only far too restrictive-because of the lack of ability to adopt a proper balance of policies-but also came fairly late upon the scene. The screws were really turned on, it says here, only in April 1988. Why were they turned on only in April 1988, when they should have been progressively and more gently applied from the latter part of 1987? Everyone-even blind Freddy-knew that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Haven't you heard of the stock market crash?

—I have heard of the stock market crash, Senator McMullan, but I have also heard of something else. There was a far more important thing in the eyes of Senator McMullan's Party, and the far more important thing was the desperate attempt by the Hawke-Keating Government to save that ravaged Unsworth Government when it was facing an election in March 1988. The only reason why monetary policy was not applied earlier than April 1988 was the desperate attempt to salvage an unsalvageable New South Wales Government in 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many other points of an economic policy nature that one could make about the report itself. I will not go into those tonight; I will pursue them on other occasions, including the Budget debate.

I finally turn to support the comments that my friend Senator Michael Baume made in his remarks about the role of the Reserve Bank but, more particularly, the role of the Government and, within that, the Treasurer in the Pyramid Building Society debacle in my State.

Those here who do not come from Victoria do not really appreciate the significance of Pyramid. Pyramid was far and away the largest building society in Victoria. I think it had 54 per cent of total building society deposits in Victoria. It was very largely based around the major city of Geelong. Most families in Geelong had, and still have, a connection with Pyramid in the sense that they had money in it.

I believe that the comments that were made today by the Treasurer and by Senator Button demonstrate a degree of callousness, confusion and just sheer hopelessness, in terms of their understanding of the problems of the collapse of Pyramid-and all the events leading to that collapse-for a major provincial city of Victoria and, indeed, for Victoria as a whole. Victoria is a very depressed State. My new Senate confrere Senator Spindler-whom I see here tonight-is nodding his head; he would agree.

Victoria is a very depressed State indeed. It is a depressed State, not just because of Pyramid, but for two fundamental reasons. The first one is that we have had a hopelessly incompetent Labor government in Victoria for 8 years now-a government which has literally bankrupted the public finances of my State. Secondly, the State has had superimposed on it the abject failure and incompetence of a Federal Labor Government, led by Mr Hawke and Mr Keating, compounding all the problems that have been home grown.

TALK.START.PARA: —You say Cain was not able!

—Cain has got his desserts, Senator Baume, but not from Abel. I am sure that the new premier-Kirnerhelp-us-cannot help us at all. It is a problem of profound significance for my State. I have lived in Victoria for many years. I have never, in my lifetime, seen a State as depressed as the State of Victoria is at the moment, and that is due wholly and solely to the incompetence of a totally incompetent State Government and a more incompetent Federal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: If one reads the lines carefully, and reads between them, one sees that the Reserve Bank's annual report points to the reasons for many of those problems. I am sorry that this report is as sanitised as it is. I guess that is understandable, to some extent, when one sees the vitriol that this Treasurer poured on one of the most respected members of the financial community in Australia, the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank, John Phillips, who had the courage to say it as it really was, in terms of inflation, in a speech to the Committee for the Economic Development of Australia on 19 June, only to be vilified publicly in a statement by the Treasurer a few days later in a way that I find quite unacceptable and unbelievable.

They are the sorts of things that are the hallmarks of this Government. They are the things that this Government is going to be remembered for-the vitriol, the bile and the lack of decency in its approach, not only to the whole question of government, but also to appointed officials of government.

The Reserve Bank, despite its sanitisation of its annual report, has a fundamental role to play. I want to see the Reserve Bank become a much more independent institution. We have got to look very closely at the whole structure of the Reserve Bank Act. I am sure it is not going to happen under this Government, but I would hope, and very confidently expect, that one of the very early acts of an incoming coalition government will be to give the Reserve Bank the independence that it needs if it is to undertake the very important duties that a central bank has in any nation.

The Auditor-General Audit Report No. 1 of 1990-91 particularly deals with the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) administration to self-government day, which was 11 May 1989. The report is worth looking at from several points of view.

Before doing so, it is worth looking back at some of the statements made by the Australian Labor Party prior to self-government coming into existence. When I read this Auditor-General's report today, I was particularly reminded of the statements of the then Minister, Mr Gary Punch. I will quote some parts of a press release put out by Gary Punch on 13= April 1988. He said:

The ACT is well and truly ready for self government. In organisational terms we have an ACT Administration with its own budget and fiscus that is ready to hand over to the elected representatives of the people of Canberra.
That being his view, one can only surmise that he was not aware of a great deal going on in his Department. In the same press release he said:
There is no reason why self government should cost ACT citizens more than the current system.
Further on he stated:
Transitional financial arrangements that will apply over a number of years will be introduced to ensure an orderly and smooth transition of power.

The Commonwealth Grants Commission will decide the Commonwealth's grant to the ACT after that in the same way as it does for the States and the Northern Territory, taking into account the additional costs that arise from Canberra being the nation's capital.

I guess that many of us believe that that was the Commonwealth's view. We believe that it had been running the financial arrangements of the ACT well and was handing over a satisfactory financial situation.

In recent times it has become far too apparent that that was not the case. The ACT people are bearing the brunt of the Commonwealth's failure to manage the Territory properly during the six years that it was responsible for the Territory prior to self-government day on 11 May 1989.

Only as recently as the Premiers Conference of 1990 did we learn exactly what others think of the ACT and the way they treat us. It was then reported that the ACT would be the hardest hit of all States and Territories, except perhaps the Northern Territory, as a result of new funding formulas which had been proposed by the Commonwealth at the Premiers Conference. The report said that the ACT faced a real cut and that all others, except the Northern Territory, would receive an increase.

The Canberra Times reported that to compound the real decline in the ACT's funds, the Commonwealth proposed to withhold $32.6m, to be placed in an ACT trust account established after last year's Premiers Conference. You, Madam Acting Deputy President, will not have forgotten that last year the same thing was done. The Commonwealth took money which it had previously promised and put it into a trust account and withheld it from the ACT.

This report before us sets out some of the occurrences during the Labor Party's administration of the ACT. I shall refer just to the key points and not go into the report in detail, but anyone who reads it will get the full detail of the matters that I am referring to. It talks about the ACT Housing Assistance Fund. The report states:
. . . the accounts were unqualified, but the ANAO-
that is, the Australian National Audit Office-
found high levels of home loan mortgage debts and arrears of rent on government housing, also in the number of vacant houses.

All of those three areas within the housing area indicate that less money was coming in and more owed to the Government than one would have expected as being reasonable, if one believes the Minister's statement that all was well and in order in the financial affairs of the ACT when self-government was handed over. Clearly it was not.
The Auditor-General's Report says of the ACT Transport Trust:
. . . the accounts were qualified for over-award payments, and the ANAO also noted inadequacies in the inventory recording system.

The report also talks about the ACT Forestry Trust, the City of Canberra Municipal Accounts, the ACT Electricity and Water Authority and the Gaming and Liquor Authority. There, there were no problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I present the Committee's report on the National Crime Authority's annual report for 1988-89.

The document read as follows-
EXAMINATION OF THE ANNUAL REPORT FOR 1988-89 OF THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY
Tabling Statement

In tabling the Committee's report on its examination of the 1988-89 Annual Report of the National Crime Authority, I wish to take the opportunity to speak about the activities of the Committee in this the 36th Parliament.

The Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority is created by Part 111 of the National Crime Authority Act 1984 and consists of ten members; namely five members of the Senate appointed by the Senate and five members of the House of Representatives appointed by the House.

The Committee was re-appointed by resolution of the two Houses on 16 May 1990, and since the new Senators took up their places last 1 July the Committee has seven of its ten members new to its membership. I was honoured to be elected unopposed as Chairman of the Committee, and Senator Amanda Vanstone, Senator for South Australia, is the Deputy Chairman.

The Committee has reviewed the past activities of its predecessor Committees and it proposes to build on their substantial achievements. However, the Committee noted an apparent desire by the Committee in the last Parliament to extend its role beyond that intended by Parliament, especially in its proposed inquiry into the capacity of the police to combat organised crime. The current Committee has resolved to discontinue this inquiry because, while the Committee recognised that the quality of Australia's police forces is a matter of major importance, the subject matter is essentially one for State Governments, and is only peripherally relevant to the Committee's duties as prescribed in section 55 of the National Crime Authority Act.

The report I am tabling today is indicative of the Committee's desire to comply with these statutory duties. While the 1988-89 report of the National Crime Authority is its fifth annual report, the Parliamentary Joint Committee has not in the past reported to Parliament its examination of annual reports except in a cursory manner in its ad hoc omnibus reports. This is despite paragraph 55 (1) (c) of the Act making it an express duty of the Committee, and I quote, `to examine each annual report of the Authority and report to the Parliament on any matter appearing in or arising out of, any such annual report.'

The Committee's principal statutory function is to monitor and review the performance of the National Crime Authority on behalf of the Parliament and, through it, the citizens of Australia. This it proposes to do.

As its major task for this 36th Parliament, the Committee has announced that it will conduct a comprehensive evaluation of the Authority. Such a task had been recommended for commencement after June 1991 by the Committee's predecessor in its May 1988 Initial Evaluation report, a recommendation which was not opposed by the Government in its response in November 1988. The Committee has resolved to launch the evaluation inquiry immediately, after it had received a number of concerns, not least from the Authority itself, that such a review was necessary following the removal of the sunset clause in June 1988. The Committee proposes to review all aspects of the Authority's operations: its constitution, role, functions and powers; its efficiency and effectiveness; the issue of accountability and parliamentary supervision; and the need for amendment of the National Crime Authority Act 1984 that will arise from the review.

The terms of reference have been advertised nationally and submissions requested, with a closing date of Friday, 14= September l990. The Committee has indicated that it proposes to report its findings to Parliament by August 1991.
The Committee also intends to conduct smaller inquiries simultaneously, but with the emphasis on its statutory duty to inquire into matters relating to the activities of the National Crime Authority.

The report now presented is the first report of the Committee as newly constituted in the 36th Parliament. It is also the first report of the apparent duty of the Committee in paragraph 55 (1) (c) of the Act to do so. In the past, the Committee has met this statutory duty by passing only brief comment on the contents of NCA Annual Reports in its general reports to the Parliament; comments which have generally endorsed the quality of the reports and commended the NCA for increasing provision of information about its investigations.

The correspondence reproduced in the Committee's report includes details of the Senate's examination of annual reports, which had adjudged the NCA report as satisfactory except in relation to one of the guidelines which apply to reporting by statutory authorities. However, as indicated in the NCA's letter to the Committee dated 20 July 1990, the NCA has, since its inception, followed the guidelines for reporting applying to departmental annual reports, rather than statutory authorities.

In fact, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet wrote to the Secretaries of all departments in April 1990 to indicate that it may be appropriate for statutory authorities to follow departmental guidelines wholly or in part because of the absence of up-to-date guidelines for statutory authorities.

Clearly, the Senate will need to examine the implications of this advice for its future system of scrutiny of annual reports or alternatively to cease the approach adopted in May 1990 of routinely comparing reports against guidelines and instead adopt a more targeted approach.

The Committee had suggested to the NCA that it consider copying the ICAC precedent and present its annual reports direct to the Presiding Officers as evidence of its independence from executive influence. The NCA defended the current system of reporting to the Inter-Governmental Committee as `appropriate for a national body with a Commonwealth/State role'. As term of reference No. 3 of the Committee's Evaluation of the National Crime Authority inquiry is directed at `accountability and parliamentary supervision of the Authority', the method of reporting by the NCA will be closely examined by the Committee in the context of its foreshadowed inquiry.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, I table the report of the Committee entitled Review of the National Capital Plan 2nd Report-The Certified Draft Plan. I seek leave to move a motion relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Within this report there are five recommendations and I wish to refer to them. With the introduction of self-government in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) the Federal Government saw the need to establish proper planning arrangements which would recognise that this Territory, while being the national capital of Australia, is also home to almost 300,000 residents. One of the Acts passed by this Parliament which makes up the self-government package was the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988 which established the National Capital Planning Authority (NCPA) and required the Authority to prepare a national capital plan.

The object of this plan was to ensure that Canberra and the ACT are planned and developed in accordance with their national significance. The NCPA was required to have the plan prepared by 1990 but, with the election ensuing, it was not surprising that that was not met in the way that it had been intended. Last year volumes of the draft plan were released for public comment and were referred by the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons) to the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory.

The Committee in the previous Parliament virtually completed its inquiry but because of the election was not able to present the report prior to that time. At about the time of the election this plan was certified by the Minister. The new Committee then presented its report in May 1990. That report contained about 20 recommendations, many of which have been significantly adopted by the NCPA in its revised draft plan. The Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Capital Territory comments on the revised draft plan in the report that I have tabled today. The plan has identified areas of the ACT and recommended that they be classified into particular categories referred to as: designated areas; areas to which special requirements apply; and areas which are in neither category.
National Crime Authority
Joint Committee on ACT

The significance of these three categories can be summarised in this way: The designated areas are those with some special characteristic of the national capital, such as the Parliamentary Triangle and the areas where the planning is within the authority of the National Capital Planning Authority (NCPA). In most of the areas where special requirements apply, the NCPA will also be involved in planning, as will the Australian Capital Territory Planning Authority. Special conditions may be laid down concerning planning and development in these areas. In those areas which are not designated and which are not subject to special requirements, the Territory Planning Authority is the responsible planning body.
I wish to draw the attention of the Senate to the recommendations of the Joint Committee and make some comments about them. The first recommendation states:

the National Capital Plan provide that Special Requirements be applied in the Lanyon area either by including the area in the Murrumbidgee Corridor or by separately identifying the Lanyon area; and the River Corridors, where Special Requirements are to be applied, be defined in the National Capital Plan with more precision than the map of the General Policy Plan.

The matter of the Lanyon and Murrumbidgee area has been debated in the Senate on previous occasions and the same Committee has reported to the Senate after an inquiry into that area. The Lanyon area also came before the Joint Committee and the Parliament when the development of land was being considered in the area leading towards the Lanyon property. There was some discussion with the then Minister for Territories and Local Government, Mr Uren, about how far south the urban development should go. It is very disappointing to me that the development there has been proceeded with in the same close urban settlement as exists in the rest of Canberra when it ought, in my view, to have been somewhat more sparse, as is fitting to the entrance of a town or city where there are larger blocks on the edge of town with a different type of settlement leading into the more closely settled areas nearer the city centres. That is perhaps not a matter for discussion tonight, but it is certainly a matter which I regard as very disappointing.

The Murrumbidgee is a very important part of the inland river system of Australia. It is part of the Murray-Darling system and approximately 60 kilometres of the river are within the ACT. The significance of its being so close to a large population centre is very apparent when one thinks of the pressures on the river and its environs. It was designated an area of special national concern by the Commonwealth Government in 1964, meaning that it was given special attention as an area playing an important part in establishing the character of the city of Canberra. It is appropriate that that characteristic continue to be recognised, and I commend that recommendation to the Senate.
The second recommendation states:
the Department of Defence urgently consider ways of making as much of the land as possible occupied by the Belconnen and Bonshaw naval communications stations available for housing development.

We heard evidence also-and I will refer to the third recommendation-that the National Capital Planning Authority and the Territory planners should consider alternatives to standard housing development on the western edge of Belconnen. Both of those recommendations relate to the need to make the best use of the land available in Canberra; to make the best use of the costly infrastructure and see that the areas which can be satisfactorily built up but have not been so far can be built up. This will cut down costs considerably for the rest of the community.

The residents from the west Belconnen area who gave evidence to the Committee expressed concern at the prospective loss of open space and bushland if intense housing development occurred in that particular area which is very close to the New South Wales border. We also heard evidence from the Territory Planning Authority that, while the Belconnen area was originally planned for a population of 120,000 people, at present the population is only about 85,000 people. So the need to make the best use of the Belconnen land is, of course, apparent.

I think that all Committee members were concerned that, in the event of development in the west Belconnen area, there should be adequate open space left, as well as access to the open space areas for the people in that area. Again, I refer to what I have just said about urban development at the southern extremity near Lanyon. If there is to be development in this area of west Belconnen it, too, should be much sparser than the normal urban development, with larger blocks that some people might like to buy in order to live on the edge of town. It is not an appropriate area for close urban development.
In making this recommendation, the Committee felt that, while we concede that there is perhaps some benefit in developing there, there needs to be a closer examination before development proceeds.

I return to the second recommendation concerning building in the Belconnen and Bonshaw naval station areas. The land occupied there by the Department of Defence is indeed very valuable. One wonders whether, this long after they were first established, they could do the same thing with less land if the technology were updated. I do not know the answer to that question but it is certainly worth inquiring about. I do not want us to lose people from the ACT as a consequence of shifting the naval stations out of the ACT. We have enough problems with the economy in Canberra already without losing population.

Perhaps I can divert from this matter to say to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who is present in the chamber, that we cannot afford to lose the people that he would move to Newcastle by shifting the Federal Sea Safety Centre from Canberra to Newcastle. The Labor Government has been shifting people out of Canberra at will for the whole of the time that it has been in government. It has to stop if the economy of the Australian Capital Territory is not to be seriously affected.

We cannot afford to lose the Service personnel who would be lost to Canberra if the Belconnen and Bonshaw naval stations were just packed up and moved to some other place. While the land is very valuable for housing development, we have to be quite certain that we are not creating other problems by moving people out. It is an area where investigation is required.

While we are talking about the Belconnen area, I wish to remind the Senate that it is an ecologically unique area. The grasslands around the Belconnen Naval Station have not been used for any agricultural purpose and they are, apparently, in their natural state. Within the Belconnen Naval Station there lives a species of moth, now regarded as an endangered species, which feeds on the native grasslands which are within the station's boundaries. If that area were to be developed and if the normal things were placed upon it, as would occur if gardens were established and other developments took place, it would, I understand, mean the end of that species of moth. That may or may not be a matter of concern, but I do not think that it is something that should be embarked upon without further investigation.
The fourth recommendation of the Committee states:

. . . that all gazetted National Land should be identified in the National Capital Plan as either Designated Areas or areas where Special Requirements will apply; and an area of gazetted National Land will only be identified as a Designated Area where that land displays some special characteristic of the National Capital.

On this point I refer to the matters raised by the Department of Administrative Services. A representative of the Department's Australian Property Group expressed concern to the Committee about the Department being required to comply with the Territory plan. On the one hand, the Parliament is indicating through legislation which it has passed that there is to be a National Capital Planning Authority which will determine certain things about the way the ACT will develop in the future, and on the other hand a department of the Commonwealth is querying whether it should be required to abide by these rules. It seems to me to be an extraordinary proposition which must be resolved.

The Committee endorsed the previous Committee's recommendation that the NCPA should develop procedures in relation to the plan and that the Commonwealth should make the appropriate decisions to see that the Department of Administrative Services is not excluded from the plan. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.PARA: The three case studies that I am presenting to the Senate tonight I believe are graphic and potent evidence of malpractice, corrupt practice, perjury, deception, lying and dishonesty by major banking administrators in this country. CASE HISTORY-MIGHTY CHEF PRODUCTS

Mr Wilfred Taylor, of Cambewarra. is the Managing Director of Mighty Chef Products Pty Limited, the former manufacturer of the Mighty Chef range of microwave cookware. That range was generally regarded as the best on the Australian market and significant worldwide export markets were emerging.
On March 1 1988, The Commonwealth Bank of Australia purported to appoint Messrs Sherlock and Isherwood, partners of Cooper and Lybrand, as Receivers of the assets and undertakings of the Company.

On March 25 1988 the Company, by Deed, terminated the appointment of Sherlock and Isherwood. By letter dated that day, the Company put Sherlock on notice that he and Isherwood had no right to advertise the business of the Company for sale or to purport to sell the business to any person.

On March 28 1988 Mr Taylor re-entered the premises of the Company and took control of the business. A partner of Coopers and Lybrand, one Martin Brown, caused Mr Taylor to be removed from the premises with conduct described by The Shoalhaven and Nowra News as `Gestapo Tactics'.

During the early afternoon of that day, Brown came onto the premises of the Company. Brown became hostile and ripped a newspaper from Mr Taylor's hands and said, `I should throw you out the door'. Taylor said, `If you lay one finger on me I will charge you with assault.' Brown became increasingly hostile and said to Taylor, `I should pull that chair from under you'. Taylor replied, `Come and try it'. Brown then said, `No, you may have a heart attack and I could be charged'. Brown then left the premises.

One of Brown's employees said to Taylor, `He (Brown) has instructed me to put chains and padlocks on the office doors leading to the factory area. You'll be locked in'. Taylor replied `How will I be able to get to the toilet?' The employee replied: `You can use the gutter. There will be a security guard coming, when you go outside to relieve yourself, you will be locked out.'

Workmen drilled holes in the doors and walls to affix the chains. A locksmith arrived on the premises and put new locks on the front door and the inner office. Shortly after, a security guard arrived armed with a revolver in a hip holster. The conduct of Brown was that of an impetulant child. Brown acted in a high-handed manner with total disregard for Mr Taylor's rights. Brown acted on behalf of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the Bank that has advertised itself Australia wide as `BIG, SAFE AND FRIENDLY'.

On April 20 1988, the solicitor for the Company advised Coopers and Lybrand that Mr Kerry Packer wanted to include the Company in a joint venture with one of his Companies, United Systems, and other Companies and to float a consolidated Company on the First Board of the Stock Exchange. By letter that day, the Company advised Brown of the proposed joint venture and asked Brown not to instigate any action which could jeopardise the fruition of the proposed joint venture. Brown ignored the letter.

On April 22 1988, Sherlock and Isherwood purported to sell the business of the Company to Kambrook Distributing Pty Limited of Melbourne for $402,000. At that time, the Company's plant and equipment was valued on a replacement value basis at over $2 million and the assets were valued on a going concern basis at over $4 million.

On May 2 1988, the Managing Director of United Systems advised Kambrook that the position appeared to be that the purported sale of the plant and equipment was null and void. By letter dated May 6 1988 the Managing Director of Kambrook advised United Systems that it purchased the assets `without notice of any alleged defect in the Vendor's title to the assets'.

The conduct of Sherlock and Isherwood, in failing to disclose the Deed terminating their appointment and purporting to sell the assets for a fraction of their true value, was blatant fraud. That fraud was perpetrated by Sherlock and Isherwood as the appointees of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia.

Sherlock and Isherwood were appointed by the Bank without any Order of the Court and proceeded to strip the Company of its assets. This must never be allowed happen again. I call for urgent legislative reforms to require Receivers to be appointed by the Court and to be answerable to the Court for their misconduct.
I call upon the Commissioner for Corporate Affairs for NSW to initiate an investigation into these matters with a view to laying criminal charges.
CASE HISTORY-HUON VALLEY SPRINGS

Miss Donna Batiste was the proprietor of Huon Valley Springs Pty Limited, a company developing a mineral water processing plant in Tasmania. The quality of the product was recognised as equal to that of Perrier and able to compete on the world market.

Miss Batiste's Company borrowed funds from the Commonwealth Development Bank and operated a working overdraft account with the Commonwealth Trading Bank as it then was. The Development Bank held security over the assets of the business. The Trading Bank held first mortgage security over Miss Batiste's penthouse at the Regent Hotel in Sydney.
On January 14 1986, Mr K. M. Simington, Senior Manager, NSW Branches Administration of the Trading Bank, instructed that cheques `will be dishonoured today unless cash funds are provided . . .'

The following day Mr J. J. Vanner, Deputy Chief Manager of the Trading Bank, issued a memorandum stating: `The hard line is to be taken. Cheques drawn on HVS (that is, Huon Valley Springs) account are to be dishonoured . . . Batiste cannot expect otherwise and she is not worthy of some special treatment . . .'
On February 6 1986, the Development Bank served on Huon Valley Springs a Notice of Demand purporting to require payment of $525,020.10 within one hour.

Huon Valley Springs was in default to the Development Bank for interest not exceeding $10,000. The reason the Company was in default and could not pay that interest was because funds totalling $350,000 advanced by the Development Bank to Huon Valley Springs as start up capital had been deposited by Mr Simington of the Trading Bank on interest bearing deposit for a period of l8l days.

Mr Simington declined to release those funds to Huon Valley Springs to pay the interest. Mr Simington illegally transferred those funds in reduction of Huon Valley Spring's operating overdraft account, thereby depriving the company of its capacity to service the interest payment to the Development Bank.
On February 6 1986, the Development Bank purported to appoint receivers to the assets and undertakings of Huon Valley Springs.

On May 30 1986, Mr W. Christey, of the Trading Bank's NSW Southern Division, in an internal memorandum, said: `If as claimed Batiste is in dire financial difficulties and has no assets obviously the CBA is not going to gain any benefit from bankrupting Batiste except satisfaction.'

On June 2 1986, the Trading Bank undertook in writing `. . . not to initiate bankruptcy proceedings against you in respect to your indebtedness to it . . .' The undertaking was signed by Mr Vanner and conferred upon Miss Batiste the right to sell the penthouse in accordance with the Trading Bank's independent valuation and pay the proceeds of sale in discharge of her indebtedness to the Trading Bank.

By letter dated August 5 1986, the solicitor for the Trading Bank, Mr L. C. Hollis, wrote to Miss Batiste's solicitors alleging: . . . She is refusing the bank further access to the property and thereby preventing a second valuation from being carried out. She is, accordingly, in breach of the agreement. Should she not vacate the premises then the bank will consider taking immediate ejectment proceedings against her.'

In a judgement handed down in the Federal Court on April 27 1989, Mr Justice Burchett said of the letter: `. . . The letter ignores entirely the rights the bank had agreed to give Miss Batiste to re-finance the property or sell it herself at `the bank's independent valuation'. The proposition that the agreement cannot diminish the bank's rights is, on the face of it, extraordinary. The letter evinces an attitude of total and high-handed disregard of the rights the Bank had granted to Miss Batiste . . .'

In an internal memorandum dated September 9 1986, Mr W. Christey (referring to a valuation of the penthouse provided on behalf of Miss Batiste) stated: `. . . past experience with Batiste shows that we cannot rely on any dealings she has been involved in and it would not surprise if it came to our notice that the valuation . . . was not above board. We would always go `under the table' ourselves and obtain a valuation to our liking but . . . there is the possibility that our actions could become known'. In his judgement, Mr Justice Burchett described this proposition as `a remarkable suggestion'.

The memorandum has the following handwritten comments by an officer of the Trading Bank: `Batiste has shown quite clearly that she lacks principle completely . . . We have the cards and should play them in the strongest possible manner. Batiste deserves no compassion whatsoever. Throughout the whole saga with her my attitude has been that the Bank pursue her to the ultimate and that includes to bankruptcy . . . I believe the CBA has a social responsibility to take her there with the undertaking of 2.6.86 being revoked immediately . . . for once it appears that the CBA holds the upper hand and in this regard Batiste most definitely does not want the bank to pursue her to bankruptcy'.
To this, Mr Justice Burchett said: `The comments endorsed on the memorandum indicate a very considerable (even personal) animus against Miss Batiste . . .'

On September 26 1986, Mr R. N. Sim, General Manager to the Trading Bank, wrote in an internal memorandum: `In the last few days we have received an offer of $1.1 million (in respect of the sale of the penthouse) which we have refused believing it could well be an arrangement engineered by Miss Batiste . . . we also intend to put in train a summons to obtain judgement as a prelude to bankruptcy proceedings, the fear of which might generate from Miss Batiste a level of co-operation.'

By letter dated October 20 1986, the bank's solicitors wrote to Miss Batiste's solicitors purporting to revoke the undertaking not to bankrupt her, denying that Miss Batiste had co-operated with the bank in the exercise of its power of sale.
Miss Batiste proceeded to sell the penthouse for $1.5 million. To quote Mr Justice Burchett: `The bank consented to sale at that price, and in due course received the net proceeds.'

Miss Batiste had given the bank everything they had bargained for when executing the undertaking not to bankrupt her. Nevertheless, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the Bank that advertises Australia wide, ad nauseam, describing itself as `Australia's Leading Bank', filed a petition in the Federal Court to bankrupt Miss Batiste. In his judgment dismissing the petition, Mr Justice Burchett said: `The circumstances alleged by Miss Batiste are of some complexity. Her version of them has not been challenged by any evidence on behalf of the bank; nor, although she was cross-examined, did anything emerge to cast any shadow on the credit of her account. This is remarkable, since documents from the Bank's file make it plain the entire dispute had its genesis in a diametrically opposed view of the facts entertained at the time by officers of the Bank, never since unequivocally withdrawn, which there was no attempt at the hearing to justify.'

This conduct by management of the Commonwealth Bank at the most senior level must stand as one of the most disgraceful exhibitions by servants of the Commonwealth of Australia. This conduct casts a dark shadow over the honour and integrity of the Commonwealth Bank. It places in question whether that bank stands above the law or whether the bank and its customers are equal before the law.

I commend Mr Justice Burchett for his courage in confirming to the Australian people that our society is not based on rank and privilege but on justice and equality for all. I call upon the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, to initiate an investigation into these matters with a view to laying criminal charges.
CASE HISTORY-TONY RIGG

In June 1985, the Commonwealth Bank's Nowra Branch approved a Bills Discount facility to Mr &Mrs Tony and Dorothy Rigg of Nowra. On 34 separate occasions between August 1985 and November 1987 the Bill roll-over transactions were credited and debited by the Bank to the overdraft account of the Rigg's trading company, Tony Rigg Welding &Manufacturing Pty Ltd.

The Bank's records show that on each occasion officers of the Bank authorised the crediting and debiting of those transactions to the overdraft account of the Company. The aforementioned amounts should have been debited to the account of Mr &Mrs Rigg from the outset. Debiting the rollover costs to the overdraft account of the Company had the effect of absorbing the profits of the Company and crippled the business.

The last Bill, with a face value of $750,000, matured on 22 December 1987. The following day that amount of $750,000 was debited to the overdraft account of the Company as a miscellaneous debit. (Table bank statement.)

On 15 March 1988, the debit balance to the overdraft account was over $1 million representing the amount of $750,000 aforementioned, the Bill rollover costs and overdraft interest. On that date, the Bank wrote to the Company demanding payment of $1,032,398.67 and on the same day wrote to Mr &Mrs Rigg demanding payment of that sum as guarantors of the Company's overdraft account. (Table letters.)

The Company was unable to meet its debts and the Directors were obliged by law to freeze the account. That was done by instruction to the Bank dated August 10 1988, under the Seal of the Company. By letter dated August 16 1988, the bank wrote to the Company confirming that the instruction would be adhered to. (Instruction and reply to be tabled.)
By letter and notice dated December 21 1988, solicitors for the Company denied liability for the sum claimed and denied that Mr &Mrs Rigg were liable as guarantors. (To be tabled.)

By letter dated February 3 1989, the Senior Manager, Nowra Branch, Mr Don Alston, wrote to the Company claiming that the debiting of the $750,000 to the overdraft account was an error and purported to reverse the entry. On the same day, Mr Alston wrote to Mr &Mrs Rigg claiming they were personally liable for the $750,000 as the drawers of the Bill that matured on December 22 1987. (Letters tabled.)
The bank illegally manipulated the account of the Company for the sole purpose of making a claim against Mr &Mrs Rigg personally.

In a letter dated March 1 1989, the Managing Director of the Bank, Mr Don Sanders, alleged to me that the debiting of the $750,000 to the overdraft account was a `mistake' and had been `rectified'. (Letter tabled.)

That was a palpable falsehood. If, as Mr Sanders alleged, there was a `mistake', then all the previous debits were `mistakes' also. No attempt was made to reverse the previous entries. Further, no attempt was made to reverse any of the debits of Rollover costs, including the costs relating to the last bill. Indeed, the Bank continued to make a claim against the Company for those amounts.
Mr Sanders' letter was an attempt to cover-up the manipulation of the Company's overdraft account.

On April 5 1989, Mr Sanders letter was tabled in the Senate by the then Senator John Stone and incorporated into Hansard. Senator Stone relied on Mr Sanders letter to oppose my motion for a Senate Inquiry into Banks.

Mr Sanders letter goes on to state: `On every occasion on which a Bill was drawn down or rolled over on maturity, Mr &Mrs Rigg were written to and informed in detail of the amount of the Bill, its maturity date, its duration, the amount of fees and the nett amount credited, or debited, and specifying the account to which the credit or debit had been made.'

The allegation was a palpable falsehood. An examination of the Banks files shows that on the draw-down of the last Bill, the Riggs were not written to at all. The Riggs did not know of the maturity date of the Bill.
Further, on the day before that Bill matured, Mr Rigg met the regional manager of the Bank, Mr Geoffrey Kyngdon, at Wollongong.

The Bank's files show that Mr Kyngdon made no mention of the maturity date of the Bill or that the Bank held no intention of rolling the Bill over the following day. Indeed, the Bank's files show that Mr Kyngdon gave Mr Rigg until January 15 1988 to come up with plans for clearance or reduction of the debts.
On March 16 1989 the Bank issued proceedings against Mr &Mrs Rigg, by way of cross-claim, claiming the face value of the Bill namely $750,000, and interest thereon.

The cross-claim alleges ``On December 22 1987, the Bill was duly presented for payment and dishonoured'' and . . . that the Bill was presented for payment to the cross defendants (that is, Mr and Mrs Rigg) as drawers thereof . . . .'' The cross-claim further alleges ``. . . that presentation for payment was dispensed with . . .'' (Table cross-claim.)

These mutually exclusive statements of fact, namely that the Bill was presented to Mr &Mrs Rigg, and at one and the same time, was not presented to Mr &Mrs Rigg, were verified on oath by the regional manager, Wollongong, Mr Geoffrey Kyngdon.

In those proceedings, Mr &Mrs Rigg denied on oath, that the Bill was presented to them for payment. The Bank's files failed to disclose any evidence that the Bill was presented to Mr &Mrs Rigg. Judgement was entered against Mr &Mrs Rigg on the Cross-Claim.

The fact is the Bill was not presented to Mr &Mrs Rigg at all! The face value of the Bill was debited to the overdraft account of the Company and demand for that amount was made on the Company. The fact is that the regional manager of the bank, Mr Geoffrey Kyngdon, committed wilful and corrupt perjury.

The Riggs appealed against the Judgement to the NSW Court of Appeal. In his written judgment, dismissing the appeal, His Honour the Chief Justice, Mr Justice Gleeson, relied upon the letter from Mr Sanders and said: `That letter includes the following information: On every occasion on which a bill was drawn down or rolled over on maturity Mr &Mrs Rigg were written to and informed in detail of the amount of the bill, its maturity date, its duration, the amount of the fees and the nett amount credited or debited and specifying the account to which the credit or debit had been made.'' (Judgment to be tabled.)
I say again that the allegation by Mr Sanders, quoted and relied upon by the Chief Justice, contained a palpable falsehood. That falsehood was not disclosed to the Chief Justice.

The Riggs applied to the High Court of Australia for Special Leave To Appeal against the judgement of the Court of Appeal. The Riggs ran out of funds to prosecute the Appeal and were obliged to enter into a commercial settlement with the Bank.

Part of the settlement was that the Riggs and the Company would make a public apology. On December 20 1989 an apology appeared in the South Coast Register &The Shoalhaven &Nowra News. The apology included the following: Mr and Mrs Rigg and their Company now unreservedly withdraw all and any allegations of fraud and deceit previously made against the Bank and its officers and unreservedly apologise for the hurt, distress and offence caused by the allegations. (Table apologies).

The Commonwealth Bank of Australia, through Officers, manipulated the Company's account, committed perjury, published palpable falsehoods and perverted the course of Justice. The Commonwealth Bank of Australia, through Officers, misled the Court, misled the Parliament and misled the People.
I call upon the Attorney General for NSW to initiate an investigation into these matters with a view to laying criminal charges.
